Al-Muzaffar bin al-Fadl Al-Alawi. Praise be to Allah, Whose signs are dazzling, Whose assaults are overpowering, Whose benevolence is ancient, Whose authority is magnificent, Whose gifts are ample, Whose drinking places are delightful, Whose generosity is vast, Whose threat is crushing, Whose gift is abundant, Whose trial is beautiful, Whose reward is great, Whose punishment is severe, Whose Book is mighty, Whose reckoning is brief. The sights do not encompass Him, nor does the beholder perceive Him, nor do barriers veil Him, nor is He described as incapable. He sent Muhammad as His Prophet, His chosen one, and His pure friend, proclaiming the truth, truthful in speech, clarifying the newness of the paths, and advising all creation. So he stood up while the banners of guidance were obliterated, the landmarks of piety were effaced, ignorance was roaming, and misguidance was comprehensive. So he proclaimed what he was commanded, repelled what was denied, guided to rationality, and demolished what disbelief had founded and built. May Allah bless him and his family, the lamps of darkness, the keys to blessings, the downpours of wisdom, and the garments of generosity, and his chosen companions, and his elected parties, a perpetual prayer until the Day of Judgment. As for what follows: I was one day in the assembly of our master, the chief of the chiefs of mankind, the king of the ministers of the East and the West, whose commands are effective far and near, Mu'ayyad al-Din, acceptable to the Commander of the Faithful, Abu Talib Muhammad bin Ahmad—may Allah support his state and support his word. The foreheads of virtues have prostrated to his manners, and the lips of the piercing stars have kissed the soles of his high aspirations. Aspirations soaring over the head of Suha (a star)... seeking the center of element and origin. And for everything there is an element that shelters to... the ends of its center without aversion. His literature relieves poverty from the captivity of thoughts, and his talents extract pearls from the navels of the seas. The markets of virtues are established with him on their stalk, and the she-camels of favors are driven from before him with their loads. The extreme reach of his mind is not attained by the limits of ability, and if another is compared to him, it is said: 'Amr has outgrown the collar.' His house is fragrant with the scent of Darin (musk), and his place is worthy of the descent of blessing. A house in which flow torrents of virtues... and favors for a questioning one or a asker. So the excuse is withheld in it from a hoper... and knowledge is spread in it for the ignorant. The discussion of poetry and its attributes took place, entering its doors and striking its smooth stones (testing it), what is permissible in it and what is prohibited, mentioning the virtue for which it was praised and the vice for which it was blamed, researching its benefits and harms, its purity and impurities, and whether engaging in it is better, or abandoning it is more abundant and weightier. Each of those present brought the strangest of what he heard, the most wondrous of what he innovated, the most novel of what he understood, and the most subtle of what he knew. So despite the excuse-making in it, he was a brother to deficiency, and after prolixity, a companion of weakness and shortcoming. So our master commanded—and his command is obeyed, and his opposition is not possible—that I establish for him papers on that, and seek rain from the clouds of the minds of the predecessors in showers, and not need in it to seek guidance from others, nor to seek illumination from anyone else. So I hastened to follow his desire, and seek his intended pasture, 'And if he wished, his fire-stick when he struck it would have ignited, and all game is in the belly of the wild ass (meaning he encompasses all).' I have answered that in five chapters, devoid of prattle and excess, inclining to brevity, and speaking with conciseness. For comprehensive coverage of what has been narrated in it, and written on its meanings, requires the authorship of several books, and emptiness for it in a long period, and time for that is tight, and attachments hinder and obstruct it. 'And I swear if something other than you came to us... its messenger, but we found no defense against you.' We have named this book 'Nadra al-Ighrid fi Nusrat al-Qarid' (The Freshness of the Spadix in Support of Poetry), as we based it on the defense of poetry and poets, and we sharpened it for the struggle of the debater and peers. We hope from Allah Almighty that we present in its chapters, and sharpen from its blades, what will be quenching for thirst, beneficial for illness, satisfying for the one lacking in literature, and convincing for the one looking into its meanings. Even if it is a peak that has been ascended, and a virginity that has been deflowered, we, with the help of the Ancient—Exalted is His Majesty—strive not to fall short in that betting, nor to be belittled regarding the positions of those knights. And from Him, Glory be to Him and Exalted, we seek success and the straightening of the path, and He is our Sufficiency and the best Disposer of affairs. Chapter One: On the description of poetry and its rulings, and the explanation of its conditions and divisions.

Chapter Two: On what the poet is permitted to use and what is not permitted, and by which the correctness of speech is recognized and allowed. Chapter Three: On the merit of poetry and its benefits, and its impact on hearts and its occurrences. Chapter Four: On revealing what it was praised for, and blamed because of, and whether engaging in it is more reforming, or rejecting it is more abundant and weightier. Chapter Five: On what the poet must aim for, avoid, discard, and seek. 

**Chapter One**
**On the Description of Poetry and Its Rulings**
**And Explanation of Its Conditions and Divisions**

The first thing I begin with in this chapter is to say that the derivation of the word 'Shi'r' (poetry) is from knowledge, perception, and acumen. You say: 'Layta shi'ri' (Would that I knew) whether the rain of the sky hit the dwellings of Asma', meaning: Would that my knowledge. The poet said - recited by Ibn al-A'rabi:
'Would that I knew (shi'ri), while wishes do not benefit... Will I leave early one day while my affair is resolved?
And under my saddle is a Zafayan Mayla'... A lean camel, if urged, she strides wide.
As if she is a wailing woman grieving... weeping for a dead one while another is the pained one.'
Zafayan: A she-camel that struts in her walk, and Mayla': fast and escaping. The poet was called a 'Sha'ir' (poet) for his knowledge and acumen. As for them calling poetry 'Qarid', it is because its derivation is from 'Qard' which is cutting, because it is cut from speech a cutting, meaning it is severed from it a severing, just as a thing is cut with scissors (Miqrad). Allah Almighty said: "And when it set, it cut them (taqriduhum) to the left," meaning it passed them and left them on one of the two sides. Abdul Aziz bin Hatim bin Al-Nu'man Ibn Al-Ahmar said, and he used to satirize Al-Farazdaq:
'I exile the speck of poetry from it when I cut it (aqriduhu)... So there is no defect nor fault in my poetry.
As if I select my poetry and scoop it... From the wave of a deep, swelling, overflowing sea.
From it are strange proverbs, famous... gathered; indeed, it is my arrangement and my mastery.'
As for 'Qasid', which is the plural of 'Qasida' like 'Safin' is the plural of 'Safina', its word is derived from 'Qisda', which is a piece of something when it breaks, as if it is a piece of speech. From that is 'Rumh Qisad' (a broken spear) and 'taqassada' when it becomes pieces. Al-Musayyab bin 'Alas said:
'I will surely send with the winds a poem (Qasida)... from me, carried deep to Al-Qa'qa'.
It arrives at the waters, so it never ceases to be strange... among the people, between proverbs and hearing.'
As for their naming the poem 'Qafiyah', it is because the rhyme (Qafiyah) follows (taqfu) the verse, meaning it trails it. They named the whole by a single name for brevity and abbreviation, just as they named the poem in its entirety a 'Kalimah' (word), and the 'Kalimah' is a single utterance, inclining towards abbreviating speech and relying on what indicates completeness in it. Al-Khansa' said:
'And a rhyme (Qafiyah) like the edge of the spearhead... remains while the one who said it perishes.
You spoke it, O Ibn Amr, so you made it easy... and people did not speak the likes of it.'
I say: Poetry is an expression of organized words indicating understood meanings. And if you wish, you can say: Poetry is an expression of arranged words indicating intended meanings. If prose is compared to it, [poetry] is more brilliant in beginnings, purer in endings, faster in rein, more eloquent in tongue, more wandering as a proverb, sharper as a blade, straighter as arrows, more intense in dispute, brighter as a star, more blooming as a flower, more lasting in marks, purer in smiles, more intelligent in pathways, purer in landmarks, more elegant in hearing, and more sticking to natures. Al-Asma'i said: Poetry is what its wording is little, its meaning is easy, fine, and subtle; that which if you hear it, you think you can attain it, but if you attempt it, you find it far. Whatever is other than that is organized speech. Some eloquent people said: Poetry is an expression of a current proverb, a rare simile, and a metaphor with luxurious wording. Al-Ghaznawi narrated to me from Hibatullah known as Ibn al-Shajari, who said: Abu Zakariya al-Tabrizi told me, saying: I used to ask Al-Ma'arri about poetry I read to him, and he would say to me: 'This is good organization (Nazm).' But if a good verse passed by him, he would say: 'O Abu Zakariya, this is Poetry.' As for poetry, it requires tools, and in it are titles and it has attributes. We will mention that generally, and explain it in detail, without intending order in it, since presenting one chapter over another does not require refinement. Regarding poetry:

1 - Grammar (Nahw) 2 - Rhetoric (Balagha) 3 - Eloquence (Fasaha) 4 - Literal and Metaphorical (Haqiqa and Majaz) 5 - Craft and Crafted (San'a and Masnu') 6 - Establishing Meter (Iqamat al-Wazn) 7 - Rhymes (Qawafi) 8 - Titles (Alqab), which are: a - Allusion (Ishara) b - Metonymy (Kinaya), also called Tatbi' (Following), 9 - Balance (Muwazana), which is Similarity (Mumathala) 10 - Paronomasia (Tajnis), and of it is Pure (Mahd) and Absolute (Mutlaq), which is verbal paronomasia, and Variant (Mughayir) and Proximate (Muqarib), and semantic paronomasia, and the Aspiring (Mutmi'), Substituted (Mubdal), and Differing (Mukhtalif), and script paronomasia called Tashif (Misreading), and partial paronomasia, and Completed (Mutammam), and Rhyme paronomasia, and Similar (Mumathil). And in it: 11 - Antithesis (Tibaq) 12 - Exportation (Tasdir), which is returning the ends of speech to its beginnings 13 - Apostrophe (Iltifat) 14 - Digression (Istitrad) 15 - Division (Taqsim) 16 - Arrowing (Tas'him) 17 - Inlaying (Tarsi'), also called Checkering (Tafwif) 18 - Repetition (Tardid) 19 - Correspondence (Muqabala) 20 - Exception (Istithna') 21 - Deepening (Ighal), also called Delivery (Tabligh) 22 - Metaphor (Isti'ara) 23 - Simile (Tashbih) 24 - Sound Padding in Useful Meaning (Hashw Sadid) 25 - Following (Mutaba'a) 26 - Transition (Makhlas) 27 - Inclusion (Tadmin), which is Tasmits and Tawshih 28 - Feigned Ignorance (Tajahul al-Arif) 29 - Mumatana, which is Exhaustion and Authorization 30 - Plagiarism (Sariqa) and its praiseworthy and blameworthy types 31 - Criticism (Naqd). And other things which we will clarify, explain, specify, and expound upon by way of brevity without excess, due to the need of prolixity for a long time, extended life, and extensive speech. And Allah is the Grantor of success to the clear path of guidance by His will and generosity. 

1 - As for Grammar, it is one of the conditions of the speaker, whether he is a versifier or a prose writer, an orator or a poet. It is impossible to dispense with it except for the mute who cannot articulate a single letter. Some eloquent people used to say: 'I find for solecism (Lahn) in my mouth a stench like the stench of meat.' The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "May Allah have mercy on a man who corrected his tongue." This is an encouragement to rectify the tongue and discipline the human being. Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) said: 'Learn grammar, for the Children of Israel disbelieved because of a single letter written in the Noble Gospel, which was: "Ana walladtu 'Isa" (I gave birth to Jesus - with shaddah on Lam), so they lightened it (to "waladtu" - I begot) and disbelieved.' What has been narrated urging the learning of grammar and regarding the honor of its virtue and the majesty of its craft, if we undertook to recount it, we would need a separate book for it. For by knowing it, the Book of Allah (Mighty and Majestic) is understood, and what it contained of His wisdom, and what He deposited in it of His clear verses, His illuminating proofs, His clear Quran, and His healing admonitions. And by it, the traditions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) leading to his commands, prohibitions, laws, and sunan are understood. By it, a person expands in his logic; if he speaks, he is eloquent; if he argues, he clarifies; if he writes, he is expressive; and if he gives a sermon, he impresses.

The meaning of 'Nahw' (Grammar) is pursuing the direction (samt) of the speech of the Arabs in its inflection, including declension (I'rab), dualization, pluralization, breaking (irregular plurals), diminutives, attribution (Nisba), and other things. It is originally a common verbal noun (masdar) from your saying: 'Nahawtu nahwan', meaning I intended an intention. Then the pursuit of this type of knowledge was specifically designated by it, so it became as if restricted to it and not others, just as 'Fiqh' (Jurisprudence) is originally the verbal noun of 'Faqihtu al-shay'', meaning I understood it. Then the science of Sharia regarding the lawful and unlawful was specifically designated by it. And just as 'Bayt Allah' (House of Allah) was specifically designated for the Kaaba, even though all houses belong to Allah Almighty. Parallels of what was common then restricted in its genus to one of its types are many. It was narrated about a Bedouin that he said: 'Indeed you look in many "Nuhuww" (directions),' likening it to ' 'Utuww' (arrogance/excess), which is rare in their speech. The rule for such a Waw, if it comes in a plural, is [to become] Ya', like their saying in the plural of 'Haqw': 'Huqiyy'. The first to speak of Grammar was Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, and the story regarding that is well-known. When the method became clear by his example, and the straight and crooked became distinct by his speech, the paths in it branched out, and the causes in its meanings expanded. The origin is three words: Noun (Ism), Predicate/Verb (Khabar), and Particle (Adat) indicating a meaning. The Noun is every described thing of creation. Creation is three things: either a body, a color, or an action. As for the Predicate, it is everything that establishes an unknown or sets up a description from a noun or other. However, the word we allocated to it is the word whose utterance only occurs as a predicate, and it is every word indicating the occurrence of a temporary movement, like your saying: 'Fa'ala' (he did) and 'Yaf'alu' (he does), or 'Fu'ila' (it was done) or 'Yuf'alu' (it is being done). As for what occurs sometimes as a predicate and sometimes as a subject (Mukhbar 'anhu), we disliked naming it a predicate since its state does not endure. As for the Particle, it is everything other than being a noun or a predicate. It is a word that does not occur as a description nor described. The word we named Predicate is, in the terminology of grammarians, Verb (Fi'l), and that is a mistake. Because your saying 'Fa'ala' or 'Yaf'alu' or 'Fu'ila' or 'Yuf'alu' is merely informing about the occurrence of the action and its happening, and informing about the occurrence of the thing is different from the thing itself. If 'Fa'ala' or 'Yaf'alu' were an Action (Fi'l), you could describe it, praising it or blaming it, like saying: 'Ni'ma al-Fi'l' (Excellent is the action) he believed and reformed, and 'Bi'sa al-Fi'l' (Miserable is the action) he disbelieved and corrupted. This is the summary of the explanation of the three words by which Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, encompassed utterances and gathered meanings. For every type of these three types, there are different forms, divergent branches, and distinct meanings that grammarians have finished with in their books. What he presented has objections that Abu Ali answered in 'Ilal al-Mantiq' (Causes of Logic), and I narrated his speech and reported from him. As for poetry, its skin is not safe from tanning defects (nafal), nor its sick part cured from illnesses, except by knowing Grammar, extending one's reach in it, and understanding its obscure and hidden parts, as the modern poet said: 'And if you want the most majestic of sciences... then the most majestic of them is the rectifer of tongues.' In this brief overview is sufficiency.

2 - As for Rhetoric (Balagha), it is Eloquence (Fasaha). It is said: 'Balugha al-rajul' (The man became eloquent) with a Damma on the Lam, so he is 'Baligh'. There is no difference between Balagha and Bayan (Clarity/Expression) except in the wording. Someone was asked about Balagha, and he said: 'Brief speech whose meaning reaches your heart closer than its wording reaches your ear.' Ja'far bin Muhammad al-Sadiq, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'The eloquent one (Baligh) is named Baligh only because he reaches (yablughu) his need with the easiest of his striving.' Ibn al-A'rabi said: Al-Mufaddal al-Dabbi said: I asked a Bedouin about Balagha, and he said: 'Brevity without incapacity, and prolixity without nonsense.' Al-Attabi was asked: 'What is Balagha?' He said: 'He who makes you understand his need without impediment, nor stuttering, nor seeking help.' Some wise men were asked about Balagha, and they said: 'Whoever takes many meanings and conveys them with few words, and takes few meanings and generates from them many words, he is eloquent.' It was said: 'Balagha is speech that is good upon hearing it, concise upon its improvisation.' It was said: 'Balagha is a glance indicating what is in the conscience.' It was said: 'The eloquent one is he who reaches what he wants, whether he lengthens or shortens.' Some said: 'Eloquence is correcting the divisions and choosing the speech.' It was said: 'Balagha is knowing separation from connection.' I say: The combination of B-L-Gh (Ba-Lam-Ghayn) means attaining what a human attempts with strength and mastery of ability. From that is: 'Balaghta al-amr wal-gharad' (You reached the matter and the goal) if you stood at its limit and overlooked its end; were it not for your strength over it, you would not have reached it. From that is Balagha, for if you stand at the limits of speech and ends of meanings, that indicates your ability in literature and your mastery of the language of the Arabs. Whether you are brief or verbose, you are eloquent in it, and what you brought is eloquence. From that is Gh-L-B (Ghayn-Lam-Ba); 'Ghalab' (victory/overcoming) only comes from strength, mastery, and ability. From that is L-Gh-B (Lam-Ghayn-Ba); 'Lughub' is fatigue, and that only comes from diligence and intensity of movement indicating strength and ability for movements and mastery of violent striving at all times. From that is B-Gh-L (Ba-Ghayn-Lam); it is said 'Baghghala al-faras' (The horse paced) if it walked between the trot ('Anaq) and the pace (Hamlaja). From it is 'Tabghil', which is a fast walk with variation, and that only comes from strength and ability to strive. Among the highest degrees of Balagha and the loftiest in prose speech is His Almighty's saying: "And it was said, 'O earth, swallow your water, and O sky, withhold your rain.' And the water subsided, and the matter was accomplished, and the ship came to rest on the Judi. And it was said, 'Away with the wrongdoing people.'" And His Almighty's saying: "So proclaim what you are commanded." Among Balagha in poetic speech is the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'Stop, let us weep from the memory of a beloved and a dwelling...'
For he stopped and asked to stop, wept and asked to weep, and expressed love by remembering the beloved and the dwelling in half a verse. Tarafa said:
'I am not one to dwell in the hilltops out of fear... but when the people ask for support, I support.'
The meaning is more than the wording. He says: I do not dwell in hidden places fearing hospitality (having to feed guests), but I dwell in visible places that are not hidden from the knocking guest. So if I am asked for hospitality, I give it. He presented speech indicating the negation of his dwelling in hilltops only out of fear. When he mentioned support (rifd) in the second half, it indicated that the fear was of hospitality. He did not counter the wording by saying: 'But I dwell in the highland, visible, and I am brave.' He sufficed with the listener's knowledge and what the speech indicated. This is pure eloquence. 

3 - As for Eloquence (Fasaha), speaking about it requires a long explanation that would take us away from our purpose, and restricting it is neither healing nor sufficient. We have exhausted the divisions of that in the 'Alawiyya Epistle', and we followed in it the path of Abdullah bin Sinan al-Khafaji in the beginning of his book titled 'Sirr al-Fasaha' (The Secret of Eloquence). Fasaha is derived from disclosure (Kashf) and the lifting of ambiguity. It is said: 'Afsaha al-laban ifsahan' (The milk became clear) when the colostrum goes away from it and the milk becomes pure. And the she-camel 'Afsahat', so she is 'Mufsih', when her colostrum ceases and her milk becomes pure. And the milk 'Fasuha' when you uncover its foam from it. The poet said:
'............ ... And under the foam is the clear (Fasih) milk.'
And 'Afsaha al-subh' (The morning became clear) when it was revealed and appeared. Everything clear is 'Mufsih'. Based on that, every speaker is eloquent (Fasih), and what does not speak is mute (A'jam). This brief overview in this place is sufficient.

4 - As for the Literal (Haqiqa) and Metaphorical (Majaz), the Literal is what is established upon its original placement in the language when used. The Metaphorical is what is contrary to that. Ali bin Isa al-Rummani said: The Literal is the indication of meaning without the aspect of metaphor (Isti'ara), and the Metaphorical is exceeding the original to metaphor. One only deviates from the Literal to the Metaphorical for three meanings, which are: Expansion (Ittisa'), Emphasis (Tawkid), and Simile (Tashbih). If these qualities are absent, the Literal is more worthy of use. Allah Almighty said: "And We admitted him into Our mercy." This is a Majaz, and it contains the three qualities. As for Expansion, He increased the names of directions, and the place is a noun, which is Mercy. As for Simile, He likened Mercy, even if entry into it is not physically valid, to what can be entered, and thus placed it in its stead. As for Emphasis, He reported about an accident (attribute) with what is reported about a substance. This is elevating the accident and aggrandizing it, as it was put in the domain of what is seen, touched, and witnessed. Majaz in the poetry of Arabs is numerous and uncountable. From it is the saying of the first:
'Abundant of robe (generous), when he smiles laughing... the necks of wealth break at his laughter.'
Tarafa said:
'And a face as if the sun cast its robe... upon it, pure of color, not wrinkled.'
He assigned a robe to the sun, which is a substance, because it is more eloquent than light, which is an accident. All that is of these metaphors falls under Majaz. Glory be to His Majesty, He said: "So whoever disbelieves in Taghut and believes in Allah has grasped the most trustworthy handhold (Al-'Urwa Al-Wuthqa) with no break in it. And Allah is Hearing and Knowing." He began the verse with literal speech, then made the answer metaphorical and a metaphor because its occurrence is more emphatic than the literal. The intent is to liken the one holding fast to the conditions of faith to one holding fast to a firm handhold of a rope's loops because he protects himself by it from slippery slides and destructive falls. Then He Almighty said: "no break in it," distancing it from the likeness of familiar loops which might break with prolonged pulling or whose strength wears out over time. 

5 - As for Craft (San'a) and Crafted (Masnu'), Craft is an expression for accidents in crafted things, such as repair and corruption, length and shortness, hugeness and thinness, greenness and redness, motion and stillness, and things theologians call accidents. As for Crafted things, they are the things upon which these accidents succeed. So Craft and Crafted things are originated (muhdath). Among crafted things is the animal that Allah Almighty creates, and images in inanimate objects that we make. The indications in images from the skill of painters in their actions upon them make you imagine that some of them are speaking even though they do not speak, and some make you imagine they are moving while they are still. You call the body 'crafted' in the literal language, and you call it 'craft' by expansion and Majaz. Do you not see that you say: 'This is a crafted body of good craft', or 'ugly craft', and 'perfect craft' or 'imperfect craft', even if the origin of the two words in them is one. I only presented this as a prelude so you know that Craft in poetry is an expression for the organization (Nazm) that purifies it from prose, and gathers its scattered parts after dispersion and cracking. And that the Crafted is the poetry whose element is prose speech. The Crafted is not called crafted until it exits from non-existence to existence. When it exists, it is called crafted because it is witnessed and known. Then criticism takes turns on it after that, so it is said of it: complete and deficient, beautiful and ugly, sick and sound, and good and bad. I saw people among the authors mixing Craft with Criticism and Criticism with Craft, and not distinguishing between the Crafted and the Craft, and this is a mistake and excess. Do you not see that it is not permissible to say regarding poetry you haven't heard or connected with: 'good and bad', until you stand upon it and repeat looking at it? You have known by this subtle indication and light expression what the difference is between the Crafted and the Craft, and between the Craft and the Criticism, and Allah is the Grantor of success. 

6 - As for Establishing Meter, it is an expression of a natural taste that preserved its measures (fusul) from addition and decrease, and adjusted them with the adjustment of justice by the scale. If every versifier of poetry needed, in establishing his meter, correcting its breakage, and adjusting its measures, to know Prosody ('Arud) and Rhymes (Qawafi), only a few people would have composed poetry. However, if the poet knows them, he cannot dispense with them.

As for Prosody ('Arud), which is feminine, it is the scale of poetry by which its sound is extracted from its broken. All poetry is composed of a Sabab (cord), a Watad (peg), and a Fasilah (separator). The Sabab is two Sababs, the Watad two Watads, and the Fasilah two Fasilahs. The scansion (Taqti') of poetry is based on pronunciation, not writing. Every stressed letter counts as two letters: the first silent, and the second moving (vowelled). The difference between the silent and the moving is that the three vowels succeed upon the silent, while the moving is specialized with one of them. The paradigms by which poetry is scanned are eight: two are five-lettered, which are Fa'ulun, Fa'ilun; and six are seven-lettered, which are: Mafa'ilun, Mustaf'ilun, Fa'ilatun, Mufa'alatun, Mutafa'ilun, Maf'ulatu. Whatever comes after that is a Zihaf (deviation) of it, or a branch upon it. Zihaf is permissible like the original, and Kasr (breakage) is prohibited. Zihaf only occurs in Asbab (cords), and Kharm and Qat' (cutting) only occur in Awtad (pegs). The 'Arud is the name for the last foot in the first half of the verse, and the Darb is the name for the last foot in the second half of the verse. Every rhymed (Musarra') verse, its 'Arud follows the weight of its Darb or what is permissible in its Darb. Tasri' (internal rhyme) is likened to the two leaves of a door. If the verse is devoid of Tasri', it is called Musmat. Poetry in total has thirty-four 'Aruds, sixty-three Darbs, and fifteen meters (seas). The explanation of that has been completed by prosodists in their books, so know it. 

7 - As for Rhymes (Qawafi), the Qafiyah is disputed. According to Abu al-Hasan al-Akhfash and those who followed him among rhyme scholars: The Qafiyah is the last word in the verse. He said: It was named Qafiyah because it follows (taqfu) the verse. According to Al-Nadr bin Shumayl, Mu'arrij, and Abu Amr al-Jarmi, it is the last half of the verse. It was said it is the verse in its entirety, and it was said the poem in its entirety. According to Al-Khalil bin Ahmad: The Qafiyah is from the end of the verse to the first silent letter preceding it along with the moving letter before the silent one. Upon his saying is the reliance, for the saying is what Hadhram said. The Qafiyah is divided into three things: Roots (Usul), Letters (Huruf), and Movements (Harakat). The Roots are: Mutakawis, Mutarakib, Mutadarik, Mutawatir, Mutaradif. The Letters are: Dakhil, Ta'sis, Ridf, Khuruj, Wasl, and Rawi. The Movements are: Tawjih, Ishba', Rass, Hadhw, Nafadh, and Majra. Four defects occur in the Qafiyah, which are: Ikfa', Iqwa', Ita', and Sinad. And Tadmin, which is that the verse is not complete except with the one following it, and it is among the disliked defects of poetry. This has been organized in poetry. The poet said:
'The Rhymes are five-fold threes... Movements, letters, and corruption.
So their beginning is Rass, Hadhw, and Ishba'... and Majra, and in Nafadh is the equipment.
And the letters: Al-Rawi, Al-Ridf, and Al-Ta'... sis (Ta'sis), Al-Wasl, and Al-Khuruj is the pillar.
And the defects: Al-Ita', Al-Iqwa', and Al-Ik... fa (Ikfa'), and in them Tadmin then Al-Sinad.'
Another said:
'The letters of Rhymes are six, evident... a system gathers scattered ones for them.
Rawi, Wasl, Khuruj, and its Ridf... and its Ta'sis, then Al-Dakhil is completion.
And following this, its movements are necessary... likewise six, an Imam fashioned them.
So Majra, Tawjih, Hadhw, and its Rass... and its Ishba', then Al-Nafadh is a support.'
All letters of the alphabet can be a Rawi except Waw, Ya', and Alif, the silent additions that follow what is before them, for they are never a Rawi at all. The Alif of duality, the Waw of plural, and the Ya' of the feminine pronoun are not Rawi. The Alif substituted for Tanwin like your saying 'Ra'aytu Zayda' is not Rawi, nor the light Nun like your saying 'Idriban', nor the Hamza substituted for the feminine Alif in pause like your saying 'Hadhihi Hubla' (This is a pregnant woman), nor the Ha' of pause, the Ha' of pronoun, and the feminine Ha'; all these are not Rawi. If what is before these Ha's is silent, they can be Rawi. The original Ha' may be a Rawi, whether what is before it is silent or moving, like the saying of Ru'bah bin al-'Ajjaj:
'Ubayla killed me and I did not notice... Life is nothing but the heedlessness of the love-struck.
When she saw me, worn of camouflage... Shining of the bald forehead stones.
After the raven-black youth, the foolish.'

The Rawi letter was named Rawi because it is from 'Riwa'', which is the rope used to tie loads and luggage to gather them. 'Rawa' in their speech is for joining, gathering, and connecting. Likewise, the Rawi letter; all letters of the verse join and gather to it. Thus, rhymes are seals on the address of poetry, gathering the ends of its meanings, grasping the reins of its foals. 

8 - As for Titles (Alqab), they are divided into sections, and for each section of them is a chapter. Among them:

**Chapter of Allusion (Ishara)**
Allusion is one of the beauties of Badi' (rhetoric). Its meaning is the inclusion of few words over many meanings, even if by the slightest glance one infers what was concealed of long explanation, like the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'On a huge horse that gives you before asking him... varieties (afanin) of running, neither stiff nor weak.'
Contemplate what is under the word 'afanin', and what is associated with it of all types of quality, then he negated stiffness and weakness from him, which are the two biggest defects of horses.
Zuhair said:
'If I met you and we faced each other... there would be a guarantor for every denied thing.'
This is few words indicating much meaning. As some Bedouins said:
'I made my hands a sash for him... and some knights do not embrace.'
His saying: 'I made my hands a sash for him' is a marvelous allusion to embracing without its word, and it indicates it.
Al-A'sha said:
'You hear a whisper from the jewelry when she leaves... as a rustling 'ishriq plant sought help from a wind.'
He alluded by that to the slenderness of the waist, agility, and lankness, because the movement of the sashes indicates that. As for anklets, bracelets, and rings, they are described with silence and muteness. In the verse is another allusion to the intensity of motion, which is his saying: 'as a rustling 'ishriq plant sought help from a wind', for the 'ishriq is a tree intense in motion in a weak breeze, so how about if it sought help from a wind?
Al-Khansa' said:
'The rising of the sun reminds me of Sakhr... and I remember him at every setting of the sun.'
A good allusion to the time of raiding, the time of Maysir (gambling game), and feeding the guest.
Al-Quhayf said:
'The call of Ka'b came to me at Al-Aqiq... so the Nab' (tree) and the thirsty spears yearned.'
A good allusion to aiding him with the army.
Another said:
'And Zayd is dead with the grief of the bustard... because Sukayna and Al-Rabab departed.'
A good allusion to the intensity of worry. That is because birds gather in places far from humans and shed their feathers there, including the bustard. Then they graze until their feathers grow. When the feathers of all those birds grow, the bustard lags behind them because its feathers are slow to appear. So all the birds rise and the bustard remains, so most of them die of grief.
Ibn al-A'rabi recited:
'We walked and leveled the graves at 'Aqil... so its graves became beautiful after ugliness.'
Meaning we killed for our killed ones, so the number of our killed and theirs became equal. This is a wondrous, subtle allusion to taking revenge. In this chapter is breadth, and our effort is to be brief.
Close to the meaning of Allusion, though the expression differs, is:

**Chapter of Metonymy (Kinaya)**
Some people may call it Tatbi' (Following) because the poet says a meaning and brings a word following it; if the follower indicates, it reveals the followed. From that is His Almighty's saying: "And hearts reached the throats," a metonymy for the intensity of the matter and war. The meaning of that is that hearts rose from their places and shied away as if they wanted to exit the bodies, separating from them.
And His Almighty's saying: "And We did not make them a body not eating food." Within this speech is a metonymy for drinking, not mentioned due to the indication of eating to it, and a metonymy for defecation and urination, because whoever eats needs to drink, and whoever eats and drinks needs to defecate and urinate.
Al-Mubarrad recited:
'She says, while weeping has shown scars... in his eye: Will you not treat your eye with kohl?
For I have seen kohl occupy an amount... of the eye, an amount that was not occupied away from you.'
A metonymy that he does not like to occupy his eye from looking at her, because the time that goes into occupying with kohl was not, before kohl, occupied with other than looking at her, so he dislikes not being in the state he was in.
Bal'a' bin Qais al-Kinani said:
'With me is every loose-robed one, as if he... when he walks, is limping on the sole of the foot.'
A metonymy for luxury and grace.
Al-Minhal said:

'If there is heat, they advance me to its heat... and if there is cold, they delay me from the cold.'
He used heat as a metonymy for evil, and cold for good.
They recited:
'With salt, what is feared to change is preserved... so what is the medicine for salt if changes befall it?'
A metonymy for the matter for whose revealing the Sultan is hoped, so that Sultan is afflicted with a matter that distracts him from performing what is hoped of him.
Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani said:
'Six fathers, they are what they are... they are better than whoever drinks the water of clouds.'
A metonymy that they are the best of all people, because all people drink the water of clouds.
Mu'aqqir al-Bariqi said:
'And every thrower in the running places, as if she... when she washes with water, is a breaking eagle.'
He describes a mare, likening her, when she sweats from galloping and fatigue, to a breaking eagle, which is the Fat-ha'; Fatakh is a praiseworthy softness in the wing. This is a metonymy using water for sweat. He meant that in this state where her likes become weak, this is her condition, so how would she be at the start of her run!
The predecessor to this meaning is Imru' al-Qais where he says:
'As if she, when the water overflowed and she gathered herself... is a white-headed eagle to whom a wolf appeared at the lookout.'
In this verse are additions that Mu'aqqir's verse did not reach, which is his saying 'the water overflowed'. Overflowing is greater than what is washed with, because washing happens from the overflowing and more. And his saying 'gathered herself' is an exaggeration in effort and fatigue. And his saying 'a white-headed eagle to whom a wolf appeared at the lookout': the Saq'a' is the eagle with whiteness in its face. If a wolf appears to it, it is more intense for its swooping. And if its swooping is from a lookout, it is more intense for its descent.
Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah said:
'Far is the falling place of the earring; either to Nawfal... belongs her father, or to Abd Shams and Hashim.'
He used that as a metonymy for the length of necks. Similar is the saying of Humayd al-Arqat:
'Long is the falling place of the twins of earrings.'
Amr bin Qi'as al-Ghutayfi said:
'And a black-eyed one, intimate of a rock... watching me with anticipation, I have shot.'
He used that as a metonymy for a doe.
'And meat that people did not taste before me... I ate in emptiness and selected.'
Al-Asma'i, Abu Amr al-Shaybani, and Ibn al-A'rabi said he used that as a metonymy for the flesh of his son, for he hungered so he slaughtered him and ate him. Others said he used it as a metonymy for a king whom he satirized and no one had satirized before him, so it was as if he ate his flesh dead.
'And water not from a quenching spring... nor water of the sky have I drawn.'
A metonymy for his tears.
'And a girl disputing my robe with me... behind the tribe, I have no house upon me.'
A metonymy for the wind.
'And a fire kindled without a fire-stick... I stirred its hell then warmed myself.'
A metonymy for war.
'And a house not of fur and hair... on the back of the mount I have built.'
He used it as a metonymy for a verse of poetry he composed on the back of his camel.
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And a carrier of ninety, she did not meet of them... in a place except a trustworthy brother, empty.'
He used that as a metonymy for the quiver and the arrows in it, meaning he did not find for it a child except a trustworthy brother, describing her arrows with quality, accuracy, and penetration.
The story of Khawwat bin Jubayr al-Ansari with the woman of the two butter-skins (Dhat al-Nihyayn) is famous. He came to her to buy ghee (clarified butter) and found her alone, so he desired her. She untied a skin, he tasted it and pushed it to her. She untied another, he tasted it and was not pleased. He said: 'Hold it, for my camel has strayed.' She said: 'Wait until I tie the head of this skin.' He said: 'Either you hold it, or I throw it from my hand.' So she held it. When he occupied her hands, he assaulted her and she could not repel him, so he fulfilled his desire from her. That was in the Jahiliyyah. When Islam came, Khawwat embraced Islam and witnessed Badr. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to him one day, smiling: 'O Khawwat, what did your straying camel do?' He said: 'O Messenger of Allah, Islam has shackled it.' It was narrated that he said to him: 'O Khawwat, how is your straying?' He said: 'O Messenger of Allah, Allah has provided better than it, and I seek refuge in Allah from deficiency after increase (al-hawr ba'd al-kawr).' The Prophet (peace be upon him) used the best and most subtle metonymy for his past deed. And Khawwat's saying: 'Islam has shackled it' is a beautiful metonymy for repentance, adhering to the limits of Islam, and knowing the lawful and forbidden. This example in this chapter is sufficient, Allah willing. Among them:

**Chapter of Balance (Muwazana)**

This is when the poet brings a verse where the number of words in its first half equals the number of words in the last half, and the parts are equal. If anything of its parts changes when scanned, or increases or decreases, balance is not achieved. Likewise, if the parts are equal but the words change by increase or decrease. This is hardly achieved by a poet except after knowing Prosody. As for it occurring coincidentally without intent, its occurrence is not counted, though the occurrence of that in Arab poetry without intent is frequent.
Mu'aqqir al-Bariqi said:
'They passed by the ropes of the tents, so repelled them... men with the tips of spears, kindlers [of war].'
Its scansion:
Wa marru bi-atnabil buyuti faraddahum
Fa'ulun Mafa'ilun Fa'ulu Mafa'ilun
Rijalun bi-atrafir rimahi masa'iru
Fa'ulun Mafa'ilun Fa'ulu Mafa'ilun
Al-Kindi said:
'We have sheep we drive, abundant... as if the horns of their large ones are sticks.'
Its scansion:
Lana ghanamun nusawwiquha ghizarun
Mufa'alatun Mufa'alatun Fa'ulun
Ka'anna quruna jillatiha 'isiyyu
Mufa'alatun Mufa'alatun Fa'ulun
Another said:
'To whom belongs a relic that became desolate... for Salma at Dhat al-Ghada?'
Its scansion:
Li-man dimnatun aqfarat
Fa'ulun Fa'ulun Fa'al
Li-Salma bi-dhatil ghada
Fa'ulun Fa'ulun Fa'al
From the poetry of the Jinn:
'Did the dispersion of the tribe's unity grieve you... so you are sleepless for it, in pain?'
This verse has equal words and parts, except that its first half ends at the first Ya of 'al-Hayy', and the second Ya remained with the last half, so it exited the condition of balance.
Its scansion:
Ashajaka tashattutu sha'bil hay-
Fa'ilun Fa'ilun Fa'ilun Fa'lun
-yi fa-anta lahu ariqun wasibu
Fa'ilun Fa'ilun Fa'ilun Fa'ilun
If the words were equal and the two halves of the verse were similar, but something of the parts changed, the balance would be invalid, like the poet's saying:
'He benefited so he gave, and ruled so he led... and led so he increased, and returned so he excelled.'
Fa'ulu Fa'ulu Fa'ulu Fa'ulu... Fa'ulu Fa'ulu Fa'ulu Fa'ulun
So it exited the condition because of the shift from Fa'ulu to Fa'ulun. Likewise, if the parts were equal but words increased or decreased, the condition would be invalid. As the poet said:
'If you cannot do a thing, leave it... and surpass it to what you can do.'
The first half is more than the last by a word, though its parts are equal.
Its scansion:
Idha lam tastati' shay'an fa-da'hu
Mafa'ilun Mafa'ilun Fa'ulun
Wa jawizhu ila ma tastati'u
Mafa'ilun Mafa'ilun Fa'ulun
This is a convincing example in this chapter. Among them:

**Chapter of Paronomasia (Tajnis)**
It is when the poet brings two words coupled, close in weight, not distant in organization, not repelling to understanding, accepted by hearing, and nature does not recoil from them. If he increases in paronomasia and makes it three-fold, that is a corruption in craft because two words correspond and the other stands alone without a pair. Some people might approve something of that due to frequent usage and familiarity of hearing, like the saying of Al-Ta'i:
'Salim (Greet) upon the quarter of Salma at Dhi Salam.'
His saying: 'Salim' and 'Salam' are two corresponding words, and the word 'Salma' stood alone without a pair. But due to the familiarity of hearing with the name Salma, Salam, and Salam, it became as if it were one thing. If he had made it four-fold, the correspondence would have been valid, even if the words were heavy on the hearing and heart, and affectation appeared on them. An example of four-fold is if he had said:
'Salim salamta ala Salma bi Dhi Salam.'
As Muslim bin al-Walid said describing wine:
'Sullat wa sullat thumma sulla saliluha... fa-ata salilu saliliha maslula.'
He means it was extracted (sullat) from its vine as grapes, then extracted from its grapes as wine, then the wine was extracted from its jar. It was also said he meant its refinement and that it became consumptive (maslula) from consumption (sill) which is the illness. There is no increase upon the ugliness of this verse. Al-Asma'i used to find the poet's saying repugnant:
'Fa-ma lil-nawa, jadda al-nawa, qata'a al-nawa... kadhaka al-nawa qatta'atun li-wisali.'
He used to say: 'If Allah empowered a sheep over this verse, it would eat its date pits (nawa) and relieve people of it.'
Ishaq al-Mawsili recited to Al-Asma'i his saying:

'O Sarha (tree) of water whose sources are blocked... Is there a path to you that is not blocked?
For a hovering one (ha'im) who hovered (hama) until there is no hovering (hiyam) in him... driven away from the water path, expelled.'
Al-Asma'i said: 'You did well in the poetry, except that these Ha's, if they gathered in Ayat al-Kursi, would have flawed it.' We narrated from some Sheikhs that he used to say: 'The likeness of paronomasia in a verse is like a single mole on the cheek; if it increases, it moves from being appreciated to being ugly, and might obliterate the beauties of the face.' In Al-Ta'i's verse is a good craft, which is returning its Arud (first hemistich end) to its Sadr (beginning). Paronomasia is divided into sections, among them:
a - Pure Paronomasia (Al-Tajnis Al-Mahd). The meaning of Mahd is pure, as if it is from one origin in the sound of its letters. Fresh milk is called Mahd because water has not mixed with it. Abu Hayya al-Bajali said:
'They are prepared for the enemies (Al-'Ida) by youths of a charger (Adiya)... and every broad-armed, determined (Sihmim) middle-aged man.'
His saying: Al-'Ida and Adiya is pure paronomasia, and his saying: Yu'idduha (prepares it) for Al-'Ida is resembling paronomasia. Sihmim is one who is not turned away from his desire. Miskin bin Nadr al-Bajali said:
'And the place of saddle-blankets of her was likened... to the rock (Safa) of a paved [road], the surface (Jadad) of the smooth rock (Safa').'
Al-Safa is the smooth rock, and Al-Safa' is the clear smoothness. He also said:
'So I said to him: Standing has prolonged and allowed... the coupling (Qaruna) of whom you coupled (Qaranta), and the shadow is familiar.
And if he meets grace, she met with a dweller... generous, and a brave one (Zawl) if calamities befell.'
Al-Farazdaq said:
'And indeed Tamim, his mother did not seek... health for him in his cradle with amulets (Tama'im).'
Antara said:
'As if she, on the day she turned away not speaking to us... was a fawn at 'Usfan, languid of eye (Saji al-Tarf), struck [in the eye] (Matruf).'
Sudayf said:
'With chests advanced (Muqaddamat) of old (Qadiman)... and heads like great vessels (Qamaqim), big-headed (Ru'as).
They supported religion with thrusting until it became... clear of path after the inclination of the props (Awasi).'
Yazid bin Jad'a' said:
'And they attacked in the morning another [group], Dirar and his band... and they left the wounded in the brain (Ma'mum) while he is wounded (Amim).'
Al-Ma'mum is one who raves from the wound of his head, and Al-Amim is a stone with which the head is crushed.
Yazid bin Abd al-Madan al-Harithi said:
'Did you ally with Jarm against us in hatred... your enmity is without crime (Jurm) nor blood.
Sufficed us against you our edge (Hadduna) and our iron (Hadiduna)... and a palm, whenever it seeks revenge, it avenges.'
Jarm is a tribe, and his saying 'without Jurm' means without sin. 'Hadduna' means our might, taken from the edge of the sword. 'Hadiduna' means our strength. 'Kafana' (sufficed us) and 'Kaff' (palm) is from the chapter of Variant Paronomasia, and it will be mentioned. Another said:
'Ramim departed and her rope became worn (Rimama)... and she obeyed regarding you he who incited and he who cut.'
Ramim is a woman's name. Among it:
b - Verbal Paronomasia (Tajnis al-Lafz), and they might call it Absolute (Al-Mutlaq). Jarir said:
'You drove away a sick one who sees for his cure... a watering place (Wird), and is prevented if he desires arrival (Wurud).'
In it is paronomasia and antithesis. Dhu al-Rumma said:
'You see the wild ass, the white-flanked one of them, like a hater (Farik)... her mate addressed (Tasadda) her eyes so she turned away (Saddat).'
Her mate is the subject. 'Tasadda' and 'Saddat' is verbal paronomasia, corresponding in meaning because addressing is the opposite of turning away. Al-Afwah al-Awdi said:
'And I cross the desert (Hawjal) seeking familiarity... with a swift (Hawjal), active, strong she-camel.'
Al-Hawjal is the vast desert, and Al-Hawjal is the fast she-camel. Al-Nabigha said:
'And I cross the desert (Kharq) with the Kharqa' (clumsy/fast camel) that has begun... after fatigue to complain of tiredness and weariness.'
Miskin al-Darimi said:
'And I cross the desert (Kharq) with the Kharqa' playfully... when the stars were lamps in the darkness.'
Al-Kharq is the great desert, and Al-Kharqa' is the she-camel that traverses in running. Al-Qutami said:
'A victim of beauties who pleased them and they pleased him... since he grew up (Shabba) until the black forelocks turned gray (Shaba).'
Shabba and Shaba is verbal paronomasia, and it is antithesis because they are opposites of youth and gray hair. Ali bin Jabala said:
'And he returned the white swords (Al-Bid) and the white women (Al-Bid)... to the sheaths and the veils.'

He says: He sufficed war with his awe and protected women with his might. This is a verse of good Correspondence (Muqabala) because the first 'Bid' are swords, so he began the second hemistich by mentioning sheaths, and the second 'Bid' are women, so he delayed what relates to them which is veils. Ibn Ahmar said:
'We wore its joy until we were demanded (uqtudina)... by deeds, and deadlines were decreed (qudina).'
It was said: Iqtida' is demanding, and Qada' is performance. So the wording is paronomasia, and the meaning is application (Tatbiq). It is possible that 'qudina' means estimated and known, so it would be verbal paronomasia only, which is more likely to me than the first. Al-Quhayf said:
'And how, when no crow runs with estrangement (Ghurba)... nor are the intimates mentioned except he becomes confused (Taballada).'
Asma' bin Kharija said:
'Indeed I ask every possessor of medicine (Tibb)... what is the cure for the passion of the lover (Sabb)?'
He also said:
'Since there is nothing but blades we strike with... and our saddles and the mounts of the rider (Rakb).'
Al-Quhayf said:
'Greetings (Hayyan) and life (Hayat) whose soldiers do not harm... an innocent, and single out the sinful aggressor.'
Sa'd bin al-Ghurayr al-Ansari said:
'Is he free, pure-bred, or a mixed breed (Hajin), base... his mother goes early to the drinker and goes late?'
Abu Jilda said:
'And you committed sins in error... and you wept for the unjust (Zalim) the oppressed (Mazlum).'
The unjust is the opposite of the oppressed, and they are derived from injustice (Zulm); paronomasia and antithesis. Al-Qutami said:
'And upon you is Asma' bin Kharija who... knew ('Alima) the deed and taught ('Allama) the youths.'
'Alima and 'Allama is verbal paronomasia corresponding in meaning because 'Alima is accepting something and 'Allama is giving it, and giving is the opposite of accepting because this one took and this one gave. 'Uqal bin Hashimi al-Qayni said:
'So the effort of people other than Banu Ali... is against me ('Alayya) when the fire throws sparks.'
Among it:
c - Variant Paronomasia (Al-Tajnis Al-Mughayir): It is when the poet brings two words: one a noun and the other a verb, like His Almighty's saying: "And I submitted (Aslamtu) with Solomon (Sulayman)", and His Almighty's saying: "Indeed I have turned (Wajjahtu) my face (Wajhiya)", and His saying: "The Approaching Day (Azifa) has approached (Azifat)", and His saying: "I will bring it to you before you stand (Taqum) from your place (Maqam)", and His saying: "We will not assign to them on the Day of Resurrection (Qiyama) any weight", and His saying: "And when We bestow favor upon man, he turns away (A'rada) and distances himself, and when evil touches him, then he is full of extensive (Arid) supplication." So 'A'rada' and 'Arid' is variant paronomasia. This paronomasia is appreciated by the people of Badi' in poetry and is very frequent. We only mention a small portion of it for familiarity and rest. Imru' al-Qais said:
'The ambitious one (Tammah) aspired (Tamiha) from the distance of his land... to clothe me with his disease what he was clothed with.'
Al-Shanfara said:
'So we spent the night as if the house was stoned over us... with a wind (Rihana) that was blown (Rihat) in the evening and rained upon.'
Al-Aqra' bin Mu'adh said:
'And you are their hostage, and every living one... to a term, death (Sha'ub) will seize him (Satasha'buhu).'
Sha'ub is one of the names of death. Dhu al-Rumma said:
'As if the rings and ivory, their backs were bent ('Ijat)... upon an 'Ushar tree with which a valley restrained (Nahha) the torrent.'
Amr bin Khalid al-Taghlibi said:
'They caught up on lean-flanked ones like spears... led (Qud) prepared for every day of raid.'
'Uqal bin Hashim al-Qayni said:
'Gray hair forbids (Yan-ha) he who has intellect (Nuha)... and clemency scolds his ignorance so he becomes dignified.'
He also said:
'Wide-eyed like a wild oryx, a tender wide-eyed one inclined (Saraha)... to the coverts of the wild cows (Siran).'
Saraha means inclined her. Surtu al-shay' asuruhu, and asartuhu means I inclined it. The noun is Sawar. Siran are wild cows. Al-Arji said:
'And I travel by night when the lover is frightened by the night journey (Sura)... and I work the night of the swift working camels.'
Durayd bin al-Simma said:
'I advance the old camel ('Ud) before me and follow him... and I see myself, and the old camel ('Ud) does not walk with me.'
Another said:
'Ibn Layla made the horses run (Jarra) while they were changing color... until they raided with the darkness when it darkened (Zulima).'
Another, who is from Banu Abs, said:
'Convey to you, O Abu Sa'd, a message carried deep... that what is between us has died or become critically ill.'

'And that is because the humiliation of the neighbor allied with you... and that your nose does not disdain (Ta'nafu) disdain (Anafa).'
Another said:
'And Umm Bakr came to us early (Bakarat) blaming us... and there is no great blame upon us in it.'
Tha'lab recited from Ammar bin Abi Tammam al-A'rabi:
'Faq'as boasted (Tafaq'asa) until glory missed Faq'as... and Banu 'Ayya were incapable, and the misleader (Mudallil) was led astray (Dalla).'
These are tribes. Among it:

**Proximate Paronomasia (Al-Tajnis Al-Muqarib)**
Its meaning is that it approximates paronomasia but is not paronomasia, as Muhammad bin Abdul Malik al-Asadi said:
'The mixture returned (Radda) she-camels and camels... and your neighbors wanted (Arada) separation in the morning.'
'Radda' and 'Arada' resemble paronomasia due to proximity but are not paronomasia. Al-Qutami said:
'As if all people are of one mother (Li-umm)... and we are for a cause ('Illah) that rose ('Alat) in elevation.'
The Bedouin said:
'A brother of distance (Shiqqa) whom glory yearns for (Yashtaquhu) as an opportunity... to his family or a covenant not to be broken.'
Abu Qais bin al-Aslat said:
'I prepared for the enemies a flowing [coat of mail]... woven like a pool (Nahy) in the plain.'
Similar is the saying of Qais bin Zuhair:
'They prepare for the enemies every swift mare... and short-haired, firm-fleshed, strong horse.'
Labid said:
'If it were other than me, O Sulayma, today... the impact of accidents would have changed him, except the sharp sword (Sarim), the male (Dhakir).'
Sulayma is a woman's name, vocative. Its meaning: If it were other than me, other than the sharp sword (Sarim Dhakir), the impact of accidents would have changed him. So he raised 'Sarim Dhakir' as an adjective. As was said:
'And every brother, his brother parts from him... by the life of your father, except the two Farqad stars.'
Sa'id bin Abdul Rahman bin Hassan said:
'I rectified his stumble after... the clients conspired (Tamala) to kill him.'
Ka'b al-Ashqari said:
'And we turned (Durna) as the mill turns on its axis... and the swords poured (Darrat) upon the heads of men.'
Zuhair bin Abi Sulma said:
'As if my eye, when the valley (Salil) flowed (Sala) with them... and neighbors, what are they if they are nations.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz included this verse in Pure Paronomasia. I did not see it from that chapter because 'Salil' is from 'Insilal' which is exiting from a thing, as you say 'Insalla al-rajul' from his clothes if he exits from them. And 'Sala al-ma' yasilu' (water flowed) is from 'Saylan' which is running, and from it is 'Sayl' (torrent) which is rushing water. This paronomasia is proximate, similar, not pure. Ibn Qudama followed Ibn al-Mu'tazz in that. Rakkad al-Asadi said:
'She saw you driving (Tusiru) the caravan in the intensity (Sawra) of the forenoon... to her, so she said: The hearing of my ear is its sayer.'
'Tusiru' and 'Sawra' is proximate to paronomasia. Among it:

**Semantic Paronomasia (Tajnis al-Ma'na)**
It is when the poet brings words whose meaning indicates the genus even if he does not mention it. The poet said praising Al-Muhallab:
'He sang to Abu Umm al-Ri'al (Ostrich's father) so his Ostrich fled... from a cloud raining.'
He mentions Al-Muhallab's action with Qatari bin al-Fuja'a. Qatari was nicknamed Abu Na'ama (Father of Ostrich). He wanted to say: 'He sang to Abu Na'ama so his Ostrich fled', meaning his soul, but it did not fit, so he said 'Abu Umm al-Ri'al', the ostrich, which is the plural of Ri'l. Hurayth bin Muhaffid al-Mazini said:
'If he comes to us, Suwayd returns and his face... upon it are bubbles of dust (Ghubra) and darkness (Qatam).'
He wanted to say: Blackness (Sawad) [pun on Suwayd], but he couldn't, so he said 'Ghubra' and 'Qatam', and they are black. Al-Shamakh said:
'And no female mountain goat (Arwa), even if she is dear to us... is closer than a stopped, stubborn one.'
It is narrated 'Hazun' (rugged), meaning she is in the rugged ground, which is what is rough and elevated of the earth. Arwa is a woman. The stopped, stubborn one is a female mountain goat (Arwiyya) of the wild, and the woman was named after her. He couldn't bring her name so he brought her description, as if he said: And not this Arwa is closer than the Arwiyya of the wild. Al-Kindi said:
'Say to Dudan, slaves of the stick... what deceived you regarding the brave lion?'
Dudan is from Banu Asad (Sons of Lion). They are called Slaves of the Stick. It is as if he wanted: Say to Banu Asad, what deceived you regarding the brave lion (Asad). Al-Matrud al-Khuza'i said:
'Those striking the ram whose helmet shines... and preventing the white women (Bid) with swords (Asyaf).'

This verse has several facets: Among them is speckling (Talmi'), which is 'striking' and 'preventing'. Among them is verbal paronomasia, which is 'Bayd' (helmet) and 'Bid' (white women). And semantic paronomasia, which is 'Bid' meaning women, and 'Asyaf' plural of 'Sayf' in paucity, and the swords are white (Bid). It is as if he wanted to say: And preventing the white women (Bid) with the white [swords] (Bid), but it did not fit for him, so he said: And preventing the white women with swords. Among it:

**The Aspiring Paronomasia (Al-Mujannas Al-Mutmi')**
It is when the poet brings a word then starts its sister in accordance with its letters, making one aspire (yutmi') that he will bring its like, then substitutes a letter for a letter at its end. It is beautiful in paronomasia. Al-Hutay'ah said:
'Piercing (Mata'in) in war, feeding (Mata'im) in darkness... their fathers built for them and the grandfather built.'
Muzarrid said:
'Every herd visits Salma's house in the evening... jet-black (Gharabib) like the barefoot, quick (Hawafid) Indian women.'
Abu Kadra' al-'Ijli said:
'I rose to a Mashrafi iron... newly polished (Hadith), transmitted, a sharp sword.'
Al-Khatim al-Muhrizi said:
'Nights of a month I do not stop for rest (U'arris) for an hour... and days of a month I do not turn aside (U'arrij), diligent.'
He made one aspire that he would make a pun with 'U'arris', so he said 'U'arrij', substituting Jim for Sin. The wording is aspiring paronomasia, and the meaning is antithesis, because Ta'ris is at the end of the night and Ta'rij is at the end of the day. Abu Bakr bin Hanzala al-Anzi said:
'Gaining (Mufid), losing (Mufit), my dirhams do not come... when they come, except as wayfarers.'
This is aspiring paronomasia corresponding in meaning and wording, because the Mufid is the gatherer and the Mufit is the scatterer. Among it:

**The Substituted Paronomasia (Al-Tajnis Al-Mubdal)**
It is close to the Aspiring. Al-Zibraqan bin Badr said:
'Knights of truth in the morning when... shouting increases and clamor in the group (Nafr).'
He substituted Ya for Ba [in text seems unrelated to Nafr? Perhaps referring to another word not cited or typo in source analysis. The example 'Nafr' doesn't show substitution clearly here without context or comparison]. Alqama bin Abada said:
'You obeyed the slanderers (Wushat) and the walkers (Mushat) in cutting her off... so her ropes have weakened for breaking.'
He substituted Waw for Mim. Al-'Udayl said:
'A brother of distance worn out by the night journey (Dalaj)... spends the night seeking concern (Hamm) every seeking.'
He substituted Fa for Qaf. [Note: Text says 'Hamm' then says substituted Fa for Qaf? The example doesn't match the description. Perhaps 'Maraam' vs something else?]. Khufaf bin Nadba said:
'With the one restraining (Dabit), the stretching (Dabi')... when the horses flagged and the possessor of witness.'
He substituted Ayn for Ta. Jawwas bin al-Qa'tal said:
'I witnessed for her, while Abu Burayd was absent (Ghaba)... assemblies, if the Sheikh saw them he would be jealous (Ghara).'
Ghaba and Ghara; he substituted Ra for Ba. Amr bin Sha's said:
'We are those who for our clemency have merit (Fadl)... of old, and with our orator is judgment (Fasl).'
He substituted Sad for Dad. Imran bin Hittan said:
'If you lead him, you lead a strong (Shadid), correct (Sadid)... for he walks like the walk of the arrogant.'
He substituted Sin for Shin. Ka'b bin Ju'ayl said:
'So she permits (Tasmahu) me tears out of sadness for his memory... and sheds (Tasfahu) from it neither little nor scarce.'
He substituted Fa for Mim. Abu Hayya al-Numayri said:
'And as if mounds (Kuthub), trembling (Rawajif)... from the sky of locusts, were made buttocks (Rawadif) for them.'
Jurad is the name of a sand dune. He substituted Jim in Rawajif for Dal in Rawadif. Al-Mulayh al-Hudhali said:
'Is it in quarters in which the wind has a path (Madraj)... and a morning path on their known places and a night path (Madlaj)?'
He substituted Lam in Madlaj for Ra in Madraj. Ma'n bin Aws said:
'And I said (Qultu) when she stood (Qamat) and spoke and turned away... dragging a new [robe] of silk and a body-garment.'
He substituted Lam in Qalat for Mim in Qamat. Poetry in this chapter is abundant, and in the examples we mention and others is sufficiency for whoever wants, Allah Almighty willing. Among it:

**The Differing Paronomasia (Al-Mujannas Al-Mukhtalif)**
Al-Yazidi recited to me:
'With vines, full moons, and spears (Qana)... swaying over the dunes of the sand hill (Naqa).'
Qana and Naqa is differing paronomasia. Al-Harith bin Khalid al-Makhzumi said:
'And I fell in love among them in the morning with a tender one... of slender build, twisted like the twisting (Jadl) of a rein.'
Abu Dahbal said:
'There was in the family of Moses before him a body... a calf ('Ijl), when it lowed among them a lowing, they prostrated.'
Humayd bin Thawr said:
'We place the visit where the honor (Sharaf) of kings... does not disgrace us, nor do the visitors appear disappointed.'

It was said to Al-Asma'i: Abu Tammam al-A'rabi said: It is only 'Saraf' (extravagance) of kings with an un-dotted Sin. Al-Asma'i said: The man erred. Do you not know that there can be honor below honor without disgracing us? I said: This is an explanation as you see. But what Abu Tammam al-A'rabi went to is an acceptable face. Among the best of what is narrated in this chapter is the saying of Al-Ta'i:
'White of blades (Safa'ih), not black of pages (Saha'if)... in their texts is the clearing of doubt and suspicion.'
Among it:

**Script Paronomasia (Tajnis al-Khat)**
It is called Tashif (Misreading). It is when two words appear and are not distinguished except by dots. Allah Almighty said: "And they think (yahsabuna) that they are doing good (yuhsinuna) work." Urwa bin Jandal al-Faq'asi said:
'Nights when the causes of affection between us... despite stinginess (Bukhl), were sweeter to us than the harvest of bees (Nahl).'
Bukhl and Nahl is script paronomasia. Al-Farazdaq said:
'You played (Azafta) at A'shash and almost did not refrain (Ta'zifu)... and you denied of Hadra' what you used to know (Ta'rifu).'
Ta'zifu and Ta'rifu is script paronomasia. Abu Du'ad al-Iyadi said:
'I arrived on a strong, bulky she-camel... so she sipped cool water (Simalan) and the north wind (Shimalan) blew.'
Al-Afwah al-Awdi said:
'Until he bent from me the spear of the back... and masked the head with a mixed color (Khalis).'
Ibn Qais al-Ruqayyat said:
'They returned from you blaming, so everyone... went from you sad, robbed (Hariba).'
Bal'a' bin Qais said:
'To a garden in which are trefoil (Nafal) and herbs (Baql)... the flies sing in its beds.'
Nafal and Baql is script paronomasia. Ubayd bin Mawiya al-Ta'i said:
'And Nu'm, with what she sent her mind (Balaha)... and obtained the greeting whoever obtained it (Nalaha).
And I am possessor of bitter strength... if a state rides its state (Halaha).'
Al-Farazdaq said:
'And the healers did not find like our blood... a cure, nor the cupbearers from the honey of bees (Nahl).'

**And from it is Partial Paronomasia (Tajnis al-Ba'd):**
Al-Qutami said:
'More beautiful than Jumana the day they returned... the camels (Jimal) of separation and departed by day.'
Jumana and Jimal is partial paronomasia. He also said:
'And it was a blow from a wide-mouthed one... when the camels ran (Istannat) rising high (Istina'a).'
Istannat and Istina'a is partial paronomasia. Al-Tammah al-Uqayli said:
'The trotting place of the pregnant camels (Makhad) of the two sons of Qushayr as if they are... ostriches at the shears of Al-Hazabi loaded.'
Abdullah bin Abdul A'la said:
'And how much iron has wear and tear betrayed... and how many a fortress whose bases strength betrayed.'
Malik bin Awf al-Nasri said:
'Coquettish (Mikhrad) of dalliance, no clumsiness ('Iyy) nor age (Sanah)... and the creation is like the branch of the thicket in the morning.'
Al-Ujayr al-Saluli said:
'He quenched (Tarawwa) from the two seas then went in the evening (Tarawwahat)... with him the eye gifting him to Zamya', his transporter.'
Tarawwa and Tarawwahat is partial paronomasia, and Tarawwa and Zamya' is antithesis. Abu al-Juwayriya said:
'And seeking captive (Musta'sir) to the cold, I straightened his head... unwillingly, while the night is resuming (Musta'nif), a child.'
Musta'sir and Musta'nif is partial paronomasia. Abu al-Tamahan al-Qayni said:
'Oh, would that I had perished when I was righteous (Salih)... and when I was earning (Janin) for the enemy and wounding (Jarih).'
Janin and Jarih is partial paronomasia. Asad bin Kurz al-Bajali said:
'Chiefs, gambling, stabbing with spears... kindlers (Masa'ir) in war, shedders (Masafik) of blood.'
Masa'ir and Masafik is partial paronomasia. Al-Qutami said:
'Until you see the free, hardy she-camel exhausted... and the Arhabi camel in whose step (Khatw) is clumsiness (Khatal).'
Khatw and Khatal is partial paronomasia. Among it:

**The Completed Paronomasia (Al-Mujannas Al-Mutammam)**
It is when the poet brings a word then brings its sister, except he completes it with a letter or two from other than their letters. Hamal bin Badr said:
'We met and they met us with short-haired, prepared horses... surrounded by spears (Qana) and troops (Qanabil).'
Qana and Qanabil is completed paronomasia. Hassan said similar:
'And we used to, whenever the Prophet raided a tribe... connect its two edges with spears (Qana) and bombs (Qanabil).'
Amr bin Sha's said:
'I remembered Layla while the mounts were as if... sandgrouse of a watering place aiming for Al-Qatat then La'la'a.'
Uqba bin Ka'b bin Zuhair said:

'And she attacked with the glances of wild cows and smiled... with lean [gums] revealing white teeth (Ghurr) having sharpness (Ghurub).'
Ghurr and Ghurub is completed paronomasia. Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di said:
'It has the fire of Jinn after humans who shifted... and the vicissitude of distance and calamities (Nawa'ib) removed them.'
Al-Khansa' said:
'Indeed weeping is the cure (Shifa')... from the passion (Jawa) between the ribs (Jawanih).'
She also said:
'Ra'la has missed you and rested... would that the horses, their rider sees them.'
Al-Akhnas bin Shihab said:
'And a protector (Hami) of a banner we killed, and a carrier (Hamil)... of a banner we prevented, while the spears were pointed.'
His saying Hami and Hamil is completed paronomasia, and in the verse is inlaying (Tarsi'). Ka'b bin Zuhair said:
'And you knew, while you are not forbearing... that passion does not bring me near to humiliation (Hawan).'
From the beautiful of this section of paronomasia is the saying of Al-Ta'i; Abdul Rahman al-Wasiti informed me by my reading to him, he said: Ibn Khayrun told me from Al-Jawhari and Ibn al-Muslima, they said: Al-Marzubani told us from his Sheikhs, he said: Umara bin Aqil bin Bilal bin Jarir asked the companions of Abu Tammam to recite some of his poetry, so they recited to him:
'If Lujaym bridled (Aljamat) Lujaym one day and around it... were Banu al-Hisn, the offspring of chaste, noble women.
For deaths, sharp swords, and spears... are their relatives in fear, instead of relatives.
When the horses traversed the dust of the battle, they cracked... the chests of the upper spears in the chests of the battalions.
They extend from disobeying (Awasi), protecting (Awasim) hands... attacking with destroying (Qawadi), cutting (Qawadib) swords.'
Umara said: 'To Allah is his goodness! As if his returns (raddat) are the returns of Jarir.' He called paronomasia 'returns'. His saying: 'Awasi and Awasim, and Qawadi and Qawadib is of the appreciated completed paronomasia. Among it:

**Rhyme Paronomasia (Tajnis al-Qawafi)**
Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani said:
'You see the desirous ones clinging to his door... upon every walnut bowl filled with humps (Ara'ir).
He has in the courtyard of the house a black, dark pot... swallowing the limbs of the huge (Ura'ir) slaughtered camel.'
Ara'ir are humps, and Ura'ir is huge and big. Qais bin Zuhair said:
'I think clemency guided my people against me... and the forbearing (Halim) man may be treated as ignorant.
And how many men have I practiced in my time... refusers, whom dreams (Hulum) do not miss.'
Halim: The man of clemency, and Hulum: plural of Hulm (dream). Since the meaning differed, the proximity between the two words became good. Al-Arji said:
'You named me worn-out (Khalaq) for a suit that wore out... and there is no new if the worn (Khalaq) is not worn.
Return to the truth if you were saying it... indeed fabrication (Takhalluq) comes short of character (Khuluq).'
A'sha of Banu Abi Rabi'a said:
'Abu al-Is, Al-Asi, and Harb, and there was no... brother like Abu Amr by whom the back (Azr) is strengthened.
The honors were pure from them from every suspicion... feared, and the waist-wrappers (Uzr) were good in their tying places.'
Amr bin Imri' al-Qais al-Ansari said:
'I opposed in opinion every possessor of debauchery... O Mal, and the truth is other than what we describe (Nasifu).
We walk to death from our anger... a rapid walk, and our judgment is half (Nasafu).'
Nasifu from Wasf (description), and Nasafu from Nasafa (justice/half). Ashyam bin Shurahbil said:
'If you ask Tamim about their evils... then seek Usayyid until you catch the predecessor (Salafa).
Like slave girls, when a clamor bites... they do not gamble easily nor do you meet advancing food (Sulafa) for them.'
Salaf is the past, and Sulaf is the little food presented before lunch, singular Sulafa with Damma. From that is their saying 'Sallaftu al-rajul taslifan' (I gave the man an advance), and if you fed him something hastened before his lunch. Ibn Abdal al-Asadi said:
'And indeed I become rich but do not become arrogant in wealth... and I offer my kindness to one seeking my offer ('Ardi).
And I become insolvent sometimes so my difficulty intensifies... and I attain the ease of wealth while my honor ('Irdi) is with me.'
Jumana al-Absiya said:
'My father does not see that he be robbed of his armor today... and my grandfather sees that he take the armor from my father.'

'So my father's opinion is the opinion of the miser with his money... and my grandfather's nature is the nature of the refusing swearer.'
Ibn al-A'rabi recited:
'His drink (Shirab) is like cutting with razors... neither quenching nor consoling (Muwasi).'
He meant by his drink his drinking partnership. Abu Dahbal said:
'Is it not precious that you are in a town... both of us residing in it and we do not speak?
A pampered woman, if an ant crawled on her skin... the crawling of the ant on the skin would almost wound (Yuklamu).'
Amr bin Qami'a said:
'Those are my people, the family of Sa'd bin Malik... they conspired on grudge against me and oppression (Ilghaf).
So all people are closer today than them... to me, even if they were Oman, possessors of the Ghaf tree.'
Ilghaf is injustice and oppression, and his saying: Possessors of Ghaf means owners of the tree. Al-Mada'ini recited for Al-Khalil bin Ahmad:
'O woe to my heart from the motives of passion... when the neighbors departed at sunset (Ghurub).
I followed them with my glance and they had gone far... and the overflow of my eyes was like the overflow of buckets (Ghurub).
They departed and among them was a free, tender woman... smiling revealing hidden hail [teeth] of the spathe (Ghurub).'
The first Ghurub is sunset, the second is plural of Gharb which is a large bucket, and the third is the spathe (Kufurra) which is the spadix. Abu al-Abbas Tha'lab recited:
'Do you know ruins that saddened you at Al-Khal... and the life of a time that was in the past (Khali) age?
Nights when the prime of youth was empowered... over me with disobedience to the commanding [soul] and arrogance (Khal).
And when I was a friend to the seducer, brother of youth... and to the flirt, the windy, possessor of amusement and unmarried state (Khal).
Nights, Tukna captivates me with her coquetry... and with the enchanting look, the cheek, and the mole (Khal).
If she inhabited a quarter, you loved its quarters... just as the soft meadow is loved by the abundant rain, the thundercloud (Khali).
And a soft one in his coquetry leads me from her... just as a colt is led when the groom (Khali) tames it.'
The first Khal is a place, the second is the past, the third is vanity, the fourth is one with no wife, the fifth is the black mole, the sixth is one with no helper, and the seventh is the one who tends to animals. Among it:

**Similar Paronomasia (Al-Tajnis Al-Mumathil)**
It is when the two words are two nouns or two verbs, as Allah Almighty said: "Fa-rawhun wa rayhan" (Then rest and basil), two nouns. And as His Almighty's saying: "Wa jana al-jannatayni dan" (And the picking of the two gardens is near). And His Almighty's saying: "Ya asafa ala Yusuf" (O my sorrow over Joseph). And as the Prophet's saying (peace be upon him): "Al-Zulmu zulumat yawm al-qiyama" (Injustice is darknesses on the Day of Judgment). And his saying (peace be upon him): "The two-faced one will not be a notable (Wajih) on the Day of Judgment." Jarir said:
'So Iqal ceased not to be hobbled (Ma'qul) from generosity... and a restrainer (Habis) ceased not to be restrained (Mahbus) from good.'
Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani said:
'She said: I see you as a brother of a saddle and a mount... covering wastelands that will not wait for you (Yanzirnaka) for old age.'
Suhaym bin Wathil al-Riyahi said:
'And indeed my peer does not return to me... on the morning of the day after (Ghibb) except in a horn (Qarin).'
Meaning with him another. Another said:
'Nights of Layla, her sweet water was not mixed... with salt, and her two ropes, their strands are strong.'
Meaning the rope of her affection for him and the rope of his affection for her. Al-Ajjaj said:
'And the daughter of Abbas, the chief of Abs... in a stock (Qins) of glory above every stock (Qins).'
Qins is the origin of everything and its root. Al-Udayl bin al-Farkh al-Ijli said:
'At Khala she visited us, so her phantom was stirred... and she visited at Huwwarin while he is Levantine (Sha'am).'
Yazid bin Hudhayfa al-Asadi said:
'We repelled Tarif with our tips (Atraf)... and with the palm (Rah) from us, and they did not repel us.'
We have cited of the sections of Jinah (Paronomasia) what contains sufficiency and indication to others, so measure it and adopt it, Allah Almighty willing. From the titles we previously mentioned in poetry:

**Chapter of Correspondence (Mutabaqa) / Antithesis**
Scholars have differed regarding Tibaq (Antithesis). Al-Akhfash said when asked about it: I find people differing on Tibaq. A group, which is the majority, claims that it is mentioning a thing and its opposite, joined by the wording not the meaning. And a group opposes that and says: It is the sharing of two meanings in a single word, like the saying of Ziyad al-A'jam:

'And I was informed they seek victory through Kahil... and for meanness among them is a wither (Kahil) and a hump.'
His saying 'through Kahil': meaning the tribe, and his saying 'Kahil' for the limb is correspondence according to them. He said: This is paronomasia. He said: Whoever claims it is Tibaq has opposed Al-Asma'i and Al-Khalil. It was said to him: Did they know this? He said: Glory be to Allah, is there anyone like them in the knowledge of poetry and distinguishing its bad from its good?! Some people included in Tibaq a type of Division (Taqsim), like the saying of Ka'b bin Sa'd:
'Indeed, as for his clemency, it is relieved... upon us, and as for his ignorance, it is distant.'
When they saw the mention of clemency and ignorance, and relieved and distant, they placed it in correspondence, and it was not far from it, but it is closer to the chapter of Division.
