Al-Asma'i said: The origin of Tibaq is that the horse places its hind leg in the place of its foreleg, and he recited:
'And horses that match (Yutabiqna) with the armored men... the matching (Tibaq) of dogs treading the rugged ground.'
Al-Khalil said: I matched (Tabaqtu) between two things if I gathered them on one pattern and attached them. I say: Tibaq is one of the best beauties of Badi'; it is when the poet brings the thing and its opposite in the verse. Abdullah bin al-Zubayr al-Asadi said:
'Events threw the women of the family of Harb... with a decree for which they stood bewildered (Samadna Sumuda).
So it returned their black hair white... and returned their white faces black.'
Zuhair said:
'A scattered lion hunting men when... the lion lied about his peers, he was truthful.'
Al-Farazdaq said:
'May God curse Banu Kulayb, for they... neither betray nor fulfill for a neighbor.
They wake up to the braying of their donkeys... and their eyes sleep from vengeance.'
Al-Farazdaq took it from the saying of Thumamah al-Dhuhli:
'A people whose eyes sleep from vengeance... but their foolish ones do not sleep from theft.'
Amr bin Kulthum said:
'That we bring the banners white... and issue them red, having been quenched.'
If Amr had said: 'From the thirsty spears, they arrive white... and we issue them red, having been quenched,' he would have been excellent and creative in Tibaq between bringing and issuing, whiteness and redness, and thirst and quenching. Abu al-Shis took the meaning of Amr's verse and completed what was missing from it, saying:
'So he brought them white, thirsty in their chests... and issued them with quenching, their colors red.'
So his taking became appreciated due to the completeness of his meaning and addition with paronomasia in: 'Suduruha' (their chests) and 'Asdaraha' (he issued them). Al-Ghatammash al-Dabbi said:
'If we travel between East and West... the awake of the dust and its sleeper move.'
Al-Kumayt bin Zayd said:
'And I see gray hair and youth as two robes... one preserved and one everyday garment spread out.'
Gray hair and youth, and preserved and everyday is application (Tatbiq), and in it is one metaphor. Abu Sakhr al-Hudhali said:
'Nay, by the One who made weep and made laugh, and the One who... caused death and gave life, and the One whose command is the Command.'
Aws bin Maghra' said:
'So the rope of affection between me and her wore out... and every new thing will become worn.'
Abu Dahbal said:
'And the spear of religion became in the hand of an oppressor... if a side of it bends, he does not straighten it.'
In it is Tibaq and a good metaphor. Abu Jilda al-Yashkuri said:
'If she balances cutting off and connecting, a balance... of love, heavy, hinders her from cutting off.'
In it is Tibaq and metaphor. When he made a balance for love, he made the indicator verbal, which is his saying 'heavy' (Rajih). This section is vast and abundant, indicated by the little and easy. Among them:

**Chapter of Exportation (Tasdir)**
Some call it: Returning the ends of speech to its beginnings. It is when the poet begins with a word in the verse then repeats it in its end, or half of it then returns it in the last half. If poetry is organized in this manner, extracting its rhymes becomes easy before they knock on the ears of its listeners. Al-Asma'i said: Of good Tasdir is the saying of Amir bin al-Tufayl, and so said a group of poetry critics:
'So you were a hump in Fazara, high... and in every tribe is a peak and a hump.'
Some said: Rather, of good Tasdir is the saying of Jarir:

'A black cloud pouring its white clouds watered the sand... and that is nothing but love for who settled in the sand.'
Others said: Rather, the saying of the first is of good Tasdir:
'Quick to the cousin insulting his honor... and not quick to the caller of generosity.'
People said: The saying of Ibn Ahmar is among the good of what was said in Tasdir, which is:
'I sipped (Taghammartu) from her after youth ran out... and he who sips (Taghammara) is not quenched from a need.'
Taghammur is little drinking. Al-Farazdaq said:
'Issue (Asdir) your worries, let not their import kill you... for every import one day has an issue (Sadar).'
Among them:

**Chapter of Apostrophe (Iltifat)**
It is turning from addressing to informing, and from informing to addressing. It is of the wondrous Badi'. Jarir said:
'When were the tents at Dhu Tuluh?... May you be watered by rain, O tents.
Do you remember the day she polished her cheeks... with a stick of Basham tree? The Basham was watered.'
It is also narrated: 'Do you forget when Sulayma bid us farewell... with a stick of Basham tree? The Basham was watered.'
Of brilliant Iltifat is the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'Did Banu Abs claim that I... No, they lied! Old of age, vanishing.'
Another said:
'For if I miss you, there misses you from me... so do not be surpassed in it, a precious object.'
Kuthayyir said:
'If the misers, and you are one of them... saw you, they would learn procrastination from you.'
From this section is the interjection of speech within speech whose meaning is not complete, then the poet returns to it and completes it at once, which is of good Iltifat. Tarafa said:
'So may the downpour of spring and pouring rain... water your dwellings, without spoiling them.'
The meaning was completed by his saying: 'without spoiling them'. Nafi' bin Khalifa al-Ghanawi said:
'Men who, if the truth is not accepted from them... and given to them, sought refuge in cutting swords.'
He completed the meaning by his saying: 'and given to them'. Among them:

**Chapter of Digression (Istitrad)**
The meaning of Istitrad is the poet's exit from blame to praise or from praise to blame. The moderns have many wondrous poems in this chapter. Zuhair said:
'Indeed the miser is blamed wherever he is, but... the generous one, despite his defects, is Harim.'
He digressed the speech to praising Harim. Al-Farazdaq said:
'As if the anuses of Azd around Ibn Misma'... when they sweat, are the mouths of Bakr bin Wa'il.'
He digressed the speech to blaming Bakr bin Wa'il. Jarir threw dust in the face of the predecessor to this meaning, let alone who followed him, for he digressed with two in one verse, which is:
'When I placed my brand on Al-Farazdaq... and Al-Ba'ith cried out, I cut off the nose of Al-Akhtal.'
Al-Dhaghw and Al-Dugha' is the voice of the humiliated, conquered one. Another said:
'You are the son of Bid, by my life I do not deny it... truly, certainly, but who is the father of Bid?'
Bakr bin al-Nattah said about Malik bin Tawq, which is a digression from praise to praise:
'I offered her what she wanted of wishes... to please her, she said: Stand and bring me a star.
So I said to her: This obstinacy is all... like one who desires the flesh of a western Phoenix.
Ask every matter whose seeking is upright... and do not go, O pearl, in every way.
For I swear, if I were in the glory of Malik... and his power, my demand would be impossible with what you aimed for.
A youth whose wealth was miserable by his giving... just as Qais was miserable by the spears of Taghlib.'
Similar to these verses is what Al-Isfahani mentioned in his book, he said: Ahmad bin Ubaydullah bin Ammar said: We were at Al-Mubarrad's one day, and with him was a youth from the descendants of Abu al-Bakhtari Wahb bin Wahb the Judge, a handsome beardless boy, and a youth from the descendants of Abu Dulaf al-Qasim bin Isa al-Ijli resembling him in beauty. Al-Mubarrad said to Ibn Abi al-Bakhtari: 'I know a witty story of generosity for your grandfather, beautiful, not preceded.' The youth said: 'What is it?' He said: 'A man of letters was invited to some banquets and was given Nabidh other than what they were drinking. He said:
"Two Nabidhs in one assembly... for preferring a wealthy one over a poor one.

"If your action was this in food... I would have adhered to your analogy in the intoxicant.
But if you were doing the deed of the noble... you would have done the deed of Abu al-Bakhtari.
He followed his brothers in the lands... so he enriched the poor from the wealthy."
The verses reached your grandfather, so he sent the man five hundred dinars.' Ibn Ammar said: I said: 'The grandfather of this youth has done in this meaning what is better than this.' Al-Mubarrad said: 'What is it?' I said: 'I heard that Ibn Abi Fanan became poor after wealth. His wife said to him: "Enlist in the army." He recited saying:
"Away from me, for you have tasked me with excess... carrying weapons and saying to the house: 'Eye, stop.'
Deaths walk to people and I hate them... so how can I walk to them with bare shoulder?
I thought that the exhaustion of money changed me... or that my heart is in the sides of Abu Dulaf."
Abu Dulaf summoned him and said to him: "How much did your wife hope your provision would be?" He said: "One hundred dinars." He said: "And how long did you hope to live?" He said: "Twenty years." He said: "You have from me what you hoped and your wife hoped from my money, not the Sultan's money." And he ordered giving that to him. He said: I saw the face of Ibn Abi Dulaf beaming, and Ibn Abi al-Bakhtari was broken.' Another said:
'We captured as our spears accustomed us... at the battle of the two cavalries, while the dust was rising.'
He informed that he captured an enemy and digressed the speech to [saying] that he is accustomed to that. Among them:

**Chapter of Division (Taqsim)**
Nusayb said:
'I was not pleased with what she said, nor did I show anger... and my chest narrowed with what I mumbled of her love.
So a group of the tribe said: No. And a group of them... Yes. And a group said: Woe to you, we do not know.'
There is nothing in the answer of one who asked about something other than what he mentioned. This verse was narrated by Al-Akhfash according to what I established and know of his poetry:
'So a group of the people said when I adjured them... Yes, and a group: By Allah's oath, we do not know.'
Al-Shammakh said describing the hardness of the donkey's hooves and the intensity of his trampling the ground:
'Whenever his pasterns fall settled... on a stone, it shatters or rolls away.'
There is nothing in the description of intense treading except that what is trodden upon is soft so it shatters, or hard so it rolls away. Zuhair said:
'He spears them as long as they throw, until if they spear... he strikes, until if they strike, he embraces.'
Antara said:
'If they catch up, I attack again; if they pursue, I intensify; and if they are found in a tight spot, I dismount.'
Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah al-Makhzumi said:
'You wander for Nu'm, so neither is the reunion gathering... nor the rope connected, nor the love short.
Neither is the nearness of Nu'm, if she approaches, beneficial to you... nor does her distance console, nor are you patient.'
The Kharijite took this meaning and said:
'I belied my eye regarding you, while the eye is truthful... and I made my ear hear regarding you what it does not hear.
And I did not inhabit the land which you inhabit... so that they would not say: Patient, he does not panic.
So neither does my grief end, nor is there mercy from you... nor holding back from you, nor hope in you.'
Qais bin Dharih said:
'If the world has turned with Lubna... then Time and the world have bellies and backs.
Indeed there was in it a place for trust... and a grazing ground for the heart and a view for the eye.
And for the hovering thirsty one a quenching in her nearness... and for the strutting one trailing his robe a scent and an intoxicant.'
The people of the craft approved in this chapter the saying of Bashar bin Burd, which is:
'With a strike that he who tastes its taste tastes death... and its defects overtake him whom flight saved.
So they went: a group in captivity, and its like... killed, and a like whose fleer sought refuge in the sea.'
They said: There is no addition to what he mentioned in describing one whom victory befell and the mill of war turned upon. Among them:

**Chapter of Arrowing (Tas'him)**

A group of those who practice the science of Badi' and criticism of crafted poetry were asked about Tas'him, but none of them answered with an answer of understanding. Nothing was obtained from their indications to it and their texts on it except that the Musahham (arrowed) is that which the listener anticipates its rhymes before its narrator reaches them. I say: This title is not indicative of this meaning. If the titler intended strangeness by it, he missed the mark and deviated from the straightest path. Tas'him is striping, and the Musahham robe is the striped one. It would have been more appropriate to say: Tas'him in poetry is its beautification and refinement of its words and meanings, likening it to the robe beautified by striping, so that this type of poetry has its meaning reach your heart faster than its words reach your ear. If it were called Al-Mutmi' (The Aspiring)—meaning whoever hears it aspires to say the like of it, while he is far from that—it would be permissible. We have presented it as we heard and narrated it. Al-Akhfash said: Among the most brilliant of what was said in Tas'him is what Al-Janub, sister of Amr Dhi al-Kalb, said:
'I swore, O Amr, if they alerted you... then they alerted from you an incurable disease.
Then they alerted a lion of a thicket... destroying, benefiting souls and wealth.
And a desert whose unknown you crossed... with a Kharqa' (she-camel) complaining of fatigue.
So you were the sun to it by day... and you were the crescent in it in the darkness of night.'
Then he said: Look at the embroidery of this speech, how pure it is, and at its divisions, how complete they are. Look at her saying 'destroying, benefiting', and her description of him in the day as the sun and in the night as the crescent; you find the far, aspiring, impossible. In this small sufficiency of this chapter is enough, Allah Almighty willing. Among them:

**Chapter of Inlaying (Tarsi')**
It is called Checkering (Tafwif). Tarsi' in language is composition. From it is a crown inlaid (Murassa') with jewels, and a sword inlaid, meaning adorned with Rasai' (inlays), which are rings used for adornment, singular Rasi'a. The inlaid verse is the one in which associated parts follow successively as the crown is inlaid with jewels. From Tarsi' in the Glorious Quran is His Almighty's saying: "And why should you not eat of that upon which the name of Allah has been mentioned, while He has explained in detail to you what He has forbidden you, excepting that to which you are compelled." And His Almighty's saying: "Or has He not guided those who inherit the land after its people that if We willed We would strike them for their sins and seal over their hearts." Among good Tarsi' is the saying of Al-Khansa':
'Praise is his nature, and generosity is his illness... and truth is his domain, if his peer feared.
Blocker of breaches, attender of assemblies... crosser of valleys, seeker of vengeance.
Bearer of banners, striker of buildings... arrive at water-wheels, usurper in war.
Poison of enemies, releaser of captives, when... he met the battle he was not fearful of death.
Good he does, and speech he prefers... and wealth he plunders in right a plundering.
He guides the patrol if the path deviates with them... high of neck, rider of blue spears.'
She also said:
'Refuser of oppression, bearer of the great matter... waster of the precious, neither falling nor weak.
Protector of the truth, traveler of the intense heat... liberator of the driven herd, sturdy not weak.
Descender of valleys, bearer of banners... attender of assemblies, wolf of youths.'
She also said:
'Sharp of spearhead, eloquent of tongue... rewarding the lender the likes of it.'
She also said:
'Bearer of a burden, rider of a dilemma... giver of a favor, mender of bone.
Protector of the truth, praised of path... driver of the driven herd, beneficial and harmful.'
Imru' al-Qais said:
'The water is pouring, and the run is descending... and the flank is lean, and the back is smooth.'
Ziyad said:
'Black are their tresses, white are their chests... full are their elbows, in their creation is abundance of hair.'
In it, along with Tarsi', is Tibaq (antithesis). Dhu al-Rumma said:
'White in blackness of eyes, yellow in whiteness of skin... as if she is silver touched by gold.'

This is a verse that combined Antithesis, Inlaying, and Simile. Bashama al-Nahshali said, and it is narrated for another:
'White are our partings, boiling are our pots... we heal with our wealth the traces of our hands.'
I saw in the handwriting of Sheikh Abu Zakariya al-Tabrizi a book in which Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Abdullah al-Khatib extracted over two hundred faces in his saying 'White are our partings' alone, and he constructed the building of those meanings with Arabic poems and accepted words. Another said:
'Long of sword-belt, high of pillar... much of ash, and the night is cold.'
Al-Harithi said:
'She visited, greeted, then stood and bid farewell... when she turned away, the soul almost perished.'
Tarsi' in poetry is more numerous than the number of raindrops. Among it:

**Chapter of Repetition (Tardid)**
It is when the poet attaches a word in the verse with a meaning, then repeats it in it itself and attaches it with another meaning. The critics agreed that Abu Hayya al-Numayri preceded in this excellence all who came before him and after him with his saying:
'Hey, greet for the sake of the beloved the dwellings... they wore decay from what the nights wore.
If a day and a night demand payment from a man... something demands him that does not tire of demanding.'
He began in the first hemistich and excelled in beginning, and repeated in the second hemistich and excelled in repetition. Abu Tammam al-Ta'i said: I do not know anyone with better craft in repetition than the saying of Zuhair:
'Whoever meets Harim one day despite his conditions... meets generosity from him and nobility as a character.'
It is narrated: 'If you meet... you meet generosity'. Al-Asma'i said: This is the most praising verse the Arabs said. Abu Ali al-Hatimi said: Abu Nuwas excelled in repetition with his saying:
'Yellow (wine), sorrows do not descend in its yard... if a stone touched it, joy would touch it.'
He also said:
'He thought of me, he whom I became fond of... so he shuns me on suspicion.'
Al-Hatimi said: Ali bin Jabala did well, despite his later time, in describing a horse where he says:
'Agitated, shaking from his sides... like water in which wind roamed so it agitated.
If we think of him, he confirms us... and if the wild ass thinks escaping him, he lies.'
Repetition in the poems of the moderns is abundant, but we did not direct attention to it, so in the example we brought is sufficiency. Among them:

**Chapter of Correspondence (Muqabala)**
Ali bin al-Husayn al-Qurashi said: I asked Ja'far bin Qudama the Scribe, who was one of the critics of poetry, about Muqabala. He said: I asked my father about it, and he said: It is that the poet posits meanings intending agreement between some of them, or disagreement, so he brings in the agreeing what agrees with it, and in the disagreeing what disagrees with it correctly, or stipulates conditions and enumerates states in one of the two meanings, so he must bring in what agrees with it the like of what he stipulated, and in what disagrees with it the opposites of that. He said: I said to him: Recite to me the best of what was said in it. He said: I do not know better than the saying of the first:
'O wonder, how we agreed! So an advisor... loyal, and one folded on rancor, treacherous.'
So he placed opposite 'advisor' 'folded on rancor', and opposite 'loyal' 'treacherous'. He said: And the saying of Al-Tirimmah bin Hakim al-Ta'i in that is also good, which is:
'We captured them and bestowed favor upon them... and we gave the dust their blood to drink.
So they did not have patience for might in war... nor did they perform reward for a good hand.'
He says: When we gave the dust their blood to drink, they had no patience for what befell them from us due to their failure and weakness of souls, and when we bestowed favor upon them and treated them well, they did not reward with praise for us. So he placed opposite their giving the dust their blood to drink and fighting them, that they be patient, and opposite their bestowing favor upon them, that they praise. He said this is Muqabala. Ali bin Harun said: Yahya bin Ali claimed that the best of what was said in Muqabala is the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'A youth in whom was completed what pleases his friend... despite that in him is what displeases the enemy.'
So he placed opposite pleasure offense, and opposite friend enemy. This is a sufficient draught in this chapter. Among them:

**Chapter of Exception (Istithna')**

A group expressed it, and the closest of their sayings to the heart was what Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz mentioned, for he said: Exception in poetry is confirming praise with what resembles blame. From that is the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'And there is no fault in them except that their swords... have notches in them from striking battalions.'
As for the grammarians, Exception in speech according to them is extracting a part from a whole in a comprehensive ruling meaning 'except'. He also said:
'A youth whose morals are perfect except that he... is generous so he leaves nothing remaining of money.'
He also said:
'A youth in whom was completed what pleases his friend... despite that in him is what displeases the enemies.'
His saying in the first verse 'except that he' and in the second 'despite that in him' is of the most brilliant and best Exception. They said: The best of what was narrated in this type is the saying of Al-Rabi' bin Dabba:
'I perished but my talk and speech do not perish... and every man except his talks is perishing.'
Some said: Rather the saying of the other:
'So do not be distant except from evil, for I... towards you, even if the abode is far with me, am yearning.'
Others said: Rather the saying of some Bedouin:
'Clumsy (Kharqa') except that she is skillful (Sana').'
Abu Hiffan al-Mihzami al-Abdi excelled and did well in this chapter where he says:
'If you ask about us, then we are the ornaments of highness... Banu Amir, and the earth of highlands.
And there is no fault in us except that our generosity... harmed us, and might is from every side.
So death annihilated our lives, not unjust... and generosity annihilated our wealth, not faulting.
Our father is a father, if all people had... a father like him, he would have sufficed them with virtues.'
Among them:

**Chapter of Deepening (Ighal)**
It is called Delivery (Tabligh). It is when the poet brings the meaning in the verse complete before reaching his rhyme, then brings it for the need of poetry for it, because by it poetry becomes poetry, so it increases the verse in elegance, and the meaning in reaching the farthest limit. Al-Tawwazi said: I said to Al-Asma'i: Who is the most poetic of people? He said: He who comes to the base meaning and makes it great with his wording, or intends the great meaning and makes it base with his wording, or his speech ends before the rhyme, so when he needs it he brings it and provides a meaning that was not before it, as Al-A'sha said:
'Like one butting a rock one day to split it... so he did not harm it and weakened his horn...'
The proverb was complete, then he needed the rhyme, so he said 'the ibex' (al-wa'il), increasing the meaning. He said: I said to him: So how did the ibex become preferred over every butter? He said: Because it descends from the peak of the mountain on its horn and it does not harm it. Dhu al-Rumma said:
'Stop the white camels at the ruins of Mayya, let us ask... traces like the worn parts of the robe...'
His speech was complete, then he needed the rhyme so he said: 'the striped' (al-musalsal), increasing the meaning. Then he said:
'I think what bestows upon you asking her is... tears like the sorting of pearls...'
His speech was complete, then he needed the rhyme so he said 'the separated' (al-mufassal), adding something not in the verse. The most brilliant of what was said in this chapter is the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'As if the eyes of the wild beasts around our domes... and our saddles are onyx which has not been pierced.'
He brought the simile before the rhyme, then when he brought the rhyme, he delivered it to the far extent in confirming the meaning, because the eyes of wild beasts resemble onyx, especially if they die and their forms change. Then when he brought the rhyme he said: 'Onyx which has not been pierced', so he increased the meaning in clarity; because it is more impactful in simile with unpierced onyx. He also said:
'When he ran two heats and his flank became wet... you say the roar of the wind...'
The presentation and simile were complete before the rhyme. When he brought it, the rhyme increased the meaning in brilliance and purity, which is his saying: 'passed through an ath'ab tree'. That is because the ath'ab is a tree for which the wind has a intense rustling in the folds of its branches. Among them:

**Chapter of Metaphor (Isti'ara)**

Metaphor is one of the noblest and most majestic crafts of speech. The ancients used to call it 'Proverbs' (Amthal), saying: So-and-so is frequent in proverbs. Titling it 'Metaphor' is more binding because it is more general, and because not all proverbs run the course of metaphor. Do you not see the saying of Al-Sulayk bin al-Sulaka, when a man fell on him while he was sleeping and pressed Al-Sulayk, so the man farted? Al-Sulayk said: 'A fart while you are on top!' He sent it as a proverb, while stating the thing in its reality. Among the most brilliant metaphors is the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'She stayed in it until the wood withered in the moist earth... and dawn drove the Pleiades in its robe.'
Abu Amr bin al-Ala said: My hand was in the hand of Al-Farazdaq, so I recited to him the verse of Dhu al-Rumma. He said: 'Shall I recite to you or leave you?' He said: I said: 'Nay, recite to me.' He said: 'She stayed in it until the wood withered and the moist earth,' then he said: 'The wood does not wither as long as it stays in the moist earth.' Then he said: 'And I do not know a speech better than his saying: "and dawn drove the Pleiades in its robe", and it has no robe, but it is a metaphor.' Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: The wood does not wither as long as it is in the moist earth. Al-Suli said: I and a group of the knights of poetry gathered at Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz's, and he was an investigator in the science of Badi', whose claim was supported by the tongue of his discourse. No path of the paths of poetry remained but we walked it, and we cited the best of what was said in its meaning, until Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: What is the best metaphor of the Arabs contained in a verse of poetry? Al-Asadi said: The saying of Labid:
'And a morning of wind and cold I removed... when its rein became in the hand of the North Wind.'
He assigned a hand to the North Wind and a rein to the morning. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: This is good, and other than it is better. He took it from the saying of Tha'labah bin Su'ayr al-Mazini describing a female ostrich and a male ostrich:
'So they remembered a piled weight after... the sun (Dhuka') threw its right hand into a coverer (Kafir).'
The weight: Ostrich eggs. Piled: stacked one upon another. Dhuka': The sun. Kafir: The night. He assigned a right hand to the sun thrown into the night. He said: And the saying of Dhu al-Rumma is more wondrous to me than it, even if his time was later, where he says:
'Did Mayy visit a lovesick one with her memory... while the hands of the Pleiades were leaning in the setting places?'
Some of us said: Labid's saying is better:
'And I protected the tribe, my weapons carried by... a swift horse, my sash when I went early was its bridle.'
It is said: A horse is Furut (swift) if it precedes the horses. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: This is good. But look at the saying of Al-Hudhali:
'And if I entrusted him to the sun, deaths would ascend... to him, its eye and its messenger.'
Then he said: This is marvelous. And more marvelous than it in borrowing the word of entrusting is the saying of Al-Husayn bin al-Humam al-Murri where he says:
'We chase them, entrusting our white swords to their heads... and they entrust to us the straightened Samhari spears.'
In this verse is a subtle meaning indicating their advance and the retreat of their opponents, so know it from its wording. Some of us said: Dhu al-Rumma's saying is better:
'She stayed in it until the wood withered in the moist earth... and dawn drove the Pleiades in its robe.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: This is the ultimate, and Dhu al-Rumma is the most creative of people in metaphor. Al-Suli said: It was as if, by Allah, he alerted me to Dhu al-Rumma, so I said: Rather his saying is better:
'And when I saw the night, while the sun was alive... the life of one spending the last breath of a dying man.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: You struck your fire-stick and it ignited, O Abu Bakr. This is very brilliant. But Jarir preceded him to this metaphor and did well by his saying:
'The winds revive its quarter so they renew it... after decay, and the rains kill it.'
He said: This is a good verse that combined metaphor and antithesis, because he brought in it reviving and killing, and decay and newness. But Dhu al-Rumma took over the mention of reviving and killing in another place and did well by his saying:
'And intoxicated from long drowsiness as if he... by two ropes in a knot is swinging.
If he dies on the saddle, I revived his spirit... by your memory, while the white camels, the messengers, are leaning.'
Al-Suli said: We left, and there was none of the group but was overwhelmed by the sea of Ibn al-Mu'tazz in the science of poetry and his good handling of speech. I say: The first to use metaphor in poetry was Imru' al-Qais. Among his metaphors is his saying:

'And a night like the wave of the sea letting down its curtains... upon me with types of worries to test [me].
So I said to it when it stretched its spine... and followed with buttocks and rose with a chest.'
Zuhair said:
'The heart sobered from Salma and its falsehood shortened... and the horses of youth and its mounts were stripped.'
Al-Asma'i said: The first to strip the horses of youth was Tufayl by his saying:
'So I became scolding its people for ignorance... and the horses of youth and its mounts were stripped.'
Al-Udayl bin al-Farkh said:
'The white swords are a refuge for us... when they flew with hands like the flash of lightning clouds.'
He also said:
'Who is the mighty stabber, while the horses are amidst... dust whose soaking is gifted by the hooves.'
The metaphor is 'gifted' (tahada), and the indicator is 'by the hooves'. Muzahim al-Uqayli said:
'I imprisoned passion in the chest until appeared... the daughters of passion wailing from every wailer.'
He made his chest a prison for passion, and made daughters for passion—meaning his worries—and made them appearing, and made them wailing. This is of the good metaphors. Al-Khansa' said:
'At a predicament whose interval was narrow... death drags its tails.'
She assigned tails to death and made them dragged, and the indicator is verbal. Muzahim al-Uqayli said describing a desert:
'The violent winds die in its sides... and far from its diameters is every watering place.'
Jarir said:
'And I saw the mount of youth had fallen short... after the quick pace and tired of traveling.'
He also said:
'The morning we slit with swords fetuses... of war in a pregnant one not yet due.'
'Ibtaqarna' (we slit) is the form ifta'alna from Baqr, which is slitting the belly of a pregnant woman or other. He borrowed a belly for war and obligated slitting upon it, and extracting its fetus. Tatriq is when the exit of the child is difficult. This is a good metaphor for war. Al-A'idhi said:
'We are the sons of war, it fed us with its breast... and its temples and horns have turned gray.'
Hajib bin Zurara said:
'And the likes of me, if his noble striving is not rewarded... his favors speak with her mouth and pronounce.'
From this verse Nusayb took his saying:
'So they turned and praised with what you are worthy of... and if they were silent, the bags would have praised you.'
Al-Farazdaq said:
'And gray hair rises in youth as if it is... night whose sides shout day.'
Ibn Harma took it and said:
'And the day shouted in the night as if it were... contrary to the darkness, the flanks of a piebald horse with a blaze.'
Ibn Muqbil said:
'From early morning until they pulled at evening... and half the sun had died, and the half was critically ill.'
Sulayman bin Ammar al-Sulami said:
'And a master like abdominal disease, not leaving... his snakes and scorpions creep to us.'
He established the biting words of his speech in the place of snakes and scorpions. This is a good metaphor whose indicator is verbal, which is his saying: 'creep'. Jahsh bin Zaid al-Hanafi said:
'We weaned Banu Ka'b from war after it... and they met from the heroes a clumsy impact.'
The indicator in this verse is semantic. That is because comparing war to a she-camel with various attributes has settled with them, and that they mention its teats and that it flows milk and is milked. When it settled with them and became frequent among them, discarding it and bringing it became one to them. This is a subtle meaning, so know it. Ajlan bin La'i al-Tha'labi said:
'I wondered at the caller of war while war is raising its tail (shamidh)... pregnant, in our hands it is untied and saddled.'
Al-Shamidh: The she-camel 'shamidhat tashmidhu' with Kasrah 'shimadhan' if she is impregnated and raises her tail. Sabir bin Safwan al-Hudhali al-Hanafi said:
'And the sun ignited its fires and the Ghadwar of the desert... warmed itself with it until it flamed.'
Al-Muhriz bin al-Muka'bir al-Dabbi said:
'The reefs of glory flowed upon him when he called... his companions with faces like dinars.'
This is a good metaphor whose indicator is verbal, which is his saying: 'The reefs of glory flowed upon him', mentioning the flow (sayl) with the reefs (shi'ab). If he said: 'Glory flowed upon him', it would not be good. A man from Bal'anbar said:

'A people, if evil showed its molars to them... they flew to it in groups and individuals.'
Al-Asma'i recited:
'I ceased not bribing Time with patience over that which... displeases until Time pleased me with you.'
He made patience a bribe to Time to help him, which is a good metaphor. Qurt bin Haritha al-Amiri al-Kalbi said:
'Indeed, only the mutual support of sorrows... grayed the forelock of me and saddened me.'
The metaphor is in 'mutual support' (tanasur). Abu Dahbal al-Jumahi said:
'I say while the riders, their turbans have tilted... and night-talk has given the people the cup of intoxication to drink.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'Slumber gave him the cup of drowsiness to drink, so his head... to the religion of slumber at the end of the night is prostrating.'
Hamza bin Bayd al-Hanafi said:
'And gray hair resided in my head, so frightened me... a guest, by your father's life, not departing.
And he bent my spear then strung his bow... and shot with his arrows, so he pierced my legs.'
Al-Afwah al-Awdi said:
'Indeed the blessing of a people is enjoyment... and the life of a man is a borrowed robe.'
He made life a robe and made it borrowed. Ibn Mayyada describing glances:
'And they sharpened, when they wanted our struggle... arrows without feathers and without shafts.'
When 'arrows' settled for 'glance', he borrowed struggle and feathers, and the indicator here is verbal. Another said:
'We took the ends of conversations between us... and the valleys flowed with the necks of the mounts.'
Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah al-Makhzumi said:
'And she is hidden, confused from her... in the skin of the two cheeks is the water of youth.'
Tha'lab recited:
'When the askers came to him, the lamps of... cheerfulness and joy ignited upon him.'
Mihjan bin Utarid al-Anbari said:
'You tell me that calamity has come... and that the years of drought, their owl has shouted.'
This is a good metaphor. Metaphors in verse and prose exceed the limit of every confined limit; in what we brought is sufficiency. From the Titles previously mentioned:

**Chapter of Simile (Tashbih)**
Abu Amr bin al-Ala said: And Al-Asma'i said: The best simile is what has two similes in two similes, like the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'As if the hearts of birds, wet and dry... at her nest are jujube and worn-out bad dates.'
He only singled out the hearts of birds because they are the best part. It was said: The bird of prey, when it hunts a bird, brings its heart to its chicks as food without the rest of its meat. So there remains in its nest of bird hearts fresh and old due to the abundance of its hunting, as Abu Zubayd al-Ta'i said:
'Remaining overnight at his place from preys... are broken remains or fresh shredded meat.'
Rufat is old, and Gharid is fresh. Al-Asma'i said: The bird of prey brings the game to its nest, eats its meat and leaves its heart, so wet and dry bird hearts never cease to be in its nest. For this reason he singled out bird hearts over others. Bashar bin Burd said: I have not ceased, since I heard the verse of Imru' al-Qais, trying to approximate two similes with two similes but I cannot, until I said:
'As if the raising of dust above their heads... and our swords, is a night whose stars are falling.'
Bashar took it from the saying of Kulthum al-Attabi:
'Their hooves build above their heads... a roof whose stars are the cutting white [swords].'
Al-Asma'i narrated, saying: Al-Rashid summoned me one day, and his messengers startled me. I did not delay standing in his presence. In the assembly were Yahya bin Khalid, Ja'far, and Al-Fadl. He brought me near, so I approached, and the fear that befell me became clear. He said: 'Let your panic subside, we only wanted you for what the likes of you are wanted for.' I stayed until my soul returned to me. Then he put me at ease and said: 'I disputed with these'—and he pointed to Yahya, Ja'far, and Al-Fadl—'regarding the most poetic verse the Arabs said in simile. Our consensus did not fall on a verse to be pointed to over others. So we wanted you to decide this case and harvest the fruit of the bet.' I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, designating a single verse in a single type in which poets have expanded and set up as a landmark for their thoughts and a pasture for their minds is far from being textually fixed. However, the best of poets in simile is Imru' al-Qais.' He said: 'In what?' I said: 'In his saying:

'As if the eyes of the wild beasts around our domes... and our saddles are onyx which has not been pierced.'
And his saying:
'As if the hearts of birds, wet and dry... at her nest are jujube and worn-out bad dates.'
And his saying:
'I rose to her after her family slept... rising of the bubbles of water, state upon state.'
He said: So Al-Rashid turned to Yahya and said: 'This is one. He has stated that Imru' al-Qais is the most brilliant of people in simile.' He said: Yahya said: 'It is yours, O Commander of the Faithful.' Then Al-Rashid said: 'What are his most brilliant similes to you?' I said: 'His saying describing a horse:
"As if his looking up in the forenoon... is the looking up of a blue [eyed eagle] with claws.
If his housings are stripped from him... you say stripped [of flesh], but he is not stripped."' 
Al-Rashid said: 'This is good, and better than it is his saying:
"So we went with him like the water bird, being led in our midst... the eye descends in him at times and ascends."' 
Ja'far said: 'It is arbitration, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'How?' He said: 'Let the Commander of the Faithful mention what his choice fell upon, and we mention what we chose, and the judgment will occur afterwards.' Al-Rashid said: 'You have hit the mark (Aghradta).' Al-Asma'i said: I appreciated it from him. It is said: 'Aghrada al-rajul' if he neared correctness. Then Al-Rashid said: 'Let Yahya begin.' Yahya said: 'The best of people in simile is Al-Nabigha in his saying:
"She looked at you with a need she did not fulfill... the look of the sick to the faces of the visitors."
And his saying:
"For you are like the night that overtakes me... even if I thought the distance from you is wide."
And his saying:
"From the wild of Wajra, marked on her shanks... folding the gut like the sword of the solitary polisher."'
Al-Asma'i said: I said: 'As for the simile of the sickness of the eye, it is good, except that he spoiled it by mentioning illness and likening the woman to a sick person. Better than it is the saying of Adi bin al-Riqa':
"Drowsy, slumber targeted him so... a sleep fluttered in his eye and he is not sleeping."
As for likening attainment to the night and day in what they attain, the way was for him to bring what has no counterpart so he brings a unique meaning. If a sayer wished to say that the saying of Al-Namari in this meaning is better, he would find justification, which is:
"Even if I were in Al-Anqa' or its summits... I would think you, unless you turn away, see me."
As for his saying: "Like the sword of the solitary polisher", Al-Tirimmah is more deserving of this meaning than him, because he took it, improved it, and added to it, even if Al-Nabigha initiated it. Al-Tirimmah said:
"It appears and the lands hide it as if it is... a sword on a high place being drawn and sheathed."
He combined in this verse a subtle metaphor in his saying "hide it", and likened two things to two things in his saying "appears and hides" and "drawn and sheathed", which is a good antithesis, and contains good explanation and correct correspondence.'
Al-Asma'i said: Al-Rashid rejoiced until the lines of his face shone, so I imagined lightning flashing from them. He said to Yahya: 'I surpassed you, by the Lord of the Kaaba.' Yahya's color paled as if hot ash was sprinkled on him. Al-Fadl said: 'Do not hasten, O Commander of the Faithful, until what he said passes his hearing.' He said: 'Speak.' Al-Fadl said: 'The best of people in simile to me is Tarafa in his saying:
"Her breastbone splits the bubbles of water with her... just as the Mufayil divides the dust with the hand."
Al-Mufayil is the one who gathers dust and divides it into two or three halves and puts a hidden object in it. Al-Fayal is the noun without Hamza. So he likened the ship splitting water with its chest to their dividing the dust. And his saying:
"By your life, indeed death, whatever the youth misses... is like the slackened tether whose folded end is in the hand."
And his saying:
"And a face as if the sun cast its robe... upon it, pure of color, not wrinkled."'

Al-Asma'i said: 'This is all good, and others are better than it. A group of poets shared these meanings with him. Furthermore, Tarafa is an author of one [poem]; he is not judged by the meters, but is counted among the authors of the single [masterpiece].' He said: 'And who are the authors of the single?' He said: 'Al-Harith bin Hilliza, Al-As'ar al-Ju'fi, Al-Afwah al-Awdi, Alqama al-Fahl, Suwayd bin Abi Kahil, Amr bin Kulthum, and Amr bin Ma'dikarib.' Al-Asma'i said: Generosity lightened Al-Rashid so he said: 'Come near, for you are a lone foal.' He said: So he increased in nobility in my eyes. Ja'far said, quoting a proverb: 'Wait a little, Hamal will join the battle.' Insinuating that he might catch up with what he attempts. Al-Rashid said:
'By Allah, the forerunners missed you in the range... and you came a silent one with increased limbs, fourth.'
He said: I saw heat in his face. Ja'far said: 'On the condition of your clemency, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'Do you think it encompasses other than you and narrows from you!?' Ja'far said: 'I do not specify a single poet as the best of people in simile in one verse, but the saying of Imru' al-Qais is among the best similes where he says:
"As if my boy, when he topped the state of his back... is on the back of a hawk in the sky soaring."
And Adi bin al-Riqa' said:
"They exchange of dust a robe... dusty, tightly woven, they both wove it.
It is folded if they ascend a protruding place... and if the hooves tread smooth ground, they spread it."
And Al-Nabigha's saying:
"For you are a sun and the kings are stars... when it rises, no star appears from them."
From this meaning Nusayb took his saying:
"He is the full moon and people are the stars around him... and do stars resemble the luminous full moon?"'
Al-Asma'i said: 'This is all pure, brilliant, and others are more brilliant than it. The designation needs to fall on what its sayer invented and was not approached, or a poet approached it but fell short. As for Imru' al-Qais's saying: "on the back of a hawk in the sky soaring", it is from the saying of Abu Du'ad:
"If its rider wished, he hugged him... as a hawk hugs the wing to itself."
As for Adi's saying: "They exchange of dust a robe", it is from Al-Khansa's saying:
"He raced his father, so they approached while they... exchanged the robe of the run."
The first to speak this meaning was a Jahili poet from Banu Uqayl, saying from verses:
"Desolate deserts where the sandgrouse become bewildered... and two wild asses become morning in them battling.
Raising from the weave of dust upon them... two shirts, worn out, which they wear."
As for Al-Nabigha's saying: "For you are a sun" etc., an ancient poet from Kinda praising Amr bin Hind preceded him in it, and he is more entitled to it than Al-Nabigha as he was its deflowerer (originator):
"The earth almost sways with people if they see... for Amr bin Hind anger while he is blaming.
He is the sun, surpassed on a day of fortune, so he excelled... in light, and the kings are stars."' 
He said: By Allah, it was as if I fed Ja'far a stone. Al-Rashid shook on his throne with joy, almost flying from wonder and delight, and said: 'O Asma'i, hear what my choice fell upon now.' I said: 'Let the Commander of the Faithful speak, may Allah grant him success.' He said: 'I have designated three poems; I swear by Allah I possess the winning cane with one of them. Do you know, O Asma'i, a grander and greater simile in a most contemptible and small simulated object in a better exhibition than the saying of Antara:
"And the fly was alone with it, so it is not leaving... singing like the act of the drinker humming.
Singing, sharpening his arm with his arm... the strike of the one bending over the fire-stick, the mutilated."
Then he said: 'O Asma'i, this is of the sterile (unique) similes.' I said: 'It is so, O Commander of the Faithful, and by your glory I swore I never heard anyone describe in poetry a thing better than this description, nor was able to reach this limit.' He said: 'Gently, do not hasten. Do you know better than the saying of Al-Hutay'ah describing the foam of his she-camel, or do you know anyone before him or after him who likened his likeness where he says:
"You see between her jaws when she murmurs... foam like the stretched spider's web."' 
He said: I said: 'I did not know anyone preceded him or indicated this meaning after him.' He said: 'Do you know more brilliant and effective than Al-Shammakh's simile of an ostrich whose feathers fell and its trace remained in his saying:

"As if the bending of the stems of what she stripped... of the fluff with her two sides are warts."' 
I said: 'No, by Allah.' He turned to Yahya and said: 'Is it obligatory?' He said: 'It is obligatory.' He said: 'Shall I increase you?' He said: 'And what good has the Commander of the Faithful not increased me from?' He said: 'The saying of Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di:
"He shot the udder of an old camel, so she poured with a stab... like the border of the Yemeni striped robe."' 
Then he turned to Al-Fadl and said: 'Is it obligatory?' He said: 'It is obligatory.' He said: 'Shall I increase you?' He said: 'That is up to the Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'The saying of the Bedouin:
"In it the striking of the scars of the old she-camels is as if... playgrounds of children lining and sharpening."' 
Then he turned to Ja'far and said: 'Is it obligatory?' He said: 'It is obligatory.' He said: 'Shall I increase you?' He said: 'To the Commander of the Faithful belongs the high opinion.' He said: 'The saying of Adi bin al-Riqa':
"She drives a nasal-voiced one, as if the needle of his horn... is a pen that hit from the inkwell its ink."' 
He said: Then Al-Rashid looked down, raised his glance and said: 'O Asma'i, do you think you cheat me of my mind by your lowering yourself in my desire?' I said: 'No, by Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, indeed you are too majestic for instigation.' He said: 'Look well.' I said: 'I have looked.' He said: 'So the precedence belongs to whom?' I said: 'To the Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'I have allotted you a tenth of it, and a tenth is much.' Then he threw his glance to Yahya and said: 'The money,' threateningly and menacingly. It was but yes and no until the purses were stacked before him so they almost stood between me and him. I saw the light of dawn had overcome the light of the candle. He signaled to a servant at his head, so he gave me from the money, which was three million dirhams, thirty purses. I left with it to the house, and he rose from his assembly. It was the happiest night with which a morning smiled upon accomplished wealth. Bashar said: When I composed my saying 'As if the raising of dust' etc., and its mention has preceded, I returned and presented the meaning in closer wording, saying:
'Of every famous one in the hand of a famous one... as if his blaze and the sword are two stars.'
I likened the blaze of the man and the sword to two stars. Muslim bin al-Walid followed him and said:
'In a dark cloud the open land shines with it... like the night whose stars are the swords and spears.'
Mansur al-Namari took it and said:
'A night of dust, no sun and no moon... except your forehead and the sharp pointed spears.'
A man from Banu Asad says:
'Accidents shaved my locks so they left me... a head ringing as if it is a Jummah.
And the fire of gray hair grew in my temples and the horn of my forelock... as the lamp grew.'
Jummah: plural Jamamih, is a yellow arrow with no arrowhead, having clay at its head like a lump children play with. Close to this simile is the saying of another, and he has a story:
'I went with a head like the small rock, overlooked... by an eagle, then its eagle flew.
And a bull went with it, shining as if it is... chains of lightning, its downpour and pouring.'
Abu Zaid recited:
'As if the casting of a rein at her knee... on the ground is a snake not slithering.'
Abu Du'ad al-Iyadi said:
'Struggling with the fold of a Hadrami [rope] as if it is... the bubble of a sand dune followed by a grazing [animal] throwing.'
Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani said:
'Thrown with the flesh of the meat, its protruding tooth... has a creaking, the creaking of the bucket pulley with the rope.'
The people of Badi' call this the Stripped Simile. If they liken what has motion and sound, they use Nasb (accusative) as they said: 'Sarifan Sarifa' (creaking the creaking of), in accusative. If it is not so, they use Raf' (nominative) as the sayer says: 'Lahu ra'sun ra'su al-asad' (He has a head [like] the head of a lion), in nominative. From it is simile by action, which is their saying: 'He does the deed of the noble', and 'He is forbearing the forbearance of Al-Ahnaf'. The meaning: He does a deed like the deed of the noble, and is forbearing a forbearance like the forbearance of Al-Ahnaf. From it is His Almighty's saying: "And you see the mountains, thinking them rigid, while they pass as the passing of clouds." Antara said in similes of banners:
'Battalions driven, above every battalion... a banner like the shadow of the bird turning.'
And he has in similes of the killed:
'As if they are by the side of the ravine, fallen... having given each other the cup of wine to drink.'
And he has in similes of tears:
'Is it from the weeping of a dove in a thicket... your tears overflowed over the back of the camel litter?
Like pearls or the arrangement of beads, cut... from it the knots of its string, not connected.'

Abu Nadlah Yamut bin al-Muzarri' said:
'And the full moon leans to setting as if... it drew over the water a gilded sword.'
And he has:
'I did not forget the Tigris while the darkness is cut... and the full moon in the horizon of the sky is setting.
So as if it [Tigris] in it is a blue robe... and as if it [moon] in it is a gilded embroidery.'
Abu Muhallim said describing the sun:
'Hidden; as for when the night covers it... it hides, and as for in the day, it appears.'
Al-Kindi said describing the Pleiades:
'When the Pleiades in the sky exposed themselves... the exposure of the folds of the preferred sash.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'I arrived by night journey while the Pleiades were as if... on the crown of the head a water bird circling.'
Qais bin al-Aslat said, and did well:
'And the Pleiades appeared in the morning to whoever saw... like a cluster of white grapes when it blossoms.'
Yazid Ibn al-Tathriya said:
'When the Pleiades in the sky were as if... pearls whose string weakened so they scattered.'
Some of them said:
'So seize drinking it, for the moon has exposed the night... as if it is the span of a fire-stick.
And the Pleiades are fluttering in the canopy of the... West, falling as if they are the head of a leopard.'
Al-Himyari said regarding the slain of Ali, peace be upon him:
'You see the birds like women around him... going early to a sick man as visitors.'
A Bedouin said describing armor:
'Upon them like pools, doubled... of Mazi [armor], not burdening the backs.'
Abu Du'ad al-Iyadi said:
'And I prepared for war a flowing [coat of mail]... dwindling in folding, like the file.'
Ka'b bin Sa'd al-Ghanawi said:
'And a people dragging their robes as if they are... drunk, while you alerted them for departure.'
He describes them with drowsiness. Zuhair said in likening the traces of dwellings to tattoos on palms and wrists:
'And a house for her at Al-Raqmatayn as if... references of tattoo on the sinews of a wrist.'
Antara said likening the jaw of a crow:
'Clumsy of wing, as if the two jaws of his head... are shears for news, fragile, fond.'
Al-Ra'i said describing a hunter with curly head hair:
'So as if the peak of his head from his hair... was planted, so its two sides grew pepper.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And a night like the bride's jilbab I wore... with four [camels], while the figure in the eye is one.'
Mudarris bin Rib'i said describing an ostrich:
'Small-headed, bare of neck veins, her head... like the mallet and her nose like the awl.'
Al-Nabigha said describing vultures:
'You see them behind the people, looking askance, their eyes... the sitting of old men in the skins of hares.'
The sister of Amr Dhi al-Kalb said and did well:
'The vultures walk to him while she is playful... the walk of virgins upon whom are jilbabs.'
Dhu al-Rumma said likening sand to the hips of virgins:
'And sand like the hips of virgins I crossed... when the dark black nights wore it.'
Al-Sayyid al-Himyari innovated and did well in describing the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, and likening him to the wind of Ad, and was not preceded to that:
'But Abu Hasan, and Allah supported him... was at the encounter accustomed to stabbing.
If he saw a warring assembly, he put them to sleep... the sleep of the Wind in its homes, 'Ad.'
Al-Kindi said:
'I gathered a Rudayni spear as if its spearhead... is the light of a flame not connected to smoke.'
Al-Hamid recited:
'As if what falls from her foam... is the house of spiders upon her rein.'
This is like the verse of Al-Hutay'ah previously mentioned. The meaning is that he likened the foam to the spider's web due to their sharing in thinness and distance from density. It is said: 'Ankabut' and 'Akanbah', as they said: 'Uqab' and 'Uqanbah', and it is said: 'Ankaba'. In this is an explanation whose exposition is long and this is not its place. Mu'aqqir al-Bariqi said in his simile of armies:
'And he gathered a gathering as if its number... is locusts blown in dust flying.'
He also said:

So battalions came to them early at sunrise... like the corners of Salma, their march successive.
Al-Hakami said describing a ship:
So it was as if, while the water struck its chest... and the bamboo pole was in the sailor's hand.
[Like] a black one of the eagles rushing to the darkness... descending with a sound and flapping of wing.
This chapter is vast in scope, far from ending, like the sea whose waves cannot be counted, nor its path exhausted. In what we have presented is more than enough. Among them:

**Chapter of Sound Padding in Useful Meaning (Al-Hashw Al-Sadid fi Al-Ma'na Al-Mufid)**
Abu al-Shis al-Khuza'i said:
Indeed the eighty [years], *and may you reach them*, ... have made my hearing in need of a translator.
His saying: *and may you reach them*, is sound padding, and it has benefited as a supplication with a good meaning.
Al-Yazidi recited:
So who is for me regarding the eye with which you were once... towards me, *my soul be your ransom*, looking.
His saying: *my soul be your ransom*, is like his saying: *and may you reach them*, in supplication.
Abu al-Walid Abdul Malik bin Abdul Rahman al-Harithi said:
If what is with me were with you, *may it not be with you*, then... kindness towards me and closeness would have come to you early and late.
His saying: *may it not be with you* is good padding.
Abu Amr bin al-Ala recited from the Jahili era:
And an old camel, *little of guilt*, I returned to beating him... when longing from her familiar places stirred a memory.
And I said to him: Dhalfa', woe to you, caused... the beating for you, so be patient, *for your habit is patience*.
Ibn al-Mu'tazz took this meaning and said:
And horses that leading has folded until they seem like... brown tubes of al-Khatt spears, withered.
We poured upon them, *being unjust*, our whips... so quick hands and legs flew with them.
His saying: *being unjust* is like his saying: *little of guilt*. This is the sound padding, in useful wording.
As for when the padding is like the saying of Abu al-Iyal al-Hudhali:
I remembered my brother so there returned to me... headache of *the head* and pain.
Headache is only in the head, so mentioning *the head* is unsound padding. Similar is the saying of Dik al-Jinn:
So it breathed in the house when mixed... with water and unsheathed the light of flame.
Like the breathing of basil mixed with... fresh branches from the roses of Jur.
So his mentioning *mixing* suffices, and his mentioning *water* is an addition not needed. He fell short of Abu Nuwas's saying:
Pull the mask of clay from a remnant... alive with life, overlooking death.
So it breathed in the house when mixed... like the breathing of basil *in the nose*.
This example in this chapter is sufficient. Among them:

**Chapter of Following (Al-Mutaba'a)**
Following in prose speech and organized poetry is that the speaker brings meanings that cannot be advanced one over the other, because the meanings in them are sequential. So the first is followed by the second, and the second is followed by the third, until the speaker reaches the end of his intent. It is not permissible to advance the second over the first, nor the third over the second. An example of that is His Almighty's saying: (It is He who created you from dust, then from a sperm-drop, then from a clot, then He brings you out as a child, then let you reach your maturity, then let you become old men). And He, Blessed and Exalted, said: (Then he called her from below her, "Do not grieve; your Lord has provided beneath you a stream. And shake toward you the trunk of the palm tree; it will drop upon you ripe, fresh dates. So eat and drink and be contented.") This is of the best craft of speech in this chapter, so glory be to the Speaker of it and Exalted greatly.
Al-Asma'i recited:
But she is a friendship whose blood was mixed with... tragedy, passion, breaking promises, and changing.
Faj' (tragedy) here is treachery, and Wal' (passion/lying) is lying. And their saying: The world, its tragedies (faja'i'uha) are not safe from, meaning its treacheries. The aspect of following is that if treachery occurs, lying becomes evident, and if changing occurs, difference appears.
Zuhair said:
It is delayed, so placed in a book, so stored... for a Day of Reckoning, or hastened so avenged.
Al-Shanfara said:
With my eyes when she entered evening, so spent the night, so entered morning... so she decreed matters, so she rose, so she turned away.
Arta'ah bin Suhayya said:
You ate blood and we drank blood... so we were not quenched from it nor were you satiated.
Ibn Sulayman al-Kilabi said:

So there ceased not to be from them a defender and a stabber... in a state, or a striker and a stabber.
A'sha of Ukl said:
We stopped at it until the intensity of the forenoon passed... fulfilling needs and weeping for youthful passion.
And we gift greetings and show affection... and hide of the passion that is not hidden.
As for the first verse, there is no witness in it, but we established it for the clarity of the second verse, and advancing and delaying is permissible in it. As for the second verse, the aspect of following in it is that greetings are what is begun with, then affection appears and some of it is hidden, even if it is not hidden as he mentioned.
Ziyad al-A'jam said:
O family of Lukayz, a call of one not regretful... Did an Anazi insult me, then was not slapped?
Nor was his nose cut, nor was he dyed with blood?
Amr bin al-Harith said:
So he may visit my pot and I ladle its meat... so I become my boon companion so I earn my praise.
Visiting happens first, then ladling, then giving drink, and after that praise is earned.
Al-Jawn al-Namari said:
Who will convey to Shayban that... I, my affair was not hidden.
I shot him until when... our arrows were exhausted.
I stabbed him until when... our spears were splinters.
I struck him until when... our swords were bent.
I wounded him by overcoming, and he was... defended of old, refusing.
I gave him my saddle and my... mount and a Himyari saddle.
Did you see if a snake bit... your brother in the land, vomiting?
Or the sickness of death attained him... then what is upon me and what is with me?
These verses have a story whose explanation is long, and we only mention a little of it: That is when it was the Day of Uwarah, Al-Jawn al-Namari captured Haritha bin Amr bin Abi Rabi'ah bin Dhuhl bin Shayban. King Al-Mundhir overcame Al-Jawn, took Haritha from him and killed him. Banu Shayban claimed that Al-Jawn killed him. So he said this poetry describing his state with him. He began by mentioning shooting which is the beginning of war, and followed with mentioning stabbing, then mentioning striking, then victory belongs to one of the two parties; so either favor or killing. When he completed that, he followed it with reproach like one apologizing to them. In this example is sufficiency. Among them:

**Chapter of the Pleasant Transition (Makhlas) to Satire and Praise**
Ali bin al-Munajjim said: I asked my father, who was one of the knights of knowledge of poetry, about the best transition a poet used to transition to praise or satire. He said: O my son, this is a path in which the moderns (Muwalladun) were unique; rarely did excellence in it happen for an ancient. As for what I found our people agreeing upon of that, it is the saying of Muhammad bin Wuhayb:
He ceased not letting me kiss his lips... and the pitcher and the cup gave me a second drink.
Until the night reclaimed its robe... and a brightness appeared through its blackness.
And the morning appeared as if its blaze... is the face of the Caliph when he is praised.
He only looked from this meaning to the saying of the Bedouin:
I say while the star, its left sides leaned... to setting: Contemplate a perplexed look.
Is it a glimpse of the light of lightning my sight saw... or the face of Nu'm appeared to me or the light of a fire?
Nay, the face of Nu'm appeared while the night was dark... so it loomed from between screens and curtains.
Hassan said in satire:
If you were lying about what you told me... then may you escape the escape of Al-Harith bin Hisham.
He left the loved ones to fight without them... and escaped with the head of a swift mare and a bridle.
The moderns have many beautiful poems in this chapter; we have no need to prolong by mentioning them. In what we have cited is sufficiency, and Allah is the Grantor of success to what is right. Among them:

**Chapter of Inclusion (Tadmin)**
It is called Tasmits and Tawshih. This is very rare in the poetry of the Arabs. The moderns have used of it what cannot be counted in abundance and number, and a little of it is evidence of much. Al-Akhtal said:
And he rose to the Khurrami but did not say... after fatigue: But my advance narrowed.
He included the saying of Antara:
When they shield themselves with me from the spearheads I did not recoil... from them: But my advance narrowed.
Another said from verses:

When I weep for bankruptcy, misery, and poverty... they say: *Do not perish of sorrow and show beauty.*
Indeed my repetition and my confinement upon you has prolonged... *so is there any reliance at an effaced trace?*
I wore out at the Prince's door as if I were... *Stop, let us weep from the memory of a beloved and a dwelling.*
Another said:
Her Amr said to me when she flirted with me... *Do not stop at the effaced ruins.*
Among them:

**Chapter of Feigned Ignorance (Tajahul al-Ta'aruf)**
The meaning of feigned ignorance is that the poet or prose writer asks about something he knows, the question of one who does not know it, so that it is known that the intensity of resemblance to the likened object has caused that in him. It is frequent in the poems and speeches of the Arabs. Dhu al-Rumma said:
I say to a dark-lipped, long-necked one who ran... for us between the top of 'Urfa and the cutting sands.
O gazelle of the soft sand between Julajul... and the sand dune, *are you or Umm Salim?*
Ibn Duraid recited for some of them:
Is it from the full moon at evening... that those curtains were lifted?
Or from the sun was unveiled... at midnight that veil?
Or upon the neck of a gazelle... were those earrings hung?
Or did time show you what... the standing people did not see?
As for His Almighty's saying: (And what is that in your right hand, O Moses? He said: It is my staff). The intent of this question, with knowledge of it, is to manifest the miracle which Moses did not know was in the staff. The people of the craft called it the Question of Confirmation. Likewise His Almighty's saying: (And when Allah said, "O Jesus, Son of Mary, did you say to the people, 'Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah?'"). Allah Almighty knew that he did not say that. The intent of it is rebuking whoever claimed that and belying whoever said it. So it is a question of a confirmer, not a question of an inquirer, so know it. Among them:

**Chapter of Mumatana (Poetic Contest), Infaq (Exhaustion), and Ijazah (Completion)**
As for Mumatana, it is two poets disputing a verse between them; one says its beginning (Sadr) and the other its end (Ajuz).
As for Infad and Ijazah: Infad, with un-dotted Dal, is from their saying: A disputant is Munafid if he argues until he exhausts his proof. And you say: Nafadtu al-rajul (I exhausted the man), like I judged him. In the Hadith: "If you exhaust them, they will exhaust you." It is that a poet says a complete verse and the other says a verse.
As for Mumatana, it is narrated that a boy from Banu Janb called Rifa'a, and it is said: he is Al-Muhtarish, excelled in poetry and contested the poets of his people until he overcame them. When he became confident in himself of that, he said to his father: I will surely go out among the tribes of Yemen; if I find someone who contests me, I will return to my land, and if I do not encounter someone who contests me, I will explore all the tribes of the Arabs. He stopped at a clan of Banu Nahd, and the neighborhood was empty of men (Khuluf). He made his camel kneel aside from the dwellings. Suddenly, an old woman, sturdy (Hayzabun), approached leaning on a crooked stick. She said: Good evening (Im Zalaman). He said: Good evening to you. She said: From whom is the man? He said: From Madhhij. She said: From which of them? He said: From Janb. She said: A guest? He said: Yes. She said: May Allah not have mercy on you, you did nothing but deem us miserly and made our story bad. Then she roused his mount and said: Rise to the dome of our guests. She did not let him possess his mount until she brought it to the dome and made it kneel, then unloaded his saddle and sheltered him in her tent. She ordered a maid of hers, who came with a knife and a young goat strutting in its skin from fatness. She said: Slaughter, O man. And she kneaded, baked, cooked, and presented food. The man, the old woman, and the maid sat eating. The old woman said to him: What threw you into this land? He informed her of his news. She laughed and said: Spend the night comfortably, tomorrow I will bring you ten virgins who will contest you instead of the men. If you are overcome, return to your land. When morning came, the old woman approached with three young women like fillies. They stepped aside. Then she pointed to one of them, and she approached like a tall palm tree swayed by the east wind. She said: Are you the challenger in Mumatana? He said: Yes. She said: Say, let me hear. He said:
Grazing camels, their pregnant ones called out with yearning.
She said:
Carriers of burdens, rising heavily so walking slowly.
He said:
When their shepherds called out in their two sides.
She said:
Separated ones rose from them, raising tails, pregnant.
He said:
If they tread a land, they water it with their flow.
She said:
Cream of musk, pure, not mixed.
He said:

When their udders poured, you thought what flowed...
She said:
On the ground from them is a deep sea splashing.
The man said to the old woman: Is this girl divorced or does she have a husband? She said:
A shackle, by Allah's life, if I wished I could cut it...
Is my straying, but nobility is more worthy.
The man said: I turned to my saddle. The old woman said: Gently, I will bring you the other. He said: The first quenched me. She said: Join your land now.
The man said: I went out wanting to return to my people, then stubbornness refused me except to pursue what I went out for. I was pushed to a clan of Jarm. Suddenly, little boys were playing at a pond. I went down to look at them, and behold, they were reciting Rajaz. I called a boy from the most elevated of them and said: O boy, is there anyone in this clan of yours who can contest me? For I have overcome the poets of the Arabs. He said: I will contest you. I said: You, O little one! He said: Say, and leave what does not benefit you.
I said:
Wild beasts like the Onyx of Zafar, four.
He said:
A dark-haired, speckled one protected them.
I said:
He roams the meadow with them, and safety is his neighbor.
He said:
And the drawn sword and the deposited are empty for them.
I said: Woe to you. And I mounted my camel until I was pushed to an old man tending little sheep of his. I asked him for hospitality. He hastened to a cup and milked the remainder of what was in their udders, then brought it to me and I drank. When I was at ease, he said to me: What threw you to this region? I informed him, and hid from him what I encountered. The old man grinned then shouted at boys grazing near him. A boy from them approached. He said: Call Ashraqa. It was not long before a little girl came, lean as if she were a stick of Khaysafuj, until she stood before him. He said: Indeed your cousin here went out of his land challenging in Mumatana. Do you have anything? She said: Say, O challenger. And she was turning her eyes like the eyes of a speckled snake. I said:
What is a blue drop in the shadow of a rock?
She said:
A store of a white-peaked, dark-layered [cloud].
I said:
The flowing of the wind denied the speck from its surface.
She said:
And the branches of the thicket drove away the burning heat from its purity.
I said:
A saliva is mixed, the bees purified its honey.
She said:
With a pure reddish wine, the foam was removed from its surface.
He said: I left what I intended and inclined to another direction, and described a she-camel. She laughed and said: You became obscure? I said:
When the chameleon flattens itself on the head of its stick.
She said:
And the intense heat forced the mother of the lizard into its burrow.
Rifa'a said: I returned to my family and swore to myself not to contest anyone after her as long as I lived. This example in Mumatana is sufficient, and were it not for lengthiness, I would have cited wondrous witty things of this type.
As for Infad and Ijazah, it was narrated that Ka'b bin Zuhair, when he started composing poetry, his father Zuhair used to forbid him from it; fearing that his poetry was not yet firm, so what would be flawed would be narrated from him. He used to beat him for that. He overcame him, and that went on for long, so he took him and imprisoned him and said: By the One I swear by, you shall not speak a verse of poetry, nor shall it reach me that you desire a poem, except I will beat you a beating that will deter you from that. He remained imprisoned for days, then he was informed that he spoke it. So he beat him a severe beating, then released him and sent him out with a small flock while he was a little boy. He went and grazed it, then returned with it while reciting Rajaz:
As if I drive with my flock a caravan...
From the villages, loaded with barley.
Zuhair went out to him angry. He called for a she-camel, rode it, reached him and let him ride behind him. Then he moved his camel wanting to test Ka'b, and know what he had, and see his poetry. He said when he separated from the tribe:
And indeed a bold she-camel goes early with me upon worry...
Trotting with a connecter, cutting off, and galloping.
Then he hit him and said: Complete (Ajiz), O slave (Luka'). He said:
Like the structure of the Qari, the place of her saddle...
And the traces of her two straps from the side are piebald.
Zuhair said:
On a clear path like the galaxy, you thought it...
When it ascends a highland from the earth, spilled.
Then he said: Complete, O slave. He said:
Illuminating, its guidance, its night is like its day...
Whole, when it ascends the rugged ground, distinct.
Zuhair said:
She stays in the soft sand of the dune as if she is...
A tent upon the two poles of a tent-pole, tented.
Then he said: Complete, O slave. He said:

The love of the forenoon delayed him, and he saw... the sky of a peeled-legged, long-necked [ostrich].
Zuhair said:
She yearns for the likes of heavy [birds], crouching...
At a path from her split eggs.
Then he said: Complete, O slave. He said:
Her eggs shattered from her, revealing beaks...
And eyes like small pox that have not split.
Zuhair took Ka'b's hand and said to him: I have permitted you poetry. Among them:

**Chapter of Plagiarism (Sariqa)**
Plagiarism in poems is divided into two parts: praiseworthy and blameworthy. The stallion poets of the Arabs used to find poetry theft ugly, as Tarafa said:
'I do not raid upon poems stealing them... I am rich without them, and the worst of people is he who steals.'
Despite this, they have ugly thefts, and raids ignited by the fire-sticks of abundance. As for the praiseworthy plagiarism, it is of ten types:
First: Fulfilling the long wording in the brief concise. Tarafa said:
'I see the grave of a miserly hoarder of his wealth... like the grave of a strayer in idleness, spoiling.'
Ibn al-Ziba'ra abbreviated it and said:
'And gifts are mean between us... and equal is the grave of a wealthy and a poor.'
He occupied the beginning of the verse with a meaning and brought Tarafa's verse in the end of a verse shorter than it with a clear meaning and distinct wording.
Second: Transferring the base to the solid sturdy. A Bedouin wishing for his wife's death said:
'Indeed the death of the Amiri woman, if Time decreed it... is life for Ibn al-Wa'ili.'
The meaning is subtle and the wording is weak. The brother of Al-Harith bin Hilliza took it and said:
'Do not be despising the affair of a man... perhaps from the affair are affairs.
Perhaps eyes were cooled by a grief... burning, from which eyes had become hot.'
Third: Transferring what is ugly in structure but not in meaning to what is beautiful in structure and meaning. Al-Hakami said:
'The voice of wealth became hoarse from... complaining about you and shouting.'
Its meaning is correct and its wording is ugly. Salm took it and said:
'Wealth and enemies complained of his hand... he ceased not to be an oppressor to wealth and enemies.'
He combined two noble complaints, and prayed for the praised one to continue his oppression of wealth and enemies, and improved the craft in his wording and taking.
Fourth: Reversing what becomes by reversal praise after being satire.
'Whatever you wish of wealth, a sanctuary... sheltering to a permissible honor.'
The sayer reversed it and said:
'He is the man, as for his wealth it is permissible... to a seeker, and as for his honor it is forbidden.'
Fifth: Extracting a meaning from a meaning he followed, even if he differed from what was intended by it. Al-Hakami said about wine:
'Night does not descend where she settled... so the time of her drinkers is day.'
Al-Buhturi followed him, and differed from Al-Hakami's intent, making it about a beloved, saying:
'Her darkness disappeared, and what night... darkens upon us while you are a full moon!?'
Sixth: Generating speech from speech whose wording is different and meaning is agreed, and it is indicative of the poet's acumen. Al-Asma'i recited for some of them:
'A boy of war who plunged into it and perished... and a grinding millstone ground him.
For upon the youth is advancing in it... and not upon him is what death committed.'
Abu Tammam took it and said:
'For a matter, upon them is that its beginnings complete... and not upon them is that its consequences complete.'
The meaning is agreed and the wording is different, and this is among the best faces of thefts.
Seventh: Generating appreciated meanings in different words. This is rare in poems, and it was among the worthiest of what the poet strained his acumen in, except that it is difficult. The poet said:
'As if the cups of the drink while the night is dark... are the faces of virgins in black wraps.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz derived from it his saying:
'And I see the Pleiades in the sky as if it is... a foot that appeared from mourning clothes.'
Eighth: Equality between the stolen-from and the stealer, with an addition that attached the preceded to the precedent. Al-Dik said:
'Diluted from the hand of a gazelle as if... he took it from his cheek and circulated it.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz took it and said:
'As if the purest of wine is from the water of his cheek... and its cluster is picked from his curly hair.'

So he added a simile that is from the completeness of meaning, so they became equal; this by his precedence, and this by his addition. And its like is many.
Ninth: Similarity in speech until no system is preferred over another. Hassan bin Thabit said:
'They are visited until their dogs do not bark... they do not ask about the approaching black figure.'
Al-Hakami took it and said:
'To the house of a tavern keeper whose dogs do not bark... at me, nor do they deny the length of my stay.'
There is no difference between the two meanings nor the two speeches, for they are similar.
Tenth: The preponderance of the taker's wording over the taken-from, and the preference of his meaning over a meaning he issued from him. Al-Nabigha said:
