'The veil (Nasif) fell and she did not want its falling... so she took it and shielded herself from us with the hand.'
Abu Hayya al-Numayri took it and said:
'So she cast a mask, beneath it is the sun, and shielded herself... with the best connected two: a palm and a wrist.'
Al-Nabigha did not increase upon informing of her shielding with her hand when her veil fell. Abu Hayya increased upon him by his saying: 'beneath it is the sun', and informed about shielding with the best report, of the beauty of a palm and the beauty of a wrist. So his speech outweighed and his system rose.

As for the blameworthy of Plagiarism, it is also ten types:
First: Transferring the short wording to the long abundant. Al-Hakami said:
'Do not extend a favor to me... until I perform thanks for what has passed.'
Di'bil took it and said:
'I left you, I did not leave you out of ingratitude for a blessing... and is attaining increase hoped for by ingratitude?
But when I saw you desiring... and you exceeded in kindness to me, I was incapable of thanks.'
The poetry is good in meaning and wording, but he brought it in lengthening and inclusion, so he transferred the short to the long, and that is blameworthy in theft.
Second: Transferring the solid sturdy to the weakened base. The first said:
'And I killed you with satire but you did not die... indeed dogs are long of lives.
He ceased not barking at me to become noble, striving... like the dog barking at the full moons.'
Ibn Tahir took it and said:
'And we killed you with satire... but you are a dog with a hooked tail.'
He combined the ugliness of theft and weakness of expression. There is no reason to mention hooking in the tail, because it does not indicate long life. This is apparent and its like is many.
Third: Transferring what is beautiful in meaning and structure to what is ugly in structure and meaning. Al-Kindi said:
'Did you not see that I, whenever I came knocking... found fragrance in her even if she did not perfume herself?'
Bashar took it and said:
'And if you brought an onion near her... musk would overcome the smell of the onion.'
This is the lowest poetry in baseness, just as Al-Kindi's verse is the highest verse in quality and sturdiness. Kuthayyir took the meaning, so he lengthened, included, and shortened, claiming that if she fumigated herself she was like a garden in its fragrance. This is not lacking in the most malodorous of humans in body and dirtiest in state, and his poetry is known.
Fourth: Reversing what becomes by reversal satire after being praise. Hassan bin Thabit said:
'White of faces, noble of lineages... high of noses (proud), from the first style.'
Ibn Abi Fanan took it and reversed it, saying:
'Black of faces, mean of lineages... flat of noses, from the last style.'
Fifth: Transferring what its meters and rhymes are beautiful to what is ugly and heavy on the tongue of its narrator. Al-Hakami said:
'Leave blaming me, for blame is incitement... and cure me with that which was the disease.'
Al-Ta'i took it and said:
'Enough, slow down, you have exceeded in excess... how much you blame while you are my friends?'
Al-Hakami scolded his blamer with a gentle scolding, informing him that blame is incitement, and occupied the end of his verse with another meaning, with moist speech and sweet meaning. Al-Ta'i scolded his blamer with abusive wording difficult to narrate, and its rhyme is detested.
Sixth: The poet deleting from his speech what is of its completeness. Al-Kindi said:
'She looked at you with the eye of a Jaziah (gazelle sufficing with moisture)... wide-eyed, bending over a child.'
Al-Musayyab bin Alas took it and said:
'She looked at you with the eye of a Jaziah... in the shade of a solitary Sidr tree.'

The ugliness of this borrowing did not satisfy him, neither in wording nor meaning, until he added unnecessary elements, because the beauty of the gazelle's eyes has no relation to the shade of the sidr tree, nor is there anything unique in it compared to others. Al-Kindi, when describing her spring as a spring of the gazelle, which had sipped the dates from the water, mentioned that she was a Houri, then described her as tender with her child, and in her tenderness, her glance reflected caution and fear—something absent in stillness and safety. Al-Musayyab stole something and left what completes the meaning; recognize it. 

Seventh: Preference of the original speaker’s words over those who borrow from him. Muslim said: 'As for satire, your honor is subtle below it… and praise for you, as you know, is noble. Go forth, you are free in your honor; it is an honor you cherish even when humiliated.' Al-Ta’i took it and said: 'Advisors told me, and it is said, to disparage the ignorant in praise is true; in satire there is strength and elevation.' Between the two forms, the difference is far, needing no further clarification due to the obvious distinction. 

Eighth: Transferring sweet words from rhymes to harsh, awkward expressions. Al-Tallamis said: 'He lowered as bravely as if he saw … the path for his fangs,' taken by Amr ibn Sha’s as a whole and closed with an awkward rhyme: 'He lowered as bravely as if he saw … the path for his fangs.' Azamm: intensified and bit; the term is not sweet. 

Ninth: Transferring what belongs to inquiry and critique to apparent flaw or corruption. Abu al-‘Atahiya said: 'I seek refuge from the one whose heart thrilled … with Ayat al-Kursi; Ayat al-Kursi wards off devils and protects from harm, but was the heart stirred in this way?' Al-A’sha said: 'I aimed at the negligence of his eyes for his goat … hitting the heart and spleen.' Mention of the heart and chest is common in poetry about love and longing; the spleen, however, is rarely mentioned, as it has no poetic relation to sorrow or passion, making its mention inappropriate. Another said: 'When I imagined burdens, I thought them … always like soft, compacted palm branches.' This is incorrect as only palms can be compacted. The Arabs and others have poetry of this kind beyond the grasp of any researcher or selector. 

Tenth: Taking both the word and its meaning as claimed. This is the ugliest and lowest form of theft. Al-Kindi said: 'And Ans, like the boards of Iran, I spread it … on a lover like frost with scribbles,' taken word-for-word. He said: 'The worst thief among people.' Amoun said: 'Like the boards of Iran, I spread it … on a lover as if the back of a tower.' Al-Hutay’ah said: 'If it is said that my killer … is from love,' Thabit and Yazid took it beautifully. Muslim ibn al-Walid said: 'My companion says, and they hastened … and the horses lined the riders with reins. At sunrise, you desire to lead us … I said no, but the sunrise of generosity.' Abu Tammam said: 'He says of a people, my companion took … from us the night and the steps of the Mehri horses. At sunrise, you desire to lead us … I said no, but the sunrise of generosity.'

These are the forms of plagiarism (Sariqa); I have removed its veil for you, and thrown its rein to you. You will rarely find anyone who knows its divisions or seeks rain from its clouds. You only find one who, if he finds a plagiarized verse, does not know if it is of the praiseworthy or the blameworthy, and whether its poet is excused in it or blamed, so know it.
As for Tawaurd (coincidence), it is the agreement of thoughts in a verse or two verses. They only named it Tawaurd out of disdain for mentioning theft and pride against being marked by it. Alqama bin Abada said:
'Or is an old man who wept, and did not exhaust his tears... after the loved ones, on the day of separation, rewarded (mashkum)?'
Aws bin Hajar said:
'Or is an old man who wept, and did not exhaust his tears... after the loved ones, on the day of separation, excused?'
Tarafa said:
'Were it not for three that are of the youth's need... by your grandfather, I would not care when my visitors rose.'
Nuhayk said:
'Were it not for three that are of the youth's need... by your grandfather, I would not care when my buriers rose.'
Muzahim al-Uqayli said:
'Its dwellings almost say from decay... to its questioner about its people: Do not labor.'
Dabi' said:
'Its dwellings almost say from decay... to its questioner about its people: Do not labor.'
Adi bin Zaid said:
'And a blamer who woke up at night blaming me... when she exceeded in blame, I said to her: Be moderate.'
Amr bin Sha's said:
'And a blamer who woke up at night blaming me... when she exceeded in blame, I said to her: Gently.'
Aws bin Hajar said:
'A camel whose brother is her father from a hybrid [mother]... and her uncle is her maternal uncle, long-necked, fertile.'
Ka'b bin Zuhair said:
'A camel whose brother is her father from a hybrid [mother]... and her uncle is her maternal uncle, long-necked, brisk.'
Ka'b al-Ashqari said:
'They did not ride horses except after they aged... so they are heavy on their shoulders, leaning.'
Jarir said:
'They did not ride horses except after they aged... so they are heavy on their shoulders, patient.'
Verses like these in the poetry of the Arabs are more than can be counted and greater than can be exhausted. I do not count that as Tawaurd where thoughts agreed and consciences resembled, but I count it as pure theft and a raid on poetry, scattered. Ibn al-Sikkit cited the saying of Imru' al-Qais: 'Stopping at it my companions', the verse, and the saying of Tarafa in the chapter of thefts, and what he went to is the correct view. It only happens that two poets agree on a meaning and adhere to organizing it on a single rhyme, so they might coincide in some speech. Of that is what Abu al-Qasim al-Andalusi and others narrated regarding the poetry of the Maghrebis. He said: There was before Muhammad bin Abbad, the ruler of the Algarve, a slave girl with a cup in her hand serving him drink. Lightning flashed, so she was terrified by it and the cup fell from her hand. He said, improvising:
'Lightning terrified her while in her palm... was lightning from the coffee [wine], shining.
I wish I knew, while she is the sun of the forenoon... how does she get terrified by lights?'
Then he said to some of his servants: Who is at the gate of the palace among the poets? He said: Abdul Jalil bin Wahbun. So he ordered him to be brought. When he stood before him, he told him the story and recited the first verse to him and said to him: Complete it. So he composed:
'And you will never see anything more amazing than a friendly one... who, from the likes of it which she holds, is terrified.'
The likes of this can occur and is neither denied nor pushed away. Al-Andalusi narrated, saying: Muhammad bin Sharaf al-Qayrawani told me, saying: Al-Mu'izz bin Badis ordered me and ordered Hasan bin Rashiq at one time to describe the banana in poetry on the letter Ghayn. Each of us sat apart from his companion so that neither of us would know what the other was composing. When we finished the poetry, we presented it to him. What I composed was:
'Oh how wonderful is the banana and its happiness... before the chewer chews it.
It is soft so we do not perceive a touch for it... so the mouth is full of it, empty.
Equal we said is a food good... in it, or otherwise a drink easy to swallow.'
And what Ibn Rashiq composed was:
'A banana quick in its swallowing... before the chewing of the chewer.
An edible for an eater... and a drink for a swallower.
So the mouth, from softness in it... is full like empty.'

This is what is possible in Tawaurd and agreement of thoughts. Al-Qayrawani narrated, saying: Then he ordered us immediately to work on it also on the letter Dhal. We worked according to the first rule. What I composed was:
'Do you have a desire for a banana which when... we tasted it we said: How wonderful!
In it is drink and food... it shows you mote like water.
If one who found pleasure... in it died, it would be said: This for that.'
And what Ibn Rashiq composed was:
'To Allah belongs a delicious banana... the seeker of refuge seeks refuge [by God] from it.
Fruits and a drink... by which the critically ill recovers.
The mote of the eye is seen in it... as the wine shows it.'
The poetry is very weak, and we only intended by citing it to exemplify how coincidences occur, and in this example is sufficiency.

31 - As for Criticism (Naqd), in poetry it indicates the acumen of the scholar, the brightness of his sense, and the burning of his intelligence. Scholars have regarding that good sayings and useful speech, which is abundant and plentiful. We only mention a little of it and make it a guide to the much. It was said: Alqama bin Abada and Imru' al-Qais disputed in poetry, which of them was more poetic than the other. Alqama said: I accept your wife Umm Jundab as a judge between me and you. Umm Jundab said: Say poetry and describe your two horses in it on one rhyme and one meter (Rawi). Imru' al-Qais said:
'My two friends, pass by Umm Jundab with me... let us fulfill the needs of the tormented heart.'
Alqama said:
'You went from abandonment in a non-doctrine... and the length of this avoidance was not right.'
They recited the two poems to her. She said to Imru' al-Qais: Alqama is more poetic than you. He said to her: And how is that? She said: Because you said:
'So for the scolding is a blaze, and for the leg a flow [of milk/sweat/blood?]... and for the whip from him is the fall of a swift male ostrich.'
Al-Akhraj: The male ostrich, and the female is Kharja'. Al-Akhraj: Ash color, and he likened [the whip mark/color] to it. Muhdhib means fast in its running. She said: So you exhausted your horse by your scolding and extracted [effort] from him, so you tired him with your leg and whip. Alqama said:
'So he caught up with them secondarily from his rein... passing like the passing of the pouring cloud.'
So he caught up with his horse secondarily from his rein, and did not hit him with a whip nor tire him. Imru' al-Qais got angry at her and divorced her, so Alqama married her and was named Al-Fahl (The Stallion) for his distinction over the rest of the poets like the distinction of the stallion over the rest of the camels. Al-Asma'i recited the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'Many a shooter from Banu Thu'al... taking out his palms (Zandayhi) from his covers.'
He said: Did he not know that the hunter is more intense in stealth than to show anything of himself! Then he said: So 'his palms' (Kaffayhi), if it must be, is more correct. So the narrators left 'his forearms' (Zandayhi) and narrated 'his palms' (Kaffayhi) despite what is in it. It was said: A red leather dome used to be set up for Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani in the market of Ukaz, and poets would come to him and present their poetry to him. The first to recite to him was Al-A'sha Maymun bin Qais, then Hassan bin Thabit al-Ansari recited his saying:
'We have the white bowls shining in the forenoon... and our swords drip blood from bravery.
We begot Banu al-Anqa' and the two sons of Muharriq... so how noble are we as uncles, and how noble are we as sons.'
Al-Nabigha said to him: You are a poet, but you diminished your bowls and your swords, and boasted of whom you begot and did not boast of who begot you. This is the majestic criticism indicated by the purity of Al-Nabigha's speech. The meaning is that he said to him: You diminished your swords, and 'Asyaf' is a plural of paucity (few number), and the plural of multitude is 'Suyuf'. And 'Jafanat' is for paucity, and the multitude is 'Jifan'. He said: You boasted of whom you begot; because he left boasting of his fathers and boasted of whom his women begot. It was said in a narration not trusted: That he said to him: And you said: 'We have the white (Ghurr) bowls', and Ghurra is a spot of whiteness in the bowl. If you had said: 'We have the white (Bid) bowls', it would have been better due to the abundance of grease on them. And if you had said: 'Shining in the darkness (Duja)', it would have been more eloquent. And if you had said: 'And our swords run (Yajrina)', it would have been more eloquent than 'drip (Yaqturna)' because running is greater than dripping. I say that this addition has objections against it. The correct is what Al-Nabigha said first. Ibn Abbad Abu al-Qasim, may Allah have mercy on him and be pleased with him, mentioned that Abu al-Fadl bin al-Amid used to exceed the criticism of verses to the criticism of letters and words, and would not be satisfied with refining the meaning and wording until he demanded the beautification of the rhyme and meter. He said: I recited one day in his presence the poem of Abu Tammam which begins:
'I witnessed, your dwellings have become desolate after me... and worn out as the stripes of a cloak wore out.'

Until I reached his saying:
'Generous, whenever I praise him, I praise him and mankind... are with me, and whenever I blame him, I blame him alone.'
He said: Do you know a fault in this verse? I said: Yes, he countered praise with blame, so he did not fulfill the correspondence its due, as the due of praise is to be countered with satire and dispraise. He said: I intended other than this. I said: I do not know. He said: One of the things needed in poetry is the soundness of the letters of the word from heaviness. This repetition in 'amdahuhu, amdahhu' (I praise him, I praise him), with the combination of Ha' (heavy H) and Ha' (soft H) twice, and they are guttural letters, is outside the limit of moderation, repelling with all repulsion. I said: This is not perceived except by one to whom the aspects of knowledge have submitted and whose nature has raised him to their peaks. It was said: Al-Asma'i heard the saying of Al-A'sha:
'As if her walk from the house of her neighbor... is the passing of a cloud, neither slow nor hasty.'
He said: He made her frequently going out and entering (Kharraja Wallaja). Why did he not say as the other said:
'And her neighbors honor her so they visit her... and she makes excuses for not coming to them, so she is excused.'
I say: Criticism of poetry is a craft that no one knows truly except one who has been pushed into the straits of poetry and swallowed the chokings of its difficulty upon him, and knew how to storm its abysses and throw himself into it. Abu al-Abbas Muhammad bin Yazid al-Mubarrad said: Umara bin Aqil bin Bilal bin Jarir said to me: Marwan bin Abi Hafsa said to me: Al-Ma'mun has no insight into poetry. I said to him: And how is that, when we recite to him the beginning of the verse and he anticipates us to its end, having not heard it before? He said: I said a good poem about him, but he did not shake for it. He said: I said to him: And what did you say about him? He recited to me:
'The Imam of Guidance, Al-Ma'mun, has become busy... with religion, and people are busy with the world.'
He said: I said to him: You did nothing. You did no more than making him an old woman in her prayer niche with her rosary in her hand. Who will undertake the matter of the world if the Caliph is busy from it, while he is the one burdened with its matter? Why did you not say as your uncle Jarir said about Abdul Aziz bin al-Walid bin Abdul Malik:
'So neither is he in the world wasting his share... nor does the offer of the world distract him from religion.'
This is good criticism. Abu Uthman al-Jahiz narrated, saying: I sought the knowledge of poetry at Al-Asma'i's, but found him knowing only its strange words. I returned to Al-Akhfash, but found him mastering only its grammar. I turned to Abu Ubayda, but saw him penetrating only in what connected to news and related to days (battles) and lineages. I did not obtain what I wanted except at the literary scribes; like Al-Hasan bin Wahb and Muhammad bin Abdul Malik al-Zayyat. To Allah is the goodness of Abu Uthman! He dove into the secret of poetry and extracted what is more subtle than magic. A poet is judged over another by one verse, and a verse is preferred over another by one word. Do you not see the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'Stopping at it my companions, their mounts over me... saying: Do not perish of sorrow and beautify yourself (tajammal).'
And the saying of Tarafa the verse in its entirety, then he ended it with his saying: 'and have endurance (tajallad).' They are both excellent poets, and we assumed they coincided, and did not judge Tarafa with theft. We were invited to judge between them, and prefer one of the two verses over the other, and there is no difference in them except 'tajammul' and 'tajallud'. From good criticism is preferring 'tajammul' over 'tajallud', and ruling the verse for its owner, because 'tajammul' is showing improvement from strength and a continuous material of capability. And 'tajallud' is showing improvement from weakness, and a continuous material of inability. Between the two words is a far distance. If we were invited to judge between Laqit bin Zurara and who followed his path in his saying:
'A youth who buys good praise with his wealth... so it remains, and you did not keep the likes of praiseworthy deeds.'
And the saying of Al-Hakami:
'A youth who buys good praise with his wealth... and knows that the circles (of fortune) turn.'
And the saying of the other:
'A youth who buys good praise with his wealth... when the ash-colored year, its rain is little.'

Criticism would necessitate judging entitlement to preference for the author of the last verse. That is because Laqit bin Zurara ended his verse with a good proverb, and Abu Nuwas ended his verse with confirming generosity, and its meaning: That the praised one buys praise with his money knowing that he might become poor, or need others, as others needed him. As for the other, he mentioned that he gives his money and buys praise with it in the difficult time when a human must preserve his money due to the intense need for it. If he gives it in such a difficult time and spends it in days of drought and famine, how would he be in a time of fertility and abundance of good and provision? By such a trait, Hatim bin Abdullah al-Ta'i was judged with generosity. Hatim was triumphant: if he fought he conquered, if asked he gave, if he took booty he let it be plundered, if he captured he released, and if he became wealthy he spent. He had sworn by Allah Almighty not to kill the only son of his mother. Muhammad bin Habib narrated from Musa al-Ahwal from Al-Haytham from Malhan, the nephew of Mawiya wife of Hatim, from his aunt Mawiya, she said: A year [of drought] befell the people that took away the camel and the cloven-hoofed (sheep/goats). We spent a night in extreme hunger and we owned nothing. Hatim took Adi and I took Saffana; we distracted them until they slept. Then Hatim began distracting me with talk so I would sleep. I pitied him for the fatigue he was in, so I refrained from his speech and pretended to him that I had slept so he would sleep. He looked from the slit of the tent, and behold a person approaching. He raised his head and behold a woman saying: 'O Abu Saffana, I came to you from hungry children.' He jumped up quickly and said: 'Bring them to me, for by Allah I will satisfy them.' When she brought them, while I was thinking about what he wanted to do, he stood hurriedly to his horse—and he owned nothing else—slaughtered it, roasted it, and fed them. Then he said: 'By Allah, this indeed is meanness; how can you eat while the people of the camp are in a state like yours?' He began going to the camp, tent by tent, saying: 'Come to the fire.' A number gathered around him and left nothing of it, while he was wrapped in his cloak sitting aside. By Allah, he did not taste a morsel of it. This, by Allah, is pure generosity and sheer munificence. If his generosity in such a state was like this, how would it be in other states? This is the end of the first chapter. Perhaps the looker into it finds its sections long and its prolixity great, especially since we stipulated at its beginning brevity and promised to avoid excess. If the looker into it knew what we left behind us and cast behind our backs of strange meanings and wondrous poems, he would know the place of brevity and the fulfillment of what we promised of restriction. This is with turning away from much of the poetry of the moderns and the proficient ancients. And Allah is the Granter of success to what is right.

**Chapter Two**
**On What is Permissible for the Poet to Use and What is Not**
**And What the Correctness of Speech is Realized By and Permitted**

What is permissible for the Muwallad (post-classical/modern) poet to use in his poetry of necessity (Darura) is all that the Arabs used in their poems of necessities, except what I exclude for you and clarify to you. The Muwallad, in the necessities of his poetry and committing its difficulties, is more excused than the Arab who speaks in his language by his nature. As for what is not permissible for the Muwallad to use, and is not tolerated in committing, it is all that came from the Arabs as solecism (Lahn) which Arabic does not swallow and its people do not permit, whether in the middle of the verse or in its rhyme. For solecism is not permissible to emulate, nor to descend into its branches. Of that is the solecism they called 'Jarr 'ala al-Mujawara' (Genitive by Proximity). The poet said:
'So O assembly of Arabs, if your drinking is permissible... then do not drink what a rider performed Hajj for Allah (Hajja lillahi rakibin).'
'A drink for Ghazwan the wicked, for he... forbids you from it with oaths of a liar (bi-aymani kadhibin).'
This is an ugly solecism, and its correct form is: 'ma hajja lillahi rakibun' (what a rider performed Hajj for Allah [nominative]). Another said:
'I circle it seeing none other than it... as the monk circled the church (kama tafa bil-bay'ati al-rahibi).'
He made 'Al-Rahib' (monk) genitive by proximity, which is an ugly solecism, and its correct form is: 'kama tafa bil-bay'ati al-rahibu' (as the monk circled the church [nominative]). Another said:
'Like the weaving of the spider, the weak (Al-murmali).'
Its correct form is 'Al-murmali' (weak/loose - [in context maybe Al-murhala? or Al-murmali genitive? Need context for grammatical case. Usually spider web described as wahin/weak. If Al-murmal describes nasj (weaving - accusative/nominative) it should match. If genitive, maybe matching Ankabut? Text says Lahn, implies incorrect case]). As for the saying of the other:
'As if Thabir (mountain) in the foreparts of its rain... is a chief of people in a striped garment wrapped (muzammali).'
It has a face mentioned by Abu al-Fath, which is that he intended 'muzammalin fihi' (wrapped in it), so he deleted the preposition, so the pronoun rose and became hidden in the passive participle. Much of this has appeared, like the saying of the other:

'As if she struck before her eyes... cotton with the tightness of strings ginned (mahlu ji).'
Its correct form is 'mahlujan' (accusative). All of that, they only brought it based on what was narrated from the Arabs of their saying: 'Hadha juhru dabbin kharibin' (This is the hole of a lizard, ruined [genitive]), while 'ruined' is not an attribute of the lizard. Al-Khalil bin Ahmad said: Their saying 'Hadha juhru dabbin kharibin' was only narrated from them by way of mistake. The proof of that is that when they used the dual, they only said 'juhra dabbin kharibani' (two holes of a lizard, ruined [nominative/dual]), because the mistake here becomes clear. It only occurred in the singular due to the gathering of the hole and the lizard in singularity. Likewise, if they used the plural, the mistake disappears, like your saying: 'Hadhihi juhratu dibabin kharibatun' (These are holes of lizards, ruined [nominative]). The investigators among the people of knowledge do not permit working according to proximity. We are not making one saying prevail over another, nor do we have a purpose in that. However, the Muwallad poet is not permitted to work according to proximity. This was not narrated for any of the proficient Muwallads, nor did the scholars of poetry permit it for them, whether the Arabs were correct in it or mistaken. The intent is that it is prohibited for the Muwallads. 
Among what is not permissible for the Muwallads to use is what the Arabs used of advancing and delaying (Ta'qim wa Ta'khir) and separation (Fasl) for which there is no justification. It is not permissible for the Muwallad to follow it or emulate it, for it is a repugnant solecism, like the saying of the poet:
'She has the two eyes of a wild cow (hawra'), bedewed a thicket... from the wild beasts, its arar plants do not cease grazing.'
He intended: She has the two eyes of a wild cow (hawra') from the wild beasts, grazing a thicket whose arar plants are bedewed, which does not cease [grazing]. Another said:
'Indeed—and doubt is clear to me, trouble—... with the imminence of their separation, a shrike shouting.'
He intended: Indeed, a shrike shouting with the imminence of their separation has become clear to me, and doubt is trouble. Another said:
'So it became after the line of its joy... as if a pen were a wasteland, its traces.'
He intended: So it became a wasteland after its joy, as if a pen lined its traces. Such is frequent. You can see what is in these verses of separations and advancing and delaying. The like of this is not permissible for the early Bedouins, let alone the later Muwallads. It is not permissible for anyone to take it as a norm to work upon. 
Among what is not permissible for the Muwallads to emulate or work upon, because it is a gross solecism, is Iqwa' in the rhyme. That is for the poet to make a verse nominative (Marfu') and a verse genitive (Majrur), like the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'Is there from the family of Mayya a departer or an early goer (mughtadi)... hasty, with provision or without provision (muzawwadi)?
The hot summer winds claimed that our journey is tomorrow... and of that the black raven informed us (al-aswadu).'
Oh wonder, how did that escape Al-Nabigha despite his good criticism of poetry, soundness of taste, and perception of the obscure secrets of it? You have known what he took from Hassan bin Thabit of what thoughts are bewildered in. When he was alerted to the place of the error, it did not reach his understanding nor did he pay attention to it until a singing girl sang it while he was present. When she prolonged 'khabbarana al-ghurabu al-aswadu', and the Damma in 'Al-Aswad' after the Dal became clear, he realized that and knew it was Iqwa', so he changed it and said: 'wa bi-dhaka tan'abu al-ghurabi al-aswadi' (and of that is the croaking of the black raven). And like the saying of Muzarrid bin Dirar from verses:
'Did Al-Tha'la' not know—may her milk not flow... Fazara—that the right to the guest is obligatory (wajibu)?'
And from it:
'I looked askance and peered at him so I saw him... so I said to him: Are you Zaid of the Rabbits (al-aranibi)?'
And like the saying of Hassan bin Thabit:
'There is no harm in the people in terms of height and size... the body of mules and the dreams of sparrows (al-asafiri).
As if they are hollow reeds, their bottoms... pierced, in which the whirlwinds blew (al-a'asiru).'
Nasb (accusative) does not occur with Jarr (genitive) nor with Raf' (nominative) in Iqwa'. By my life, all of it is rejected solecism, and nothing of that was narrated from them. Raf' and Jarr only gather due to the closeness of each one to the other. And because Waw is assimilated into Ya', and they are permissible in the Ridf (letter before Rawi) in one poem. When Waw became close to Ya' this closeness, they imagined its permissibility with it, and that is a mistake and error. The Muqayyad (bound rhyme) has no Majra (vowel of the Rawi), meaning the movement of the Rawi letter; it is only for the Mutlaq (released rhyme). I think that whoever of the Arabs committed Iqwa' did not recite poetry as Mutlaq, but recited it as Muqayyad and paused at its rhyme, like the saying of Durayd bin al-Simma:
'I looked at him while the spears were seizing him... like the falling of weaver's shuttles on the stretched fabric (al-mumaddad - pause).
So I frightened the people away from him until they scattered... and until the intense black color overcame me (aswad - pause).'

In summary, it is an excuse not bad. Some of our Sheikhs narrated to me, raising it to Abu Sa'id al-Sirafi, he said: I attended the assembly of Abu Bakr bin Duraid, and I had not seen him before that. I sat at the tail of the assembly. One of the attendees recited two verses attributed to Adam, peace be upon him, when his son Cain killed his brother Abel, which are:
'The lands changed and who is on them... so the face of the earth is dusty, ugly (qabihu).
Every possessor of beauty and goodness changed... and the cheerfulness of the beautiful face decreased (al-malihu).'
Abu Bakr said: 'This is poetry said at the beginning of the world and Iqwa' occurred in it.' I said: 'It has a face that removes it from Iqwa'.' He said: 'What is it?' I said: 'Deleting the Tanwin from "bashashata" due to the meeting of two sakin (silent letters), making it accusative for specification (Tamyiz/Tafsir), and making "al-wajhu" nominative by assigning "qalla" to it. If the Tanwin were moved due to the meeting of two sakins, it would be: "wa qalla bashashatan al-wajhu al-malihu".' When he heard this, he said: 'Rise.' He raised me until he seated me by his side. 
Among what is not permissible for Muwallads to use, and no license was narrated for anyone in the like of it: Ikfa'. It is the difference of the Rawi letter. An example of that is the saying of the Rajiz:
'My son, indeed righteousness is an easy thing... the good speech and the little food (al-tu'ayyim - Mim).'
And the saying of another:
'If a thief comes to me, I am a thief (lissu - Sad)... wolf-colored like the wolf when he prowls (ya'tassu - Sin).
My driving is my singing and my whistling is the hiss (al-nassu - Sin).'
Among what is not permissible for the Muwallad to use is Ita': It is that the poet rhymes with a word in a verse, then brings it in another verse close to the first. If the distance between the two verses is ten verses or more, the sin is forgiven, the defect covered, and it moves from prohibited to disliked. If one of the two rhymes is definite and the other indefinite, the dislike is removed and it is closer to permissibility than prohibition. The Arabs have committed Ita' frequently. Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani said:
'Or I place the house in a dumb, dark land... restricting the wild ass, the night traveler does not travel in it (al-sari).'
Then he said after a few verses:
'He does not lower the sound from a land he visited... nor does the night traveler go astray upon his lamp (al-sari).'
Ibn Muqbil said:
'Or like the shaking of a Rudayni spear handled by... the hands of merchants, so they increased its shaft in softness (lina).'
Then he said after verses:
'I disputed their minds with my mind with a brief... of conversations until they increased me in softness (lina).'
Among what is not permissible for the Muwallad to use is Sinad: It is the difference of every movement before the Rawi letter, like the saying of Amr bin al-Ahtam al-Taghlibi:
'Did you not see that Taghlib are people of might... mountains of strongholds not ascended (yurtaqayna - Fatha).
We drank from the blood of Banu Sulaym... with the tips of spears until we quenched (rawina - Kasra).'
The Fatha of the Qaf and the Kasra of the Waw is Sinad, not permissible, because one of the two Hadhws (vowel before Ridf) follows the Ridf and the other opposes it. Al-Khalil permitted Damma with Kasra and forbade Damma with Fatha. If there is Damma or Kasra with Fatha, it is Sinad. As for what he permitted, it is like the saying of Tarafa:
'A phantom kept the eye sleepless, it did not rest (yaqir - Kasra)... He loathed, while the riders were in the desert of Yusur (yusur - Damma).'
This is Damma with Kasra, and it is good. As for what he forbade and mentioned as Sinad, it is like the saying of Ru'ba:
'And dark of depths, empty of the crossing place (al-mukhtaraq - Fatha).'
Then he said:
'He united scattered ones, not being the foolish shepherd (al-hamiq - Kasra).'
He combined Fatha and Kasra. Then he said:
'Compact, strong-backed, huge, youthful camel (funuq - Damma).'
He brought Damma with Fatha and Kasra, and it is an ugly Sinad; the like of it is not permissible to use. Similar to it in ugliness and combining Kasra, Fatha, and Damma is the saying of Al-A'sha:
'Your raiding with horses the land of the enemy... so today from a raid you did not recoil (takhim - Kasra).
And their army looks at the morning... and its young ones are like the rejected of date pits (al-'ajam - Fatha).
Sitting with what was of armor... and they are standing chewing the bridles (al-lujum - Damma).'
Abu Amr al-Jarmi narrated that Al-Akhfash did not consider that Sinad and said: 'That has come frequently from the eloquent Arabs.' The reliance is on what Al-Khalil said, nothing else. Al-Khalil permitted the coming of Ya' with Waw in like 'mashib' and 'khutub', and 'amir' and 'wu'ur'. If you add a Ridf to a verse and leave another [without Ridf], it is Sinad and a defect not to be woven upon its loom, like the saying of the poet:
'If you are sending someone for a need... then send a wise man and do not advise him (tushi-hi).'

'And if a door of a matter is twisted against you... then consult an intelligent man and do not disobey him (ta'si-hi).'
The Waw in 'tushi-hi' is a Ridf, and the Sad is the Rawi letter, and the second verse does not have a Ridf (is not Murdaf). This is Sinad, and it is an ugly defect that rarely occurred. Al-Khalil bin Ahmad said: I arranged the Bayt (verse) of poetry like the arrangement of the Bayt (house) of hair (tent), meaning the tent. He said: So I named Iqwa' what came of nominative in poetry and genitive on one rhyme. I only named it Iqwa' for its contrariety, because the Arabs say: 'Aqwa al-fatilu' (The twister made strong/different strands) if a strand of the rope comes differing from the rest of the strands. He said: And I named the change of what is before the Rawi letter Sinad; from the supporting (Musanada) of a verse to a verse if each of them is thrown upon its companion, not being even like this. He said: And I named Ikfa' what the letter of its Rawi was disturbed, so it came once Nun, once Mim, and once Lam. The Arabs do that due to the closeness of the exit of Mim from Nun, like his saying:
'Daughters of a trampler on the cheek of the night (al-layl - Lam)... they do not complain of pain as long as they are selected (anqayn - Nun).'
Taken from their saying: 'Bayt Mukfa'' (An overturned/slanted tent) if its flaps which are at its rear differ. Al-Kifa': The flap at the rear of the tent. Ita' is repeating the rhyme twice, like his saying:
'And disgraces you, O son of the blacksmith, the days of Darim... and Amr bin Amr when he called O family of Darim.'
He stepped (awta'a) a rhyme upon a rhyme, he named it Ita'. As for Tadmin, it is that the verse is built on speech whose meaning is in a verse following it, requiring it. Like the saying of the poet:
'And Sa'd, so ask them, and Al-Rabab... and ask Hawazin about us if.
We met them, how rise above them... cutting swords splitting helmets and heads.'
All these defects are not permissible for the Muwallads to commit because they have known their ugliness, and witnessed in others their sting and scorch, while the Bedouin did not pay attention to them. Among what is not permissible for the Muwallad to use is breaking the Nun of the plural in like the saying of Jarir:
'A thicket from Urayna is not of us... I am innocent to Urayna from a thicket (Arini - Kasra).
We knew Ja'far and Banu Ubayd... and we denied others, rabble (Akharini - Kasra).'
This is solecism, and its correct form is 'Akharina', with open Nun. Suhaym bin Wathil said:
'I excused the old camels if they wagered me... so what is my concern and the concern of the two-year-old camels (Ibnay Labuni - Kasra).
And what do the poets know of me... when I have passed the head of forty (Al-Arba'ini - Kasra).'
The correct is opening the Nun of Al-Arba'in. Al-Farazdaq said addressing Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf when the death announcement of his brother Muhammad came to him on the day his son Muhammad died:
'I am weeping for the two sons of Yusuf in anxiety... and the like of their loss for religion makes me weep.
No living nor dead blocked their place... except the Caliphs after the Prophets (Al-Nabiyyini - Kasra).'
He broke the Nun of Al-Nabiyyin, and the correct is opening it. Al-Mubarrad has speech on that. All this is not permissible for the Muwallad to emulate or use as argument. For that Al-Sayyid al-Himyari says:
'Indeed my tongue is an instrument that does not betray me... and indeed I am precise in what I bring of the matter.
I weave and do not commit Iqwa' and am not making solecisms... and how many a sayer of poetry commits Iqwa' and solecism.'
Adi bin al-Riqa' said:
'And a poem I spent the night gathering... until I straightened its inclination and its Sinad.
The look of the straightener at the nodes of his spear... until his straightening tool rectifies its bend.'
Abu Bakr al-Suli recited, he said: Awn bin Muhammad al-Kindi recited to me for some of them, and was witty:
'Indeed there was in your eyes, O Amr, a distraction... and a nose like the sheath of the old camel, from what you follow.
You followed a solecism in the speech of a decorating poet... while your face is built on solecism entirely.
So your eyes are Iqwa', your nose is Mukfa'... and your face is Ita', so you are the patched one.'
It is narrated: 'Your ears are Iqwa', your nose is Mukfa'... and your eyes are Ita', so you are the patched one.'
Ibn Jurayj said about Sawwar bin Abi Shura'a:
'And mentioning you in poetry is like Sinad... and Kharm and Khazm or like the impossible.
And Ita' of poetry and its Ikfa'... and its Iqwa' without mentioning the vile.
Poetry is not faulted by a defect belonging to it... like being afflicted by men of baseness.
Satire is made available for the satirist of satire... a chronic disease for a chronic disease.'
We have cited these verses for the position of finding their defects ugly and likening the states of the satirized to them, confirming their ugliness in the soul and inciting avoiding them to remove ambiguity. What is permissible for the Muwallad poet to commit of necessity in his poetry is to decline (make Munfarif) what is indeclinable (Ghayr Munsarif), because the origin of all nouns is declension (Sarf). Causes only occurred to them preventing them from declension. If the poet declines what is indeclinable, he has returned it to its origin. The poet said:
'Da'd did not wrap herself with the surplus of her waist-wrapper... nor was Da'd fed with milking vessels (al-'ulabi).'
Al-'ulab is plural of 'ulba, which is a huge wooden cup used for milking. He declined Da'd and left declension in one verse. As for the poet coming to what is declinable and leaving its declension, it is not permissible because it is taking the thing out of its origin, and taking things out of their origins corrupts the standards of speech in them. Al-Akhfash argued for the permissibility of that with the saying of Al-Abbas bin Mirdas al-Sulami, which is:
'Neither Hisn nor Habis were... surpassing Mirdas (Mirdasa - non-declined) in an assembly.'
He left the declension of Mirdas, which is a declinable name. Abu Ali said: This is not to be used as a standard. I say: This is not permissible to do because it is an ugly solecism. Among what is permissible for the Muwallad poet to use by necessity is shortening the extended (Mamdud), but extending the shortened (Maqsur) is not permissible for him because it is a departure from the origin. As for shortening the extended, it is returning the thing to its origin. The poet said:
'My eye wept and its weeping (Bukaha - shortened) was right for it... and weeping (Al-Buka'u - extended) and wailing do not avail.'
He shortened 'Buka' and extended it in one verse. Among what is not permissible to use as proof for extending the shortened, because it is contrary to the original placement agreed upon by scholars, is the saying of Al-Farazdaq:
'O Abu Hadir, whoever fornicates, his fornication (Zina'uhu - extended) appears... and whoever drinks the wine becomes intoxicated.'
He extended 'Zina', which is extended in the dialect of the people of Nejd, and shortening is for the people of Hijaz, which is the language of the Quran and reliance is upon it. The reason of whoever extended Zina is that he made it an action from two, like your saying 'Ramaytuhu Rima'an' (I shot at him shooting) and 'Zanaytuhu Zina'an'. Whoever shortened it went to the view that the action is from one of them. In summary, it is transmitted, said, and others are not measured upon it. Zina in shortening is written with Ya' because it is from: Zana Yazni. As for the saying of the other:
'He who enriched you will enrich me from me... so no poverty lasts nor riches (Ghina'u - extended).'
The correct narration is that its beginning is open (Fatha), because the meaning of Ghina (richness) and Ghana' (sufficiency/avail) is one. Poetry, if forced to extend the shortened, changes its beginning and directs it to what is permissible to use, like the saying of the Rajiz:
'And the recurring of nights and changing of conditions... wears out man the wearing out (Bala' - extended) of the shirt.'
When he opened the Ba' of Bila, the extension became permissible for him. The like of this is many. It is permissible for the poet to suffice with Damma instead of Waw by necessity, like the saying of the poet:
'While he was buying his saddle, a sayer said... To whom belongs a camel loose of sides, submissive?'
The origin was: 'Fa-bayna huwa' (While he), so when he sufficed with Damma, he deleted the Waw. It is permissible for the Muwallad poet to return the defective noun (Manqus) to its origin in inflection by necessity, so he puts Damma on the Ya' in nominative and Kasra in genitive, as it is opened in accusative, because Damma and Kasra are intended and estimated in the Ya' even if they fell. So he says in 'Qadin' (judge) in the state of nominative 'Qadiyun' and in the state of genitive 'Qadiyin', without Hamza. Likewise in 'Jawari' and 'Ghawani'. The poet said:
'You see him, having escaped the shooters, as if he is... in front of the dogs, inclined of cheek (Musghiyu - nominative), earless.'
He put Damma on the Ya' of Musghi. Ubaydullah bin Qais al-Ruqayyat said:
'May Allah not bless the beautiful women (Al-Ghawaniyi - genitive), do they... become morning except having a demand?'
He put Kasra on the Ya' in Al-Ghawani. Another said:
'I have not seen, nor do I see in my duration... like maidens (Ka-jawariyin - genitive) playing in the desert.'
He used two necessities: one is putting Kasra on the Ya', and the other is declining what is indeclinable. As for the saying of Al-Farazdaq:
'If Abdullah was a client (Mawlan) I would have satirized him... but Abdullah is a client of clients (Mawaliya).'
Its estimation is that he paused on the Ya' according to the school of those Arabs who pause on it. When the noun was completed by the return of its Lam, it became prevented from declension then because its weight became with the Ya' 'Mafa'il' after it was 'Mafa'in'. When he was forced to its movement to establish the meter, he opened it in the place of genitive as 'Masajida' is opened. As for the saying of the Rajiz:
'He drives eight (Thamani - indeclinable form acting as object? or genitive?) fond of their milk camels.'

'Satire is available to the satirist of satire... a chronic disease for a chronic disease.' We have cited these verses to point out the ugliness of their flaws and to liken the conditions of the satirized person to them, emphasizing their ugliness to the soul and inciting avoidance of them to remove ambiguity. Among the poetic necessities permissible for the Muwallad (post-classical) poet to commit in his poetry is to decline what is indeclinable (treat a diptote as a triptote), because the root of all nouns is declinability (triptote). Causes only arose that prevented them from declension; so if the poet declines the indeclinable, he has returned it to its root. The poet said: 'Da'd did not wrap herself with the surplus of her waist-wrapper... and Da'd was not fed from the wooden bowls.' 'Al-'Ulab' is the plural of 'Ulbah', which is a large wooden bowl used for milking. He declined 'Da'd' and left the declension in one verse. However, for a poet to take a declinable noun and prevent its declension (treat a triptote as a diptote), this is not permissible because it is removing a thing from its root, and removing things from their roots corrupts the standards of speech regarding them. Al-Akhfash argued for the permissibility of this using the verse of Al-Abbas ibn Mirdas al-Sulami, which is: 'Neither a fortress nor a container... surpasses Mirdas in an assembly.' He prevented the declension of 'Mirdas' even though it is a declinable name. Abu Ali said: 'This cannot be used as a standard.' I say: This action is not permissible because it is an ugly grammatical error. Among what is permissible for the Muwallad poet to use as a necessity is shortening the extended noun (Mamdud), but he may not lengthen the shortened noun (Maqsur) because that is a departure from the root, whereas shortening the extended is returning the thing to its root. The poet said: 'My eye wept and its weeping (buka'aha - shortened) was its right... but weeping (al-buka' - extended) and wailing do not avail.' He shortened 'al-buka' and extended it in a single verse. Among what cannot be used as proof for extending the shortened noun—because it is contrary to the root of coinage upon which scholars agreed—is the saying of Al-Farazdaq: 'O Abu Hadir, whoever commits fornication (yazni), his fornication (zina'uhu) appears... and whoever drinks wine (al-khurtum) becomes intoxicated.' He extended 'al-zina', which is extended in the dialect of the people of Najd, but shortening it is the dialect of the people of Hijaz, which is the language of the Quran and the one relied upon. The reason for the one who extends 'al-zina' is that he made it a verb from two parties, like saying 'ramaytuhu rima'an' (I shot at him) and 'zanaytuhu zina'an', while the one who shortens it holds that the action is from one of them. In summary, it is transmitted and spoken, but others are not analogized to it. 'Al-Zina' in the shortened form is written with a 'Ya' because it comes from: 'zana yazni'. As for the saying of the other: 'The One who enriched you will enrich me from you... so neither poverty endures nor wealth (ghina'u).' The correct narration is that its beginning is open (fat-ha), because the meaning of 'al-ghina' (wealth) and 'al-ghana'' (sufficiency) is one. If poetry is compelled to extend a shortened noun, it changes its beginning and directs it to what is permissible to use, like the saying of the Rajiz poet: 'The passing of nights and the changing of conditions... wears a man out like the wearing (bala') of a shirt.' When he opened the 'Ba' of 'al-bila', the extension became permissible for him. Cases like this are many. It is permissible for the poet to suffice with the Damma (u-vowel) instead of the Waw out of necessity, as the poet said: 'So while he (baynahu) was selling his saddle, a sayer said... "To whom belongs a camel, loose in the sides, submissive?"' The original was: 'fa-bayna huwa' (while he), so when he sufficed with the Damma, he deleted the Waw. It is permissible for the Muwallad poet to return the defective noun (Manqus) to its root in declension out of necessity, so he marks the 'Ya' with a Damma in the nominative case and with a Kasra in the genitive case, just as it is marked with a Fatha in the accusative, because the Damma and Kasra are intended and implied in the 'Ya' even if they are dropped. So he says regarding 'Qadin' (a judge) in the nominative state 'Qadiyun' and in the genitive state 'Qadiyin', without a Hamza, and likewise in 'Jawari' and 'Ghawani'. The poet said: 'You see him, having outstripped the archers, as if he is... in front of the dogs, inclined (musghiyu) of cheek, earless.' He marked the 'Ya' of 'musghi' with a Damma. And Ubayd Allah ibn Qays al-Ruqayyat said: 'May Allah not bless the beauties (al-ghawani), do... they wake up except that they have a requirement?' He marked the 'Ya' in 'al-ghawani' with a Kasra. Another said: 'I have not seen, nor do I see in my duration... like maidens (jawariyin) playing in the desert.' He used two necessities: one is marking the 'Ya' with a Kasra, and the other is declining what is indeclinable. As for the saying of Al-Farazdaq: 'If Abdullah were a client (Mawla) I would have satirized him... but Abdullah is a client of clients (Mawla Mawaliya).' The estimation is that he paused upon the 'Ya' according to the school of those Arabs who pause upon it. When the noun was completed by the return of its 'Lam' (last radical), it was then prevented from declension because its weight with the 'Ya' became 'Mafa'il' after it was 'Mafa'in'. So when he was compelled to its vowel to establish the meter, he marked it with a Fatha in the place of the genitive, just as 'Masajida' is marked with a Fatha. As for the saying of the Rajiz: 'He drives eight (thamani) fond of their milch-camels...'

The poet likened 'Thamani' (eight) to 'Jawarin' (maidens) in wording not meaning, so he did not decline it. It is permissible for the Muwallad to make the Ya' silent in the state of accusative, thus attaching the accusative to the nominative and genitive, just as it was permissible for him to move the Ya' in the state of nominative and genitive, attaching the nominative and genitive to the accusative. Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad said: This is one of the best necessities because they likened the Ya' to the Alif, meaning that if they make it silent in the three states, the defective noun (Manqus) runs the course of the shortened noun (Maqsur), so the Ya' becomes like the Alif; since the Alif is silent in all its states. The poet said:
'Gently, our cousins, gently, our masters (Mawalina)... do not dig up between us what was buried.'
He made the Ya' silent in 'Mawalina' while it is in the place of accusative. Another said:
'As if their hands on the smooth, flat plain... are hands of maidens (Aydi Jawarin) exchanging silver.'
He made the Ya' silent in 'Aydiyahunna' while it is in the place of accusative, and made it silent in 'Aydi' while it is in the place of nominative. Al-Hutay'ah said:
'O house of Hind, effaced except its tripod stones (Athafiha).'
Al-Farazdaq said:
'Turning a head that was not a master's head... and an eye of his, cross-eyed (Hawla'), whose defects are apparent (Badin).'
He intended 'Badiyan' (appearing - accusative) its defects, so he made the Ya' silent and deleted it due to the meeting of two sakins. It is possible in the saying of the other mentioned earlier:
'Yahdu thamani mula'an bi-liqahiha'
That the Ya' is made silent then deleted because of Tanwin, so it would be carried on this necessity, so you say: 'Yahdu thamanin' (driving eight).
Among what is permissible for the Muwallad poet to use is establishing the Waw and Ya' in like 'lam yaghzu' and 'lam yarmi', so he says at necessity: 'lam yaghzuwa' and 'lam yarmiya', as if he made the Waw and Ya' silent after the obligation of movement for them. The poet said:
'Did it not come to you (Ya'tika), while news grows... of what the milk camels of Banu Ziyad met?'
Its origin was: 'Ya'tiyuka', so he deleted the Damma and made the Ya' silent as I informed you. Among what is permissible to use, and is very common in usage, is deleting the Tanwin due to the meeting of two sakins. Of that is the saying of the poet:
'Humayd, he whose house is Amajju... the brother of wine, the possessor of gray hair, the bald.'
He should have said 'Humaydun', so he dropped the Tanwin. Al-Amaj is heat and thirst, and Amaj is a place. Another said:
'You will find me dutiful to the Emir... and with the spear a thruster, an attacker.
If Ghutayf al-Sulami flees.'
He should have said: 'Idha Ghutayfun', so he deleted the Tanwin due to the meeting of two sakins. Ubaydullah bin Qais al-Ruqayyat said:
'How is my sleep on the bed when... a widespread raid has not included Sham.
Distracting the old man from his sons and revealing... the ankles (Hidham) of the virgin wife.'
He intended: And the virgin wife reveals the ankles. Al-Khidam is the anklet, meaning she lifts her dress to flee. The poet said:
'So I found him not seeking favor... nor remembering Allah (Dhakira Allaha) except a little.'
Deleting the Tanwin from 'Dhakir' was good, and he put 'Allah' in accusative by it to agree with the conjoined word in indefiniteness. He said:
'And Hatim al-Ta'i, giver of hundreds (Wahhabu al-mi'iy).'
It was obligatory to say 'Wahhabun', so he deleted the Tanwin due to the meeting of two sakins. It was narrated from Abu Amr in some of his paths: (Qul huwa Allahu Ahadu Allahu al-Samad), so he deleted the Tanwin from 'Ahadun' due to the meeting of two sakins. Likewise, the Tanwin was deleted due to the meeting of two sakins in the reading of whoever read: (Wa qalat al-Yahudu: Uzayru Ibnu Allah) considering it a subject and Ibnu Allah its predicate, like the reading of whoever established the Tanwin. Deleting the Tanwin from it is not because of prevention of declension, because Uzayr and its like are declinable whether Arabic or non-Arabic. Rather, deleting the Tanwin was good due to the meeting of two sakins, just as deleting the soft letters was good for that. Do you not see that it ran their course in: 'Lam yaku Zaydun qa'iman', and His Almighty's saying: (Wa in yaku kadhiban fa-'alayhi kadhibuh). The poet established the Nun of 'Mi'atay dirhamin' (two hundred dirhams) by necessity, saying:
'Indi laha mi'atani thawban mu'lama' (I have for her two hundred marked robes).
It is permissible for the Muwallad to delete the Nun of 'Min' if it is followed by a silent Lam, like the saying of the poet:
'Convey to Abu Dakhtanush a message... other than what might be said from lies (mil kadhib).'
He intended to say: 'Min al-kadhib', so he deleted the Nun for its silence and the silence of the Lam after it. Al-Muraqqish al-Akbar said:
'Nothing grieved my heart from accidents (mil-hawadith)... except my companion left in Taghlam.'
Another said:

'As if from now (Mil-ana) they did not change... and an age has passed for the two abodes after us.'
He intended: 'Min al-ana' (From now), so he deleted. Likewise, Al-Najashi deleted the Nun from 'Lakin' (But) due to the meeting of two sakins, saying:
'I am not coming to him nor can I [bear] him... but give me drink (Laki-sqini) if your water possesses excess.'
They only deleted this Nun likening it to the Ya' deleted for lightening in 'La adri' (I do not know) and His Almighty's saying: (Dhalika ma kunna nabghi) [That is what we were seeking - without Ya], due to its resemblance to the letters of Madd (prolongation) and Leen (softness). The Rajiz said:
'Nothing was, O my God, before You (Qablaka).'
As for the saying of Al-Mutanabbi:
'Great, like what is in me, let the torment be (Fal-yaku).'
We have mentioned the explanation of this verse in the 'Alawiyya Epistle', and exhausted the sections of defects in it. We only mention here the aspect of ugliness in deleting the Nun from 'Fal-yakun' and the aspect of excuse for him, even if weak. Abu al-Fath said: Deleting the Nun from 'Yakun', which is silent and has resembled the letters of Madd in exit, addition, silence, and Ghunna (nasalization), so it was deleted as they are deleted, while it is strong with movement in 'Fal-yaku al-tabrihu', is not [correct]; he should not have deleted it. End of his speech. The meaning of this saying is that if it were not deleted, its movement would be obligatory due to its silence and the silence of the Ta' substituted for the Lam of definition. It was only deleted in the like of (Wa in yaku kadhiban fa-'alayhi kadhibuh) and in the saying of the Rajiz: 'Lam yaku shay'un ya ilahi qablaka' due to its resemblance to the letters of Madd, Leen, silence, and Ghunna. So they deleted it likening it to the Ya' deleted for lightening in 'La adri' and (Dhalika ma kunna nabghi) and (Yawma ya'ti la takallamu nafsun). If the silence necessitating its resemblance to letters of Madd is removed, its establishment is obligatory, like His Almighty's saying: (Lam yakuni Allahu li-yaghfira lahum). Deleting the Nun from 'Fal-yakun' was ugly from another aspect, which is that he deleted the Nun with Idgham (assimilation), and this is not known, because he who said in Bani al-Harith: 'Balharith', did not say in Bani al-Najjar: 'Bannajjar'. The aspect of excuse for Al-Mutanabbi is to say: As for the correctness of speech, it is establishing the Nun moving, but the necessity of poetry invited him to that. Abu Zaid narrated in 'Al-Nawadir' from the Arabs the like of this necessity in what he recited for Husayl bin Urfuta, saying:
'The truth was not upon that a trace... of a house effaced at Al-Sarar excited him.
The breaches of wind and the flood of rain... changed the newness of its recognition.'
Al-Najashi deleted the light Nun of 'Lakin' while it was in a place of movement in his saying:
'Fa-lastu bi-atihi wa la astati'uhu... walahki-sqini in kana ma'uka dha fadli.'
If 'Lakin', and its origin is 'Lakinna', allowed necessity to delete its Nun after deleting the other Nun, then deleting the Nun from his saying: 'Fal-yaku al-tabrihu' is tolerated for necessity. As for deleting it with Idgham, we judge that he deleted the Nun from 'Fal-yakun' not for the meeting of two sakins, but rather, as it was deleted in the saying of Al-Qutami:
'Wa la yaku mawqifun minki al-wada'a' (And let not a stand be farewell from you)
And he introduced the assimilated sakin after deleting it. Similar to it in the ancient Rajaz:
'Wa man yaku al-dahru lahu bil-marsadi.'
This is the aspect of Ijtihad of one trying to apologize for him, and against it is a refutation that invalidates his argument and obliterates his path, and this is not the place to speak of it. The principle is that Abu al-Tayyib erred in that and followed a path not for the Muwallad to follow, and the obligation is to avoid what he followed of this necessity. It is permissible to delete the Ya' from 'Al-Aydi' and 'Al-Nawahi' and from 'Hiya' for necessity. The poet said:
'A house for Su'da since she (Idh-hi) is of your passion.'
He deleted the Ya' from 'Hiya' because he intended: 'Idh hiya min hawaka'. The poet said:
'And I flew with my blade on working camels... bleeding of hands (Dawami al-Ayd), striking the leather.'
He deleted the Ya' from 'Al-Aydi', like the saying of the other:
'Like the sides (Ka-nawah) of the feathers of a Najdi dove... and you wiped with the gums the dust of antimony.'
He dropped the Ya' from 'Nawahi'. Similar is:
'Your hands: a hand (Kaff) that does not hold a dirham... out of generosity, and another giving (Tu'ti) blood with the sword.'
He intends: 'Tu'ti', so he deleted the Ya'. Upon it is the verse of the Book (Sibawayh's):
'And the brother of beautiful women (Akhu al-ghawan), when he wishes, they cut him off.'
The Waw was deleted with Damma, like the saying of the poet:
'Indeed the poor among us is a judge who ruled... that we reach the water when the stars (Al-nujum) disappear.'
He intends 'Al-Nujum', so he deleted the Waw and sufficed with Damma. And his saying:
'Until when the throats (Halaqim) of the throats (Al-Huluq) were wet.'
He intends 'Al-Huluq'. Al-Akhtal said:

'Like the flashing of the hands of bereaved women, robbed... showing the molar of the daughters of Time and calamities (Al-Khutub).'
He intends 'Al-Khutub', so he deleted the Waw and sufficed with Damma. It is permissible to silence letters followed by Dammas and Kasras like: 'Adud' and 'Fakhidh', so it is said: 'Ad'd' and 'Fakh'dh'. Al-Akhtal said:
'You are the best of Quraysh in their lineage... and the people of its valley, the wealthy and the branch (Al-Far'a).'
He intended 'Al-Far'a' (branch), so he moved the Ra'. Al-Uqayshir al-Asadi said:
'We only drink from our wealth... so ask the policeman (Al-Shuratiyya) what is this usurpation (Al-Ghasab)?'
He intended 'Al-Shurtiyya' by moving the Ra'. It is said in 'Alima': 'Al'ma', in 'Karuma': 'Kar'ma', in 'Rajul': 'Raj'l', in 'Duriba': 'Dur'b', in 'Usira': 'Us'r'. The poet said:
'Law 'us'ra minha al-banu wal-misku in'asar' (If the willow and musk were squeezed from her, they would be squeezed).
It is said in, for example, 'Intaliq': 'Intal'qa', transferring the movement of the Lam to the Qaf and the silence of the Qaf to the Lam, like the saying of the poet:
'O how many a born one having no father... and a possessor of a child whom no two parents begot (Yal'dahu).'
He moved the Dal with Fatha when he silenced the Lam. As for the saying of the other, which is from the verses of the Book:
'Qawatinan Makkata min wurqi al-hami' (Dwelling in Mecca of the ash-colored doves).
And it is narrated 'Awalifan'. He intended 'Al-Hamam', so he deleted the Alif, remaining 'Al-Hamam'. Two letters of one genus met, so he substituted the second Mim with Ya' as they said: 'Tazannaytu' substituting Ya' for Nun. This is only permissible to use by necessity in 'Al-Hamam' specifically by transmission (Naql), and it is not permissible to analogize upon it in 'Al-Himar' nor in what resembles that because it is anomalous (Shadh). Among what Alif was deleted in, which is rare in the open (Maftuh) due to the lightness of Alif, is the saying of the poet:
'Like the sand dune, the downpour of dews (Al-Tilal) compacted it.'
He intends 'Al-Tilal', so he deleted the Alif. Abu Uthman said regarding His Almighty's saying: (Ya Abati) [O my father], He intended: 'Ya Abatah', so He deleted the Alif. The poet has doubled what is not permissible to be doubled in other than poetry for necessity. Qa'nab said:
'Gently, O blamer, you have tested of my character... that I give to people even if they were miserly (Daniffu).'
The Rajiz said:
'Praise be to Allah, the High, the Majestic (Al-Ajlali).'
The correct face is 'Dannu' and 'Al-Aliyyu Al-Ajallu'. All these necessities are only permitted for the poet to use in the straits of speech and difficulty of intent, because poetry is the place of committing necessities and using prohibitions. The poet has attached the Nun of plural with the pronoun noun, which is of the necessities not considered good, saying in like 'Al-daribuhu' (those hitting him): 'Al-daribunahu', and 'Al-kha'ifuhu': 'Al-kha'ifunahu', and 'Al-amiruhu': 'Al-amirunahu'. The poet said:
'They are the sayers of good and its commanders (Al-amirunahu)... when they fear a terrbile matter from a novelty.'
As for deleting inflection (I'rab), it is not permissible for the Arab, let alone the Muwallad. The Rajiz said:
'If they bent, I said: Companion, straighten (Qawwim - silent)... in the desert the likes of the floating ships.'
Sibawayh recited:
'So today drink (Ashrab - silent) not bearing... a sin from Allah nor an intruder.'
He intends: 'Ashrabu', so he deleted the Damma, which is a solecism. The correct narration in it is: 'Fa-al-yawma fa-shrab ghayra mustahqibin'. As for cutting the connecting Alif (Hamzat al-Wasl), it is not permissible for the Muwallad poet to use it because it is a solecism, even if the Arab did that. Jamil said:
'Indeed I do not see two (Ithnayni) better in character... upon the accidents of time than me and Juml.'
He cut the Alif of 'Ithnayn', which is a connecting Alif. It is permissible to add Ya' in what was on the meter of 'Mafa'il' so it becomes 'Fa'il' like 'Masajid' and 'Darahim', so they said: 'Masajid' and 'Darahim'. The reason for that is that if the poet needs to establish the meter, he nullifies the movement and creates from it a letter of its genus. The poet said describing a she-camel:
'Her hands expel the pebbles in every midday heat... the expelling of dirhams (Darahim) by the critica (Sayarif).'
Likewise is the saying of Ibn Harma: 'Yamuntazahin', intending 'Bi-muntazahin' from 'Nazh'. And the saying of the other: 'Fanzuru', meaning 'Fanzur'. Grammarians have clarified that and explained it. It came in like 'Al-Miftah': 'Al-Miftah', and in 'Al-Ta'mil': 'Al-Ta'mal', and in 'Al-Kalkal': 'Al-Kalkal'. This is permissible for the Muwallad poet to use if he transmits it by narration because it is the language of the people and they have disposal in it. We do not have analogy upon it, but we use what was narrated from them. The Rajiz said:
'I say when she fell on the chest (Al-Kalkal)... O my she-camel, what a run you ran.'

It is permissible for the Muwallad poet to use the diminutive in poetry without necessity for meanings in the diminutive which we will mention. Diminutive is of four types: A type for belittling, like your saying: 'Rujayl' (little man). A type for reducing in quantity, like your saying: 'Ujaymal' (few camels). A type for aggrandizing, like the saying of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him: 'Kunayf (little vessel) filled with knowledge.' Hubab said: 'I am its rubbed little stump (Judhayl) and its propped little palm branch (Udhayq).' Labid said:
'A little calamity (Duwayhiyya) from which fingertips turn yellow.'
And a type for approximation, and that is in adverbs, like your saying: 'Fuwayqa' (a little above) and 'Qudaydima' (a little before). Imru' al-Qais said:
'Robust, if you approach him from behind, he blocks his gap... with a full tail a little above (Fuwayqa) the ground, not defenseless.'
Al-A'sha said:
'Convey to Yazid of Banu Shayban a message... O Abu Thubayt, will you not cease eroding?'
Zuhair said:
'As for what is a little above (Fuwayqa) the necklace of her... it is of a white doe whose pasture is empty.'
Abu Zubayd al-Ta'i said:
'O son of my mother and O little brother (Shuqayyiq) of my soul... you left me for a severe matter.'
Sometimes they used the diminutive for the verb of wonder (Fi'l al-Ta'ajjub) because it attaches to nouns since it lacks conjugation. The meaning of diminishing is exaggeration in appreciation, as he said:
'Oh how cute (Ya ma uhaysina) are gazelles that appeared to us.'
It is permissible to use 'Ghadwan' in place of 'Ghadin', as the poet said:
'And people are nothing but like dwellings and their people... in them on the day they settled them, and tomorrow (Ghadwan) are empty.'
It is permissible to use 'Layti' in place of 'Laytani', as the poet said:
'Like the wish of Jabir when he said: Would that I (Layti)... encounter him and lose some of my money.'
It is permissible to use ''Im sabahan' in place of 'An'im sabahan', as the poet said:
'They came to my fire, so I said: Who are you?... They said: The Jinn. I said: Have a good evening ('Imu Zalaman).'
Truncation (Tarkhim) is permissible outside of vocative for necessity, as the poet said:
'Excellent is the youth you seek the light of his fire... Tarif bin Mali (for Malik) on the night of hunger and cold.'
He intends Tarif bin Malik, so he truncated outside of vocative. As the other said:
'And this my robe is with him, he borrows it... to rob me of my honor, did Mali bin Hanzal (for Malik bin Hanzala).' 
He intended Hanzala, so he truncated while not being called. As for truncation in vocative, what came of it in their poems cannot be encompassed by counting. The poet said:
'O Marwa (for Marwan), indeed my mount is detained... hoping for the gift, and its lord has not despaired.'
He intends O Marwan. Another said:
'So you said: Come, O Yazi (for Yazid) bin Mukharram... So I said to you: Indeed I am an ally of Suda'.' 
He intends O Yazid. Another said:
'O Hari (for Harith), may I not be struck by a calamity from you.'
He intended O Harith. It came from them substituting the moving letter with a letter in which movement does not run. This is of the necessities not permissible for the Muwallad poet, nor is it appreciated. The poet said:
'He has dried strips of meat he dries... from the foxes (Al-Tha'ali) and a stitch from its hares (Araniha).'
He intended 'Al-Tha'alib' so he substituted Ya' for Ba', and likewise intended 'Aranibiha' so he substituted Ya' for Ba'. Similar to it:
'And a watering place having no restrainers... and for the frogs (Dafadi) of its main body are croaks.'
He intends 'Al-Dafadi''. It is permissible for the Muwallad poet to use the past tense in place of the future and the future in place of the past. As for using the past in place of the future, it is like His Almighty's saying: (And the companions of the Fire called out [wa nada - past] to the companions of Paradise: Pour upon us some water). The meaning is: And when the companions of the Fire call out. As for using the future in place of the past, it is like His Almighty's saying: (So a party you denied, and a party you kill [taqtulun - future]). He intended: A party you killed. Similar is (They worship [ya'buduna] nothing but what their fathers worship [ya'budu] before). He placed 'ya'budu' in place of 'abada'. Al-Tirimmah said:
'And I come to you thanking what has passed... of yesterday and necessitating what was (kana) in tomorrow.'
He placed 'kana' in place of 'yakunu'. Ziyad al-A'jam said:
'And sprinkle the sides of his grave with their blood... for indeed he is (yakunu - future) a brother of blood and sacrifices.'
He placed 'yakunu' in place of 'kana'.

Abu al-Fath said: Abu Ali said: I asked Abu Bakr about verbs occurring in place of each other. He said: All verbs should have been one form because they are for one meaning, but their forms were differed due to the difference of the states of their times. If the verb is joined by what indicates it of word or state, it is permissible for some of them to occur in place of others. Abu al-Fath said: This is high, correct speech from Abu Bakr, so know it. A'sha Bahila said:
'If an enemy afflicts you in hostility... then the highness and victory are (takunu - future) for you.'
He placed 'takunu' in place of 'kanat'. Another said:
'Ju'ada said: What is with your body pale... while it is (yakunu - future) fresh in youth?'
Meaning: And it was (kana). It is permissible for the Muwallad poet to feminize the masculine and masculinize the feminine based on meaning, and it is more widespread in custom and usage than to need a witness or example. The poet said:
'Do you abandon a house in Hijaz wrapped... in it fear (Al-Khawf - masc.) and enemies from every side?'
He feminized 'Al-Khawf' because he went with it to 'Al-Makhafa' (fear - fem.). Similar is the verse of Al-Hamasa:
'O rider driving his mount... ask Banu Asad what is this sound (Hadhihi Al-Sawt - fem. dem. for masc. noun)?'
He feminized 'Al-Sawt' because he went with it to 'Al-Istighatha' (call for help - fem.). If feminizing the masculine is permissible in their speech based on meaning, which for them is carrying the original on the branch, then masculinizing the feminine is more worthy of permissibility since the origin is masculinity. It is of beautiful goodness to return branches to origins. Of masculinizing the feminine is His Almighty's saying: (The sky is split [Munfatir - masc.] by it). Because He Almighty intended by the sky the ceiling (Al-Saqf - masc.), due to His Almighty's saying: (And We made the sky a preserved ceiling). The poet said:
'So no cloud poured its rain... nor a land sprouted (Abqala - masc.) its vegetation.'
He masculinized when he meant by the land the place (Al-Makan - masc.), except that he returned the Ha' (fem. pronoun) to the word 'Al-Ard'. Zuhair said:
'It has a tool and helpers who went early for it... a saddle and a bucket when emptied (Ufrigha - masc.) poured out (Insahaqa - masc.).'
'Ghadawna' is feminine, even if for helpers (A'wan), because he feminized based on the meaning of the group (Jama'a), just as you say: 'Hadhihi Rijal' (These [fem.] are men). The saddle (Qitb) is the saddle of the water-camel, and 'Insahaqa' means poured out. Al-Mufaddal recited:
'If I were with the defeated, Sayf bin Zalim... I would have attacked so his relatives would have returned the grave of Awf.
But I found the arrow easier of notch... upon you, for a blood you seek has perished.'
He made the notch (Fuq) feminine; because he intended its peak (Dhirwa - fem.) which is its top. The like of that is many. Among what is permissible for the Muwallad poet to use is deleting the Hamza at necessity. Sibawayh recited for Abdul Rahman bin Hassan:
'So you were lowlier than a peg in a lowland... whose head is crushed by the rock, driven (Waj - without Hamza).'
He intends 'Waji''. Ibn Harma said:
'Would that the predatory beasts were neighbors to us... and that we see no one of whom we see.
Indeed the predatory beasts calm down from their prey... and people, their evil is never calming (Hadin).'
He intends 'Hadi''. Another said:
'The scouts threw him until they cast him... behind (Wara) the edge of Sham, the distant lands.'
He intended: 'Wara'a', so he shortened the word. He should not have shortened it because the Hamza is original in it. But necessity compelled him, so he turned it into a Ya'. Abu Ali recited:
'If I do not fight, then clothe me in a veil (Burqu'a).'
It is permissible for the Muwallad poet to delete the Hamza of interrogation for necessity with the indication of speech to it, as Al-Kumayt said:
'I rejoiced, and not for longing for fair women do I rejoice... nor out of play from me; does the gray-haired play (Wa dhu al-shaybi yal'abu)?'
He intended: 'A-wa dhu al-shaybi yal'abu' (Or does the gray-haired play?). Imran bin Hittan said:
'And I became safe among them, not like a group... who came to me and said: From Rabi'a or Mudar?'
He intended: 'A-min Rabi'a' (Is it from Rabi'a or Mudar?). Ibn Abi Rabi'a said:
'Then they said: You love her? I said: Wonderfully... the number of the rain, the pebbles, and the dust.'
He intended: 'A-tuhibbuha' (Do you love her?). It was said regarding His Almighty's saying (A favor you confer upon me): The intent is: 'A-wa tilka ni'matun' (Is that a favor?). If that is correct, then necessity is removed from the poetry.

Among what is permissible for the Muwallad poet to use at necessity in his poetry is Kharm, with a dotted Kha' and undotted Ra'. It is the deletion of the first moving letter from the Watid Majmu' (joined peg) at the beginning of the verse. The Watid Majmu' is two moving letters followed by a silent one, like: 'Gha-za', 'Ra-ma'. Kharm does not enter a verse beginning with a Sabab (cord) or Fasilah (separator). It occurs mostly in the first verse of the poem, and may occur in other verses. The poet said:
'We used to think every white woman a piece of fat... nights we met Judham and Himyar.'
He intended to say: 'Wa kunna' (And we were), so he deleted the Waw. Another said:
'My spear used to not soften for a pincher... so the morning and evening softened it.'
Most of what is deleted for Kharm are conjunction letters like Waw and its sisters, although Kharm occurs with other than that. Some prosodists permitted Kharm in the beginning of the second half of the verse and likened it to the beginning of the verse, reciting for it the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'And an eye for her, round, full... its tear ducts were split from others.'
He intended to say: 'Wa shuqqat' (And were split). They recited regarding Kharm at the beginning of the verse and at the beginning of its second half—which is not appreciated and should not be practiced—the saying of the poet:
'My Lord exchanged for me, instead of Taym al-Lat... Hanzala, who revived Tamim.'
He intended to say: 'Wa abdalani' (And exchanged for me) with Hanzala, so he deleted the Waw from the beginning of the first half, and the Ba' from the beginning of the second half. The story of Abu Tammam with Abu Sa'id al-Makfuf, when his Ba'iyya poem praising Abdullah bin Tahir was presented to him, and his denial of the Kharm in the first verse of it, is well known because the scholars of poetry do not appreciate it even if it is permitted and used. It is his saying:
