'They are the misfortunes of Joseph and his companions... so with resolve, for of old the seeker attained revenge.'
As for Khazm, with dotted Kha' and dotted Za', it is not permissible for the Muwallad poet to use, nor is its practice ever allowed for him. It is the addition of a word they bring at the beginnings of verses which counts in meaning but does not count in meter. If one wants to scan the verse, that extra word is deleted. It is used in all meters, as the poet said:
'Tighten your chest belts for death... for indeed death will meet you.'
The verse is from Hazaj and does not straighten except by dropping 'Ushdud'. Another said:
'Al-Musayyab bin Sharik today is a scholar among scholars.'
Its scansion does not straighten until 'Al-Musayyab' is deleted from its beginning. Khazm might be a letter or two at the beginning of the verse, as Al-Kindi said:
'And as if Thabir in the foreparts of its rain... is a chief of people in a striped garment wrapped.'
Do you not see that the meter does not straighten until the Waw falls, and so it is narrated. The origin in the correct narration is the establishment of the Waw, and so the prosodists recited it and argued with it. Khazm has come by way of anomaly in the middle of the verse, like the saying of the poet:
'O soul, eating and lying down... O soul, you are not immortal.'
The verse is from Majzu' al-Kamil, Mutafa'ilun four times, and it is not correct except by dropping 'Ya' from the middle of the verse and sufficing with the vocative particle at the beginning of the verse, so know that. They permitted deleting the Ya' from the rhyme in like the saying of the poet:
'And a tribe from Lukayz is witnessing... the group of Marjum and the group of Ibn al-Mu'all.'
He intends 'Al-Mu'alla'. They also permitted lightening the stressed letter (Mushaddad) in like the saying of the poet:
'I called my people and I called my clan... until when I found nothing but the evil (Al-Shar).'
'I was a man from Malik bin Ja'far.'
He lightened the Ra' of 'Al-Sharr'. Al-Mubarrad said: He did not intend 'Al-Sharr' (evil), but intended 'Al-Sari' with undotted Sin, which is a man's name likened to 'Al-Sari' which is a river, so he deleted one of the two Yas, remaining 'Al-Sari', then lightened the Ya'. This is a brief overview in this chapter that dispenses with other than it, and a gleam sufficing for what is besides it. For perhaps a firebrand sufficed for a lamp, and a dawn darkness sufficed for a morning.

**Chapter Three**
**On Its Merit, Benefits, Influence on Hearts, and Occurrences**

As for poetry, it is the register (Diwan) of literature, the pride of the Arabs; by it proverbs are struck, and men boast over men. It is the shackle of virtues and the string of beauties. Were it not for it, the gems of wisdom would be lost, the stars of honor scattered, the buildings of merit demolished, the quarters of glory desolate, the flags of generosity obliterated, and the traces of favors effaced. Its honor is eternal, its sovereignty renewed. Ages perish while its mention remains; mountains fall while its pride ascends to the sky. There is no eraser for what it established, nor blamer for whom it excused. Suhaym, the slave of Banu al-Hashas, died, and he has a mention more fragrant than musk and fresher than myrtle. Were it not for poetry, he would not have been known, nor described with proficiency. How many among the sons of Ham are unknown rabble, neither mentioned nor thanked. It was said: When Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi apologized to Al-Ma'mun—and his speech is known—he said to Al-Ma'mun in response to his saying to him 'You are the Black Caliph': 'As for my being black, the slave of Banu al-Hashas said:
"The poems of the slave of Banu al-Hashas stood for him... on the day of boasting, in the place of the origin and the leaves.
If I am a slave, my soul is free in generosity... or black of color, indeed I am white of character."
Al-Ma'mun said: 'I would wish they were mine for all my kingdom,' meaning the two verses. Were it not for Zuhair, Harim would not be mentioned, nor would a pen run with his praise. They died and decayed, their limbs torn apart and perished, yet their mention is fresh and new, and their fame remaining and extended; this for his merit and that for his bestowal. Were it not for poetry, they would not be mentioned nor known. Al-Ruhni narrated in his book titled 'Treasures of Wisdom', raising it to Salim bin Abdullah bin Umar from his father Abdullah that he said: We were one day with Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, when he said: Who is the most poetic of people? We said: So-and-so and So-and-so. While we were so, Abdullah bin Abbas appeared, greeted, and he [Umar] sat him by his side, then said: The expert of it has come to you. Who is the most poetic of people, O Ibn Abbas? He said: That is Zuhair bin Abi Sulma. He said: Recite to us something of his poetry by which we can deduce what you say. He said: He praised a people from Ghatafan called Banu Sinan, saying:
"If a people were to sit above the sun... a people, by their first or their glory, would have sat.
A people, Sinan is their father when you trace their lineage... they were good, and good were the children born.
Humans when secure, Jinn when frightened... generous, noble chiefs when strained.
Envied for what was of blessings... Allah does not remove from them what they are envied for."
Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: May Allah fight him, O Ibn Abbas! He said good words that were not fitting except for the people of this House from Banu Hashim due to their kinship to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He considered great what he praised Banu Sinan with, and sought a deserving one for it, but saw none but Banu Hashim. This is Jarir bin al-Khatafa, despite the meanness of his origin, the lowness of his house, the paucity of his family, and the obscurity of his grandfather and father; his poetry raised him and his speech constructed him. So he is immortal, remaining, and he has a protector from annihilation in his poetry. The mention of Yarbu' was built by his mention, and his name became famous among gatherings and groups. He matched Al-Farazdaq and opposed him, openly satirized him and antagonized him, despite Al-Farazdaq's honor and noble origin. Were it not for poetry, he would have been far from competing with his like, until Al-Farazdaq mentioned his fathers and said:
'Those are my fathers, so bring me their like... when the assemblies gather us, O Jarir.'
Imru' al-Qais and his father, his kingdom and his family have gone. His poetry and speech remained, and his saying and system were populated. How many a king in Kinda went, and his equipment and gear went with him, so his news is not sensed, nor his name or mark known. The kingdom of the Tubba's and Chosroes has gone, and the authority of the qayls and Asawira has vanished, and nothing remained for them except a current verse from the praise of a poet. Were it not for the praises of Ziyad al-Dhubyani, King Ibn al-Julah would not have been known, nor would the fragrance of praise diffused for him. Likewise his father Al-Julah; were it not for Abu Umama, there would be no sign of mention upon him:
'Al-Julah died, but did not die... what Abu Umama said about him.'
The Arabs used to consider poetry grave, and see the poet as a prince. If a poet appeared in the tribe, they were congratulated for him, and envied because of him, because he defends their lineages, and fights and struggles for their honors.

'How many a prince was in Aws... they all died except 'Araba.
A verse of a poet revived him after death... when he called, he rewarded him.
Perhaps he was in the tail... but poetry returned him to the forelock.'
Do you not see Abu Dulaf al-Ijli, how [poetry] raised him, despite the lowness of his house and the baseness of Banu Ijl, for you find no praised one among them but him, [due to] the saying of Ibn Jabala:
'The world is only Abu Dulaf... between his desert and his settled land.
If Abu Dulaf turns away... the world turns away on his trace.'
Abu al-Saqr bin Bulbul was not counted among those of established roots, nor growing branches, until Ibn Jurayj praised him saying:
'They said Abu al-Saqr is from Shayban. I said to them... Nay, by my life, but Shayban is from him.
How many a father rose by a son to peaks of honor... as Adnan rose by the Messenger of Allah.
I did not fall short with Shayban, by whom... roots and branches reached the utmost.'
So he became among the elite of the praised, and exemplars use his praise as a proverb. Banu Quray' used to be called 'Anf al-Naqa' (Camel's Nose) and they would get angry at that and resent it. When Al-Hutay'ah praised them saying:
'A people who are the Nose, and others are the tails... and who equates the tail with the Camel's Nose?'
They became pleased with it and it became one of their greatest boasts. Were it not for poetry, they would have counted it among their ugliest titles. The story of Al-Hutay'ah with Al-Zibraqan bin Badr, and what happened from his wife Umm Shadhra and her shortcoming in his right, and the correspondence of Banu Anf al-Naqa with him until they corrupted him [against Al-Zibraqan] and moved him to them, is famous and mentioned. When Al-Hutay'ah was given the choice, he chose Banu Anf al-Naqa over Al-Zibraqan. That was hard on him. Al-Zibraqan sent to a man from Al-Namir bin Qasit called Dithar bin Shayban and ordered him to satirize them. The Namari said from verses:
'And you came to the waters of Banu Quray'... so you did not join ties of kinship since you did evil.'
At that, Al-Hutay'ah needed to satirize Al-Zibraqan bin Badr, so he satirized him with verses including:
'Leave noble deeds, do not rise to seek them... and sit, for you are the fed, the clothed.'
When it reached Al-Zibraqan, he complained about him to Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, and said: He satirized me. When he asked him to recite, Umar said: There is no harm in that. He said: Send to Hassan bin Thabit and ask him did he satirize me or not. Hassan said: Yes, he satirized him and defecated on him. So Umar imprisoned him. Al-Hutay'ah wrote to him from prison verses including:
'What do you say to chicks at Dhi Marakh... red of crops, with neither water nor trees?
You threw their earner into the bottom of a dark place... so bestow favor upon him, may Allah guide you, O Umar.'
The poetry affected Umar, so he asked him to repent and released him. If Al-Hutay'ah had insulted Al-Zibraqan without poetry, he would not have been affected by his insult. Since it was poetry, he saw that by saying 'You are the fed, the clothed', he had committed a crime against him and offended him. When Al-Hutay'ah satirized Banu al-Ajlan, they complained about him to Umar bin al-Khattab and said: He satirized us and defamed our honors. Umar said: And what did he say? They said: He said about us:
'If Allah were to be an enemy to people of meanness and pettiness... He would be an enemy to Banu al-Ajlan, the group of Ibn Muqbil.'
Umar said: He invoked against them. They said he said:
'A little tribe who do not betray a covenant... nor wrong people a grain of mustard.'
Umar said: These are righteous people, would that I were of them and the family of Al-Khattab were of them. They said he said:
'And they do not approach water except in the evening... when the drinkers return from every watering place.'
Umar said: That is lighter for crowding, and then the water clears and the approach is pleasant. They said he said:
'And Al-Ajlan was named so only because of their saying... Take the cup and milk, O slave, and hurry (i'jal).'
Umar said: The master of the people is their servant, and the smallest of them is their knife. They said he said:
'The trained dogs disdain their flesh... and eat from Ka'b bin Awf and Nahshal.'
Umar said: Sufficient waste is he whose flesh dogs eat. They said: O Commander of the Faithful, this is not your craft, so if you sent to Hassan bin Thabit and asked him. He sent to Hassan and asked him: Did he satirize them? He said: No, O Commander of the Faithful, but he defecated on them.

The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, threatened whoever memorized the poem of Al-Afwah al-Awdi and guaranteed him the Fire, out of disdain for satire and anger at the positions of his arrows. He, peace be upon him, heard a man reciting:
'Quraysh was an egg so it split... so the yolk, its pure part, belongs to Abd al-Dar.'
The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, got angry and said to Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him: Is this how the poet said? He said: No, O Messenger of Allah, rather he said:
'O man shifting his saddle... why did you not dismount at the family of Abd Manaf?
The strikers of the ram whose helmet shines... and the sayers: Come, to the guests.
The mixers of their poor with their rich... until their poor returns like the sufficient.
Amr of the Heights (Al-Ula) crumbled tharid for his people... while the men of Mecca were drought-stricken, lean.
Quraysh was an egg so it split... so the yolk, its pure part, belongs to Abd Manaf.'
The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, rejoiced until the lines of his face shone and said: Thus he said. It reached him, peace be upon him, that Ka'b bin Zuhair satirized him, so he vowed his blood. He came to him disguised until he entered the mosque and asked his permission to present his praise. He permitted him, so he stood before him and recited:
'Su'ad departed, so my heart today is lovesick... enslaved after her, unransomed, shackled.'
When he reached his saying:
'I was informed that the Messenger of Allah threatened me... and pardon with the Messenger of Allah is hoped.'
He said: Allah has pardoned you. He bestowed his mantle (Burda) upon him, comforted him, and secured him. Were it not for his poetry, his blood would have been shed and his destination would have been Hell. Abu Ya'la al-Ashdaq narrated, saying: I heard Al-Nabigha say: I recited to the Prophet, peace be upon him:
'We reached the sky, our glory and our ancestors... and we hope for an ascent above that.'
He got angry and said: Where is the ascent, O Abu Layla? I said: Paradise, O Messenger of Allah. He said: Yes, if Allah Almighty wills, and smiled. I said:
'And there is no good in clemency if it does not have... impulses that protect its purity from being muddied.
And there is no good in ignorance if it does not have... a forbearing one who, when the people arrive, issues [them out].'
The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: You did well, may Allah Almighty not break your mouth, twice. He lived more than a hundred years and was among the people with the best teeth. Abu Ghaziyya al-Ansari narrated, saying: When Hassan bin Thabit recited to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, his poem until he reached his saying:
'I satirized Muhammad, so I answered on his behalf... and with Allah in that is the reward.'
He, peace be upon him, smiled and said to him: May Allah reward you with Paradise for that. Then he recited to him:
'For my father and his father and my honor... are a shield from you for the honor of Muhammad.'
He, peace be upon him, said: May Allah shield you from the heat of the Fire. Hisham bin Urwa narrated, saying: My father told me, saying: Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, told me, saying: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was sitting mending a sandal and I was sitting spinning. I began looking at the side of his neck and his cheek had sweated. His sweat began generating light, so I was stunned. He raised his head and looked at me and said: O Aisha, at what are you looking, you are stunned? I said: I do not look at anything of you except light generates in my eye. By Allah, if Abu Kabir al-Hudhali saw you, he would know that you are more worthy of his poetry than anyone else. She said: He said: And what did Abu Kabir say? I said: He said:
'And acquitted of every remnant of menstruation... and corruption of a wet nurse and a disease causing death.
And if you look at the lines of his face... they shine like the flash of the rejoicing cloud.'
She said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, put down what was in his hand and came to me, kissed between my eyes, and said: May Allah reward you with good, O Aisha. I do not remember when I was pleased as I am pleased with your words. Hisham bin Urwa narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered Abdullah bin Rawaha to improvise poetry, so he said from verses:
'You are the Prophet, and whoever is deprived of his intercession... on the Day of Reckoning, fate has disgraced him.
So may Allah establish what He gave you of goodness... the establishment of Moses, and a victory like they were given victory.'

He, peace be upon him, said: And you, may Allah establish you, O Ibn Rawaha. The narrator of this hadith said: So Allah established him with the best establishment, he was killed as a martyr, and passed away happy. Umar bin Hizzan bin Sa'id al-Ruhawi narrated from his father that a man from his people called Amr bin Subay' came as a delegate to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and recited to him:
'To you, O Messenger of Allah, I worked its pace... traversing the deserts, plain after plain.
Upon a possessor of planks (camel), whenever I want the night journey... she trots with my saddle at times and then gallops.
So you have no rest with me or you stay (talahlahi)... at the door of the Hashimi Prophet, the successful.
I was safe then from journey after journey... and cutting deserts and a clear night.'
The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, rejoiced at his poetry and tied a banner for him. Talahlahi: Originally talahhahi from ilhah (persistence), so they substituted Lam for the assimilated Ha out of dislike for the gathering of Has. When the delegation of Hawazin came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, at Al-Ji'ranah, Abu Jarwal al-Jushami recited to him a poem including:
'Bestow upon us, O Messenger of Allah, in generosity... for you are the man we hope for and store.
Bestow upon an egg (tribe/women) whose releasing is a destiny... tearing its unity; in its time are changes.'
When he heard his poetry, he sympathized with them and returned their sons and women to them. The hadith is famous. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, killed Al-Nadr bin al-Harith, his daughter Qutayla began saying from verses:
'O Muhammad, and indeed you are the son of a noble woman... in her people, and the stallion is a rooted stallion.
What would it have harmed you if you had bestowed favor? And perhaps... the youth bestows favor while he is enraged, angry.'
When he, peace be upon him, heard her poetry, he said—and he does not speak from desire—: If I had heard it before killing him, I would not have killed him. Al-Abbas bin Mirdas al-Sulami praised him, peace be upon him, with verses including:
'I saw you, O best of all creation... you spread a book that came with the truth, marked.
You legislated for us the religion of guidance after our deviation... from the truth when the truth became dark.
So who will convey from me to the Prophet Muhammad... and every man will be rewarded for what he advanced.
You established the path of truth after its crookedness... and of old its pillar had been demolished.'
He bestowed his robe upon him, and cut his tongue [silenced his demands] by his kindness to him. Were it not for poetry, the kindness from the Prophet would not have included him. The Prophet, peace be upon him, heard poetry from a group other than these, turning with listening to them, and inclining with appreciation towards them. Among them are A'sha of Banu Mazin, Dirar bin al-Azwar, and Qirda bin Nufatha al-Saluli. Among what he heard from him:
'Youth departed and I did not care for it... and gray hair and Islam approached, an approach.
So praise be to Allah, since my term did not come to me... until I clothed myself from Islam with a garment.'
He, peace be upon him, said: Praise be to Allah. He heard from Abdullah bin Kurz al-Laythi, from Humayd bin Thawr, from Al-Namir bin Tawlab al-Ukli, from Labid bin Rabi'a, from Farwa bin Amir al-Judhami, and from Amr bin Salim al-Ka'bi. When Maymun bin Qais al-A'sha intended him and praised him, Abu Jahl met him and said: Where is your intent, O Abu Basir? He said: Muhammad the Messenger of Allah. He said: And have you said anything about him? He said: Yes, and recited to him:
'Did your eyes not close on the night of ophthalmia... and you spent the night as the snake-bitten spends the night sleepless?'
Until he reached his saying:
'And I swore I would not pity it for its fatigue... nor for unshodness until it visits Muhammad.
Whenever you kneel at the door of Ibn Hashim... you rest and meet from his favors a hand.
A Prophet who sees what you do not see, and his mention... has raided, by my life, in the lands and went to the highlands.'
Abu Jahl envied him for Al-A'sha's praise, so he said to him: O Abu Basir, he forbids wine for you. He did not cease with him until he turned him away from him. Al-A'sha said: I will come to him next year. But he died, and death stood between the wish.

People complained to him of drought, so he prayed for rain for them and they were watered. When it was the second Friday, a man came running and said: O Messenger of Allah, houses have collapsed and walls have fallen. He, peace be upon him, smiled laughing at his saying, and said: Which of you narrates the word of my uncle Abu Talib? Abu Bakr stood up and said: I, O Messenger of Allah. He said: Recite. So he recited to him:
'You lied, by the House of Allah, that Muhammad be overcome... while we have not struggled around him and fought.'
When he reached his saying:
'And a white one, by whose face the clouds are asked for rain... aid of the orphans, protection for the widows.'
The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, rejoiced and his face beamed. When Hisham bin al-Walid bin al-Mughira killed Abu Uzayhir al-Dawsi at Dhu al-Majaz, and there was haste in Hisham, the people gathered and prepared for fighting. Abu Sufyan came and said: How fast are people to the blood of this clan of Quraysh! He said to his companions: Do not busy yourselves with war among you from the war of Muhammad, meaning the Prophet, peace be upon him. The Messenger of Allah said to Hassan bin Thabit: Incite Abu Sufyan regarding the blood of Abu Uzayhir. Hassan said from verses:
'Hisham bin al-Walid clothed you his robes... so wear out and succeed the likes of them new ones after.
He fulfilled a wish from him so he became noble... and you became slack, neither trotting nor going early.
So the farting donkey did not defend his protection... nor did Hind prevent the disgrace of her father.
If only old men at Badr had witnessed... a fresh roses [blood] would have wet the sandals of the people.'
He, peace be upon him, only wanted Abu Sufyan to become zealous and for poetry to shake him according to the custom of the Arabs, so he would be busy with the war of Banu Makhzum from his war. Disagreement would occur between them, so his affair, peace be upon him, would strengthen and they would weaken from him according to the custom of the Arabs in protective jealousy (Hamiyya). Do you not see that Jassas bin Murra killed Kulayb Wa'il unaware because of the she-camel of his aunt's neighbor due to verses she said, which are:
'By the life of my father, if I were in the house of Minqar... Sa'd would not have been wronged while he is the neighbor of my houses.
But I became in a house of estrangement... whenever the wolf raids in it, he raids my sheep.
So O Sa'd, let not my people deceive you, and depart... for you are among a tribe who are dead regarding the neighbor.
And take my camels and drive them, for I... am fearful that they will betray my little daughters.'
When Jassas heard the verses, they moved him, shook him, and angered him. He said: Quiet, O old woman, for I will surely kill for the she-camel of your neighbor the greatest stallion of the Arabs. She thought he would kill some of Kulayb's camels. He went out immediately, stabbed Kulayb and killed him. But Abu Sufyan, when he heard Hassan's verses, being cunning, left the war of Makhzum fearing what the Prophet, peace be upon him, calculated and attempted. Safiyya bint Abd al-Muttalib said, urging Abu Sufyan to take revenge for Abu Uzayhir from Banu Makhzum, and alluding to him about the fire that was lit for him due to treachery. That is because the Arabs used to, if a man betrayed, light a fire for him on a mountain and say: This is the treachery of So-and-so. When Abu Uzayhir, who was Abu Sufyan's son-in-law, was killed and he did not take revenge for him, fire was lit on Abu Qubays during the season and it was said: This is the treachery of Abu Sufyan. They are verses including:
'Verily convey a message to my cousins... so why is the plot among us and the command?
And ask in the crowds of Banu Ali... when reciting and boasting increases.'
She means Banu Ali bin Bakr bin Kinana. From it:
'And we are the forgivers when we are capable... and in us upon our anger is victory.
We did not begin disobedience to a possessor of womb... nor was a fire lit for us due to treachery.'
That did not move him because of what was in his soul of the war of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. It was narrated that Muawiyah said to Urwa bin al-Zubayr: Do you recite the saying of your grandmother Safiyya:
'I contended the eternities of times over you... and Asma' did not feel that she is a widow.
If he were a polytheist philanderer, I would have excused him... but people claim he is a Muslim.'

Muawiyah only wanted to provoke Urwa with that. Urwa said: Yes, and I recite her saying: 'Verily convey a message to my cousins...' the verses. Muawiyah was ashamed until his forehead sweated at the mention of his father's treachery and the fire that was lit for him on Abu Qubays. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, died and the Arabs apostatized, Al-Hutay'ah was the greatest motive for their apostasy by his saying:
'We obeyed the Messenger of Allah as long as he was among us... so O wonder, what is the matter with the rule of Abu Bakr?
Will he bequeath it to Bakr if he dies after him... then that, by Allah's life, is the breaker of the back.'
The Arabs became zealous at Al-Hutay'ah's saying and disdained obeying Abu Bakr. From the influence of poetry is that Ibn Hisham bin al-Walid had appointed Abdul Rahman bin Hazm al-Ansari over Medina. Al-Ahwas said:
'Do not have mercy on a Hazmi you pass by... one day, even if the Hazmi is thrown into the Fire.
The breakers [of allegiance] against Marwan at Dhi Khushub... and those entering upon Uthman in the house.'
When Hisham heard Al-Ahwas's poetry, he removed Abdul Rahman from Medina and ordered the seizure of their estates and money. When Al-Mansur took power, some of the children of Banu Hazm entered upon him and said: O Commander of the Faithful, for sixty years we have not taken a grant nor reached anything of our money because of Al-Ahwas's saying. He recited the two verses to him. He was affected by them and said: Then, by Allah, the outcome is praised with Banu Hashim. Write to return their estates and seize the estates of Banu Umayya and hand them over to them to exploit for sixty years. Then he ordered ten thousand dinars for him as a gift. Sudayf entered upon Al-Saffah while Banu Umayya were with him in their ranks. He recited to him:
'Let not what you see of people deceive you... indeed under the ribs is a festering disease.
So put down the sword and raise the whip until... you do not see upon its back an Umayyad.'
Sudayf also recited to him:
'The kingdom has become firm of foundations... by the masters from Banu al-Abbas.'
Until he reached his saying:
'And remember the death of Al-Husayn and Zaid... and a slain one beside Al-Mihras.'
Al-Saffah was affected by that, an effect that appeared on the pages of his face, and it was a cause for killing Banu Umayya, along with what was in the soul against them: 'And speech does what needles do not do.' He ordered striking their necks to the last of them, and their story is famous. Al-Mada'ini narrated that Al-Mansur said: I accompanied a blind man to Sham, and he wanted Marwan bin Muhammad for a poem he said about him. Al-Mansur said: I asked him to recite the poetry to me, but he refused and said: Only he whom it was said about hears it. I kept being gentle and friendly with him until he recited it to me. From it:
'I wish I knew, did the scent of musk diffuse... and I do not think there is a human at Al-Khayf.
When Banu Umayya were absent from it... and the masters from Banu Abd Shams.
Orators on the pulpits, knights... upon them, and speakers not mute.
They are not faulted speaking, and if they... spoke, they hit the mark and did not speak with confusion.
With dreams (forbearance) when dreams are lightened... and faces like smooth dinars.'
Al-Mansur said: By Allah, he did not finish his poetry until I thought blindness had overtaken me, and by Allah, I envied Marwan for the poetry more than I envied him for the Caliphate. When the matter devolved to me, I went out for Hajj in the year one hundred forty-one. I got down from the litter at the two mountains of Zarud walking in the sand for a vow I had. Suddenly I saw the blind man. I signaled to those with me, so they stepped back. I approached him, took his hand, and greeted him. He said: Who are you? May I be your ransom, I do not confirm you as an acquaintance. I said: I am your companion to Sham in the days of Banu Umayya while you were heading to Marwan bin Muhammad al-Ja'di. He greeted me, sighed deeply, and recited:
'The women of Banu Umayya became widows from them... and their daughters in a lost place are orphans.
Their lucks slept and their star was dropped... and the star drops and lucks sleep.
The pulpits and beds are empty of them... so upon them until death is peace.'

Al-Mansur said: I said to him: How much did Marwan give you? He said: He enriched me with the richness of eternity, so I ask no one after him. He said: I intended to kill him, then I remembered the right of trust and the sanctity of companionship, so I released him. Then it appeared to me [to seize him] so I ordered his pursuit, but it was as if the desert annihilated him. It was narrated that Yazid bin Ruwaym al-Shaybani, who was a man who lost things (Misya'), rested his camels one night from the pasture upon his father. His father said to him: Did you not give them supper? He said: Yes, I did. His father pushed his garment in the faces of the camels, startled them, and turned them to the pasture, saying: Improve their supper. The boy said: Indeed I reckon other than you will spend the night as their owner. When he reached the place where he gives supper to his camels, Sirhan bin Arta'ah al-Sa'di passed by him in a small group of horsemen. He drove the camels and took the boy, tying him firmly to some of those camels. The boy raised his voice and recited:
'O woe to a mother I have, noble to me... my loss to her is a grief of griefs.
Indeed, he whom you hope for the benefit of his return... supper fell with him upon a wolf (Sirhan).
Supper fell with him upon a moon-hunter (Mutaqammir)... firm of heart, accustomed to stabbing.'
When Sirhan bin Arta'ah heard his poetry, he said to him: Are you a poet? He said: Yes. He said: Let him go. So he released him and returned his camels to him. Their saying in the proverb: 'Supper fell with him upon Sirhan'. It was said: Sirhan here is the wolf. A group said: Rather it is Sirhan bin Mu'attab al-Ghanawi. He had raided the camels of Nusayha al-Asadi, so his brother Huzayla bin Mu'attab said:
'Convey to Nusayha that the herder of his camels... supper fell with him upon Sirhan.
Supper fell with him upon a moon-hunter... whom fear of accidents did not dissuade.'
The correct narration is what we mentioned first. Were it not for poetry and the poet, the soul and camels would have gone. Al-Mufaddal al-Dabbi said: I was beside Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Hasan bin Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, on the day of his meeting Al-Mansur's army. He turned to me and said: O Mufaddal, recite something to me. I said: He wants from me what I can move him with. So I recited to him the verses of Uwayf al-Fazari:
'I say to noble youths who went in the evening... on short-haired horses, in their mouths are bits.
Stand a stand, he who lives will not be disgraced after it... and he who is cut off, blames will not follow him.
And you did not distance yourself from them... to be safe from it; the last of time is safe.'
He said: O Mufaddal, repeat. I repeated three times. He stretched in his stirrups until I said they broke, and charged time after time, killing in each one a soul and ten, until he charged and did not return. It was said: A stray arrow came to him and slaughtered him. Shurahbil bin Ma'n bin Za'ida narrated, saying: I was on the road to Mecca, riding under the dome of Yahya bin Khalid, and his counterpart was Abu Yusuf the Judge. A man approached on a noble camel and recited poetry that Yahya did not approve of. He said to him: Did I not forbid you from saying the like of it? Why did you not say as the poet said:
'Banu Matar on the day of meeting are as if they... are lions having cubs in the thicket of Khaffan.
Tall chiefs in Islam, they ruled and there was not... for their first in Jahiliyya a first.
They protect the neighbor until it is as if... their neighbor has a home between the two Simak stars.
They are the people, if they speak they hit the mark, and if called... they answer, and if they give they make good and abundant.
Three, their tolerances are like mountains... and their dreams are heavier than them in panic.
And doers cannot do their deed... even if they do good in calamities and act beautifully.'
Abu Yusuf said to Yahya: To Allah is the goodness of its sayer! Whose poetry is this? Yahya said: To Marwan bin Abi Hafsa regarding the father of this youth, and he glanced at me. Abu Yusuf turned to me and said: Who are you, O youth? I said: Shurahbil bin Ma'n bin Za'ida. Shurahbil said: By Allah, I do not know a joy entered my heart greater than my joy at that, nor did a happier hour pass me than that hour. It was said when the saying of Al-A'sha reached Alqama:
'You spend the night in winter with your bellies full... and your neighbor women are hungry, spending the night with empty bellies.'

He wept, and perhaps he did not weep at the descending of calamities and striking of misfortunes, even if he witnessed death in wars and the confrontation of heroes in distress. It was said: Al-Mansur passed by the grave of Al-Walid bin Uqba bin Abi Mu'ayt, so he cursed him frequently and said: He is the first who ignited the war between Banu Abd Manaf with his saying:
'Banu Hashim, return the weapons of your sister's son... and do not loot him, his loots are not lawful.
Banu Hashim, how is peace between us... while Ali has his armor and his she-camels?
They killed him so they could be in his place... as her Marzbans (satraps) once betrayed Khosrow.'
Muawiyah was not one to talk to himself about opposing Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, nor intend to dispute him nor approach him in boasting, until this one wrote to him, and he pointed with his hand to the grave of Al-Walid bin Uqba, saying:
'Verily convey to Muawiyah bin Harb... for you are from a trustworthy brother, blaming.
You spent time like the suffering old camel... braying in Damascus and not leaving.
And indeed you, in writing to Ali... are like a tanner while the leather has rotted.
If you were the killed one and he was alive... he would have tucked up, neither heavy nor weary.'
So he shook him with this poetry and moved him, and agitated him with it and incited him, until he tucked up his leg (prepared for war), and declared after his hypocrisy. This is the end of Al-Mansur's speech. A group of the Shia narrated that Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, was not demanded of Uthman's blood, despite his innocence of it, and his saying: 'By Allah, I did not kill Uthman nor colluded in his killing,' except by the incitement of Hassan bin Thabit and his saying:
'Would that I knew, and would that the birds inform me... what was between Ali and Ibn Affan.
You will surely hear soon in their lands... Allah is Great, O revenges of Uthman.'
It was said: The cause of Ibn al-Ash'ath's rebellion against Abdul Malik bin Marwan was the poet's saying:
'Is it in Allah [justice] that Bahdal and the son of Bahdal... lives, while the son of Al-Zubayr is killed?'
He said: No, by Allah. And he sought the blood of the family of Al-Zubayr, and from him was what was. Among the curious things I came across regarding the influence of poetry is what some Sheikhs told me, raising it to Ya'la bin Muhammad al-A'raj. The narrator from him said: He told us by dictation from his memory on Wednesday, the fourteenth of Dhu al-Qa'dah in the year four hundred and forty-five, he said: When Al-Walid bin Tarif al-Shari al-Shaybani rebelled and wreaked havoc in the regions of Iraq, the people of Baghdad spread rumors about him, and people talked much. He had no equal to repel his crack and block his breach except his cousin, Yazid bin Mazyad al-Shaybani, his father's brother's son without separation. The Vizier of the Caliphate summoned him and recited to him according to the custom of the Arabs, inciting him and seeking victory through him. What he recited to him was:
'If you are called, you are not called for an easy thing... but for a dilemma that exceeds dilemmas.
Indeed the Caliphate is anchored to a mountain... and you and your son are the corners of that mountain.
Boast, for you have no like in Shayban... likewise Banu Shayban have no like.'
The Vizier began a speech encouraging him in it, and promising him what would be in its folds. Yazid said to him: Stop, O our master, for you have sufficed and been sufficed. He rose, evil having moved him and joy shook him, dragging his trails. He emerged with his group immediately to fight Al-Walid. He met him, and the chase occurred, and dust rose. Allah granted him victory over Al-Walid and he killed him, after Al-Walid was charging at the horses and turning their necks to their rears, raising his voice and calling:
'I am Al-Walid bin Tarif al-Shari... a lion (Qaswara), my fire is not warmed by.
Your injustice drove me out of my house.'
When he fell to the ground, his sister rode, put on her armor, and went out challenging to fight. Yazid, the killer of her brother and her cousin, looked at her and called to her: O Hanah (O you), throw the spear from your hand and return to your tent. You have exposed the free women; this is not a place for women. She planted her spear in the ground, leaned her head on it, and wept. She recited elegizing her brother:
'If it was Yazid bin Mazyad who destroyed him... then many a crawling [army] is afflicted by a crawling [army].
O tree of Khabur, why are you leafy... as if you do not grieve for Ibn Tarif?
We lost him, the loss of spring, so would that we... ransomed him from our elite with thousands.'

'A youth who does not count provision except from piety... nor wealth except from spears and swords.
Nor horses except every short-haired, lean mare... and every stallion, tyrannical with forelegs.'
Then she returned to her tent wailing and mourning her brother with her women. I say: To Allah is the goodness of three verses that carried the man to kill his cousin and cut his kinship ties. Had the speech in the poetry been prose, it would not have shaken him, nor carried him to take his spoil, nor killed his cousin and robbed him. Allah pardons the sinners. Yahya bin Khalid said: A man from Banu Umayya asked me to convey him to Al-Rashid. I said to him: The Commander of the Faithful is deviated from every affiliate to Umayya, and his rage against them and his bad belief in them is famous. If you have a need other than this, I will fulfill it for you. He refused except being conveyed to him. I informed Al-Rashid of his request and my answer to him. He ordered him to be brought. I did not doubt he would end the evening killed. When he stood before him, he recited:
'O Trust of Allah, I am saying... the saying of a possessor of intellect, religion, and manners.
You have merit over us, and we have... by you merit over all Arabs.
Abd Shams was following Hashim... and they are after that from a mother and a father.
So connect the wombs from us, for... Abd Shams is the uncle of Abd al-Muttalib.'
Al-Rashid said to him: You spoke the truth, affected by his saying, and the poetry had worked in his soul. He ordered forty thousand dirhams for him. Yahya said: Were it not for the verses, he would have ordered taking his head. Marwan bin Abi Hafsa narrated, saying: I went out wanting Ma'n bin Za'ida. The road joined me with a Bedouin. I said to him: Where do you want? He said: This Shaybani king. I said: What have you gifted him? He said: Two verses. I said: Only! He said: I have gathered in them what pleases him. I said: Bring them. He recited to me:
'Ma'n bin Za'ida, by whom was increased... honor upon honor the Banu Shayban.
If the days of deeds are counted, then only... his two days are a day of generosity and a day of stabbing.'
He said: And I had a poem I wove on this meter. I said: O you, you come to a man whose entourage has multiplied and poets at his door have multiplied. When will you reach him? He said: So say. I said: You take from me some of what you hoped for with these two verses and return to your saddle. He said: How much do you offer? I said: Fifty dirhams. He said: I would not do it, nor for double. He said: I kept being gentle with him until I offered him one hundred and twenty dirhams. He took them and left. I said: I will be truthful with you. He said: And truthfulness is better for you. I said: I wove a poem balancing this poetry and I want to add these two verses to it. He said: Glory be to Allah, I knew and you feared a matter that will never reach you. So I came to Ma'n bin Za'ida and put the two verses in the middle of the poem and recited it to him. He listened towards me. By Allah, it was only that I reached the two verses and he heard them that he could not control himself but fell from his bedding until he stuck to the ground, then said: Repeat the two verses. I repeated them. He called out: O boy, bring me a bag with a thousand dinars. It was only his word and his bag. He said: Pour it on his head. Then he said: Bring twenty garments from my special clothing, and my beast Such and my mule Such. So I left with the gift of the Bedouin, not the gift of Ma'n. When Abu Tammam al-Ta'i praised Ahmad son of Al-Mu'tasim with his poem beginning:
'There is no harm in your standing for an hour... fulfilling the obligation of the effaced quarters.'
When he reached his saying:
'The daring of Amr, in the generosity of Hatim... in the clemency of Ahnaf, in the intelligence of Iyas.'
One of those present, Ya'qub al-Kindi, said to him: How do you liken the son of the Commander of the Faithful to crude Bedouins while he is nobler in status and greater in position? He was cut off and looked down, then raised his head and recited improvising:
'Do not deny my striking for him those below him... as a parable wandering in generosity and might.
For Allah has struck the lesser for His Light... as a parable from the niche and the lamp.'
He shook with joy for that, and was stunned by it in wonder, and signed for him a governorship in Mosul.

Sharaf al-Dawla Muslim bin Quraysh gifted Mosul to one of his poets and departed from it. It was said to the poet that it would not remain yours, so if you sold it to the Emir's deputies, you would be successful. They bought it from him for twenty thousand dinars. When Sharaf al-Dawla heard of this, he said: Bring him to me. He grabbed his ear and said: Did you receive the money? He said: Yes. He said: And you are satisfied? He said: Yes, by Allah. Then he rubbed his ear and said to him: O cuckold (dayyuth), you sold it cheap. Why did you not hold your hand (insist) and demand one hundred thousand dinars? For they would have had no choice but to pay the money to you. This story is how my father, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated it to me, but he did not mention the poetry nor the poet. He, may Allah have mercy on him, said: My mother's uncle, Muhammad bin Ubaydullah al-Alawi al-Husayni, told me this. He said: Al-Muhadhdhab Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Mushir the Scribe told me this in the months of the year five hundred and thirty-one. Ibn Mushir used to praise the Banu Muslim bin Quraysh and serve them. He narrated to me that Abu al-Qasim al-Hasan bin Hani' al-Maghribi al-Andalusi was a poet for the Banu Marwan in Andalusia. When Al-Mu'izz al-Alawi heard his poetry, he sent for him and brought him to him, desiring literature and competing for the honor of ranks. When he joined his service, he praised him with eulogies, including:
'Love is where the company are enemies.'
And from them:
'Advance a step and retreat a step.'
And from them:
'I say statues, and they are the beautiful, soft women.'
And from them:
'Did he perfume the wind with ambergris?'
And from them:
'He traveled by night while the wing of the night was black, dark.'
And from them:
'Did she visit us at night while the stars were stationary?'
And from them:
'Al-Muhassab became desolate of a guide and of Hayd (camel driver?).'
And from them:
'Are they pearls, the tears of this cloud, or drops?'
And from them:
'These mounts traveled with me and hastened.'
And from them:
'They stood in a funeral gathering over the lovers.'
And from them:
'Is it your scent or a smear of sticking musk?'
And from them:
'We passed by those dwellings of yours.'
And from them:
'Do you think wine in the north wind is cool wind (Shamul)?'
And from them:
'A wide day in boasting, long.'
And from them:
'She stood swaying as a stream pushed.'
And from them:
'She listened and said: The footfall of a short-haired, tall horse.'
And from them:
'She gave me to drink what the mouths of snakes ejected.'
And from them:
'Are there from the canyons of Alij, Yabrin?'
Whenever he praised him with a poem, he gave him an estate. When his slave Jawhar went out and took Egypt, Al-Mu'izz went out. When he sat for congratulations, Ibn Hani' entered upon him and asked his permission to recite. He permitted him, so he recited a poem from which he says:
'Indeed, the days are your days which... for you is half of their blessings and for us the half.'
He turned to his minister and said: Write for him Alexandria and hand it over to him with whoever is in it, for it is a half we have allocated to him. Thus were the prizes of poets. Al-Ahwas was given twenty thousand dinars for his saying:
'My money was not new gain from trade... nor was it inheritance of money inherited.
But a gift from a blessed Imam... who filled the earth with kindness, generosity, and sovereignty.'
These are famous verses, and I do not think any of the shortcomings of the poets of the time are incapable of saying the like of them. Zuhair had reached the utmost in praising Harim bin Sinan bin Haritha until the Arabs struck the proverb with Harim in generosity because of Zuhair's saying:
'Indeed the miser is blamed wherever he is, but... the generous one, despite his defects, is Harim.
He is the generous one who gives you his gift... easily, and is wronged sometimes, so he bears injustice.'
The people of knowledge of poetry agreed that the most praising thing the Arabs said is Zuhair's saying:
'The seekers of good from Harim have made... and the askers, to his doors, roads.
If you meet Harim one day despite his conditions... you meet tolerance from him and generosity as a character.'
Harim was excessive in his giving and spending on him until Harim swore that he would not greet Zuhair unless he gave him money and camels. So Zuhair stopped greeting Harim, sparing him and out of shame for his excessive giving. Zuhair used to pass by the assembly and say: 'Good morning to you, except Harim, and your best I left.' Thus poets used to be ashamed of the gifts of the praised and the benevolence of the benefactors, as Al-Ma'arri said:

'If you shortened the benevolence, I would visit you... for sweet water is abandoned for excessive coldness.'
When Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Muhammad al-Tihami entered upon Hassan bin Jarrah al-Ta'i, the ruler of Sham, he recited to him his poem which begins:
'Is passion anything but that her tents appear... so their protection decrees the offering of peace?'
When he reached his saying:
'Indeed Tayy is a Kaaba for noble deeds... and Hassan is of it its corner and station (Maqam).
The lands are little for you as a kingdom, and their people... as slaves, so is its Sham considered much for you?'
He gifted him the city of Hama and its districts. From the effect of poetry on proud souls is that Al-Zahir in Egypt had removed Abu al-Qasim Ibn al-Maghribi from his ministry. He separated from the Egyptian lands and connected with the lands of Mayyafariqin. After Al-Maghribi, he appointed Ali bin Ahmad al-Jarjara'i as minister. Al-Maghribi used to continue [sending] gifts and kindnesses to Al-Tihami until he came to him and praised him with a poem beginning:
'My heart is a ransom for it, from domes... circling on the mirage like bubbles.'
Then he said in it:
'So who will convey to Egypt a saying that generalizes... and specifies the turbaned King?
You were a pearl in his crown... so the claw was substituted in its place.
If his place is blocked, it is not blocked... and if the like of it is substituted, it is not substituted.
When the lion is estranged from his thicket... the sheep becomes in it licking the grass.
I came to you praising for affection... and I did not come praising for property.'
His saying reached Al-Jarjara'i, so he did not cease employing tricks until Al-Tihami came to Egypt, so he imprisoned him and his imprisonment was long. He has many poems he said in his prison regretting his coming and apologizing for the slip of his composition. From that:
'Blame yourself, no excuse, the excuse has run out... with this the Destined ruled when the matter was decreed.'
He says in it:
'I committed a crime against myself by my striving to them... and I have no excuse from their most faithful covenants.
I have no sin except poetry, for I... indeed know that the sin in my calamity is poetry.
A captive with people without a crime... indeed, in the way of Allah is what the matter (command) did.'
He has from another:
'O he whom the tongue of poetry announced his death... and like aloeswood he spreads from his scent.
It is hard on Time what you are in... even if what is with you of its vicissitudes is great.
And the saying of one who persisted in his violence doubled my passion... when I was imprisoned.
He says—and some speech of the fool... kills if he does not hide it—
Is this Al-Tihami from Mecca... striving with his feet to his death?
Did it not suffice him that the robe of life... was ample on him, did it not suffice him?
He wanted to fly the flight of kings... and thought the spearheads were of his feathers.
Is it with poetry, woe to you, you seek loftiness... while you fall short of its construction?
And you were not worthy to settle... on the pulpit of the kingdom or its edge.
Because you are rarer (less) than a poet... despite the baseness of poetry in his description.
You shed blood you long protected... and ignited ember and did not extinguish it.
And you were on the brink waiting for ruin... while your chest is hot, you did not heal it.
When the wood dries of its water... that is more inviting to its breaking.'
When his imprisonment prolonged, Al-Jarjara'i signaled to his boy Labib to kill him in his prison. So Labib entered upon him at night and strangled him. Were it not for poetry, he would not have been affected by it an effect that carried him to kill a soul and eternal abode in the fire of Hell.

Ibn Nasr, the ruler of Aleppo, did not cease corresponding with Ibn Hayyus al-Dimashqi, connecting him with gifts, grants, and kindnesses until he brought him to him and had him visit. When he approached Aleppo, he went out in his procession and received him, honored him, greeted him, and lodged him in his guest house. After days, he sat in the Citadel of Aleppo a public sitting and permitted his deputies, emirs, companions, and ministers. When people settled in their ranks, he summoned him and seated him before him. He recited to him his poem which he says in its beginning:
'Stop in hate where you ended blaming... and do not follow one who was unjust when he ruled.'
He called for a bag containing a thousand dinars and poured it on him, so the attendees picked it up. Then he called for another bag containing a thousand dinars, twenty garments, a splendid robe of honor, and a horse with a gold collar and gold bridle (Sirfasar), and gave it to him and wrote for him an estate from the mothers of villages in Aleppo. These were the prizes of poets. Fakhr al-Mulk Abu Ghalib bin Khalaf al-Wasiti, when he entered Baghdad during the days of his vizierates for Baha' al-Dawla bin Adud al-Dawla, strove for Ibn Nubata al-Sa'di to praise him, but he did not do so and said to him: 'Ahmad bin Ishaq—meaning Al-Qadir Billah—forbade me from praising anyone but him.' When his speech reached Al-Qadir, and that he did not express him as Imam or Commander of the Faithful, nor increased upon naming him and attributing him, he tolerated that from him despite his refusal, given what he had of competition and strictness in the like of it. Then Fakhr al-Mulk reached out to Al-Qadir and approached him with types of closeness, and asked him to permit Ibn Nubata to praise him. He apologized to him and refused him, saying: 'It was not for the poet of the Caliphate to praise other than it.' When the desire became difficult for Fakhr al-Mulk, he set Ibn Hajib al-Nu'man who forged upon Ibn Nubata and said: 'The Commander of the Faithful has prescribed for you to praise the Vizier Fakhr al-Mulk.' So he attended complying with the command. When Fakhr al-Mulk saw him, he stood up for him, raised his seat, improved his prize, and gave him of clothes and gold what no poet like him was given. Look at the competition of this Vizier in earning praise, his trickery to obtain commendation from the literati, and the might of that with the Imam Caliphs, may Allah be pleased with them. Thus were the desires of the chiefs in the literati. My father, may Allah be pleased with him, told me, saying: Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Ubaydullah al-Alawi al-Husayni told me, saying: Abu al-Mafakhir al-Abhari told me, saying: Abu Ya'la Ibn al-Habbaria al-Hashimi told me, saying: Abu Sa'd al-Ala' bin al-Hasan bin Mawsilaya, the scribe of the Caliphate's presence, told me, saying: When I wrote a letter on behalf of Ra'is al-Ru'asa', I was cautious, guarded, and diligent, and I hardly escaped his criticism, his taking and rejecting. But I have become such that when I write a letter on behalf of Ibn Jahir, I let myself go in it and do not observe anything of its words and meanings. When I present it to him, he takes it and weighs it with his hand. If he finds it heavy and large, he says: 'O my son, may Allah bless you, this is a good letter in which you honored and magnified him.' And if he finds its size small, and deems its lines and writing little, he looks at me askance and says: 'Perhaps you are not pleased, or is this for lack of whiteness (paper)?' Ibn al-Habbaria recited for himself:
'So say to a Vizier whose criticism of his letter... is by its papers in weight and counting its lines.
Perhaps a time whose Vizier we complained of... returns to us today the like of its Vizier.'
Look how much is between Fakhr al-Mulk and his ambition, and between Ibn Jahir and his commonness and craft. Bishr bin Abi Khazim al-Asadi had satirized Aws bin Haritha the King unjustly; Banu Badr al-Fazaris incited him to satirize him. Then Bishr raided Tayy' in a cavalry of his people. He raided Banu Nabhan and was wounded and weakened while he was that day protecting his companions. Banu Nabhan captured him and hid him, disliking that his news reach Aws. Aws heard that he was with them, so he corresponded with them to hand him over to him, but they hid him. He swore to take him, and they feared he would kill him. When they refused, he gave them two hundred camels, so they handed him over to his messengers. Some of them said to him while he was tied on a camel: 'O Bishr, sing to us,' for people had already sung about what Aws would do to you. While they were threatening him, he scolded the birds and wild animals (took omens) and saw what he liked, so he said:
'Do you not see the birds next to the livestock... and the caravan and the herd in the valley of Salam?
Safety and a blessing from the blessings.'
One of the messengers answered:

'Indeed you, O Bishr, are possessor of illusion and concern... in your scolding the birds upon the trace of regret.
Rejoice in a falling like the downpour of drizzle... and cutting of your hands, and it will be doubled with the foot.
And with the tongue after it and with the nose... indeed Ibn Su'da is possessor of punishment and vengeance.'
When they brought him, Aws said to him: 'You satirized me unjustly. So choose between cutting your tongue and imprisoning you in a burrow until you die, or cutting your hands and feet and releasing your way.' Then he entered upon his mother Su'da, and she had heard his speech. She said to him: 'O my son, your father died and I hoped you for your people generally, and I have become—by Allah—not hoping you for yourself specifically. Woe to you! Did you claim that you are cutting a poet man? And when were poets treated with other than kindness? If you claimed that he satirized you, then who will erase what he said about you?' He said: 'So what should I do with him?' She said: 'You clothe him in your robe, carry him on your mount, and order one hundred she-camels for him; perhaps he will wash his satire with his praise.' He went out from her, released his way, treated him well, and did multiples of what his mother ordered him. So Bishr praised him abundantly, and washed away the filth and dirt from him. Al-Akhfash said: Bishr praised Aws and his family with a poem in place of every poem he satirized them with. He had satirized them with five, so he praised them with five. Of that is his chosen poem:
'Suffice with the distance from Asma' a sufficient... and there is no cure for her love as it prolonged.'
The matter was as his mother said, for Bishr erased his blame with his praise. In this chapter, from the effect of poetry and the roars of angry lions, there is much that causes wondrous wonder. In what we have presented is sufficiency for those of intellect.

**Chapter Four**
**On Revealing What It Was Praised For and Blamed Because Of**
**And Whether Engaging in It Is More Reforming, or Rejecting It Is More Abundant and Weightier**

As for the praise of poetry on the tongue of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the tongues of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them all, it is abundant and plentiful. None denies that except one inexperienced, poor in literature. In following them and tracking their method is guidance whose traveler does not stray, a cradle whose owner is not displaced, a fire-stick whose striker does not fail, and a supply whose drawer is not exhausted. From that is his saying, peace be upon him: '...from poetry is surely wisdom', and in another place: 'Indeed from poetry is surely wisdoms.' This is his saying, and he, peace be upon him, does not speak from desire, after Allah Almighty said regarding David, peace be upon him: 'And We gave him wisdom and decisive speech.' And He Almighty said: 'And Lot, We gave him judgment and knowledge.' So he, peace be upon him, made some poetry a part of wisdom with which Allah Almighty singled out His prophets and described His chosen ones. He bestowed it upon them as He made them singled out with it from Him, and immersed in its pride from His side. That is sufficient for you as a virtue for poetry and poets, and a merit by which the status of literature and literati became great. And he, peace be upon him, said to Hassan bin Thabit: 'You are Hassan and your tongue is Husam (a sharp sword).' This speech is from the chapter of Aspiring Paronomasia. Were it not for poetry, he would not have made his tongue a Husam metaphorically, for its penetration in speech and the fear of its biting words, just as the Husam penetrates in the struck object and its edges are feared at calamity. He, peace be upon him, also said to Hassan: 'Answer on my behalf; O Allah, support him with the Holy Spirit.' Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, placed a pulpit for Hassan in the mosque to defend him with poetry upon it. And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, says: 'Indeed Allah Almighty supports Hassan with the Holy Spirit.' And he said to him: 'Satirize them,' or he said: 'Mock them and Gabriel is with you.' Aisha narrated that she heard the Messenger of Allah, upon him be blessings and peace, saying to Hassan: 'Indeed the Holy Spirit does not cease to support you as long as you defend Allah Almighty and His Messenger, upon him be peace.' Ibn Abi Buraydah narrated in what he attributed, saying: Gabriel, peace be upon him, aided Hassan bin Thabit in his praise of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, with seventy verses; and there is a look (doubt) in it. In other than a report, he, peace be upon him, said to Hassan: 'Stir the chiefs against Banu Abd Manaf; by Allah, your poetry is harder on them than the falling of arrows in the darkness of night.'

It was narrated that when Quraysh satirized the Ansar, they came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and asked his permission to satirize them. He permitted them. They came to Ka'b bin Malik, who was a describer of war. He made a poem. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to them: 'He did nothing.' They came to Abdullah bin Rawaha, who was a describer of Paradise. He said a poem, and they brought it to the Prophet, peace be upon him. He said: 'He did nothing.' They came to Hassan bin Thabit. He said: 'I was not to do it until the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, orders me.' Hassan was the most knowledgeable of people about the satire of Quraysh in Jahiliyya. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to him: 'O Hassan, Abu Sufyan has satirized me, and his kinship to me is what you know. So how will you do?' He said: 'O Messenger of Allah, I will surely extract you from him as a hair is extracted from dough.' He said to him: 'Do you have poetry, O Hassan?' He stuck out his tongue, and behold it was like the tail of a snake. He said to him: 'Go, for Gabriel is with you.' Among what Hassan satirized Abu Sufyan with was his saying:
'And you are attached, attached in the family of Hashim... as the single cup is attached behind the rider.'
He, peace be upon him, said: 'I ordered Abdullah bin Rawaha, and he spoke and did well. I ordered Ka'b bin Malik, and he spoke and did well. And I ordered Hassan bin Thabit, so he healed and was healed.' Abdullah bin Abbas said: 'Learn poetry, for it is the first knowledge of the Arabs and it is the register (Diwan) of literature. And stick to the poetry of the people of Hijaz, for it is the poetry of Jahiliyya and it has been pardoned.' Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'Memorize poems and read news (history), for poetry calls to noble morals, teaches beautiful deeds, incites to beautiful actions, opens up acumen, sharpens the mind, urges the building of virtues and storing of nobilities, forbids base morals, deters from falling into suspicions, and encourages the meanings of ranks.' Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'Teach your children poetry, for it teaches them noble morals.' Al-Rashid advised Al-Kisa'i regarding Al-Amin and Al-Ma'mun, and among his advice was: 'And quench them with poetry, for it is the most fulfilling literature that urges to high ranks.' Muawiyah said: 'Teach your children poetry, for I attained the Caliphate, gained leadership, and reached this status through the verses of Ibn al-Itnaba. For on the Day of al-Harir, whenever I resolved to flee, I recited his saying:
"My chastity refused for me, and my trial refused... and my taking praise for a profitable price.
And my saying whenever it (soul) heaved and agitated... in your place, you will be praised or you will rest."
So I stood firm and said: In your place, you will be protected or you will rest.' When Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf came to Iraq, he shunned poets with a shunning whose news reached Abdul Malik bin Marwan. He wrote to him: 'In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. From Abdullah Abdul Malik to Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf. As for what follows: A matter about you has reached me that belied my physiognomy in you and disappointed my opinion of you, which is your turning away from poetry and poets. For you do not know the virtue of poetry nor do you know the places of poets' speech and the impacts of their arrows. Do you not know, O brother of Thaqif, that by poetry is the permanence of mention and the growth of pride? And that poets are the embroidery of the kingdom, the ornaments of the state, the titles of blessing, the amulets of glory, and the proofs of generosity? And that they urge to beautiful actions and forbid blameworthy characters? And that they established the path of nobilities for its seekers and guided the seekers of praises to its doors? And that kindness to them is generosity, and turning away from them is meanness and regret? So rectify the excess of your negligence, and erase with your correctness the suggestion of your errors.'

From the virtue of poetry is that scholars of literature cannot compose a single verse of it, given the lack of nature in composing it and the gift from Allah Almighty in compiling it, due to His Almighty's saying: (And We did not teach him poetry, nor is it befitting for him). He attributed teaching it to Himself, Glory be to Him, and made it among His gifts to the creature and His adornment with which He clothes whom He wills, as He Almighty said: (He increases in creation what He wills). Were it not that this merit, and the sublime virtue, is a gift from Allah Almighty, it would not have been difficult for scholars despite their knowledge of its tools and their grasp of the reins of its instruments, and easy for one empty of literature, and lean in the pastures of that slope, so that he says what he does not know its reasoning, and composes what he is ignorant of its branches and roots. From the virtue of poetry is that prose speech, even if its brocade pleases and its splendor is delicate, its words are beautiful, and its sources are sweet, if the camel-driver recites it, and the singer brings it, and the entertainer extends his voice with it, and the reciter raises his voice with it, it does not move a grave person, nor console a sad one, nor reveal an ambush from hearts, nor betray a trustworthy tear. But if it is transformed itself into verse, and marked with meter a mark, it enters ears without hindrance, and possesses hearts as bondmaids are possessed in wars, and grips limbs like splints grip wounds. How many a soul regained itself by it, and how many a lifeblood it took and snatched, and how many a noble it revived and a mean one it destroyed, and how many a poor one it enriched, and how many a rich one it emptied. A virtue that belongs only to it forever. Poetry is a mine of preference and inimitability; it encourages the cowardly weak, so he has no flight nor recoil. The miser gives generously even if weary, and the old man acts youthfully even if aged. Its miracles are apparent, and its signs are coming and going. As for he who went to blaming it and diminishing it due to his bad understanding, he is only holding onto doubts he did not know their interpretation, relying on arguments he did not know their reasoning, stumbling in a dark night blindly, involved in wading a painful rugged path. That which the blamer held onto is his saying, peace be upon him: (That the belly of one of you be filled with pus until it consumes him is better for him than to be filled with poetry). Pus (Qayh): pus not mixed with blood. Yarihi: from Wary, and the noun is Wara with movement (vowel), and from it is the supplication: May Allah Almighty inflict Wara and the fever of Khaybar on him. It is said 'Wara al-qayh jawfahu yarihi waryan' if it ate it. Abd bin al-Hashas said:
'My Lord caused them Wary (consumed them) like what they caused me... and heated the cauteries upon their livers.'
This is a hadith that testifies for itself that he, peace be upon him, intended by it a specific time, and singled out specific people with it, and did not permit it absolutely. The proof of that is what he praised poetry with and aggrandized it because of, and the fact that he, peace be upon him, heard poetry in Rajaz and Qasid, asked for it to be recited, quoted it broken in meter, and in a narration: correct in meter, and ordered buying it by satirizing whoever satirized him, and urged it and called for it. He has famous poets from the Ansar and others. Not one of his Companions remained but said poetry, little or much, recited and asked for recitation, quoted it and argued with it, wrote and corresponded. If it is established that it is for specific people, and invalidated that it is for generality and absoluteness, interpreting it would be a form of affectation. There is no harm in mentioning some of what scholars interpreted it with. From that is what Al-Kalbi narrated from Abu Salih from Abu Hurayra from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: (That the belly of one of you be filled with pus until it consumes him is better for him than to be filled with poetry with which I was satirized). And in the hadith of Aisha, may Allah Almighty be pleased with her, regarding the mutual satire of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. We said: This hadith is not authentic for several reasons: Among them: That Al-Kalbi has been criticized by the scholars of Hadith, and his saying is not trusted by them. Among them is that memorizing a single verse of what the Prophet, peace be upon him, was satirized with, its pus consumes and its ugliness does not hide, let alone the belly being filled with it.

And among them is that if he intended by it the satire of his noble self, he would have declared the disbelief of the one uttering it, let alone the one memorizing it filling his belly with it; for there is no disagreement among Muslims that whoever insults the Messenger of Allah has disbelieved, and insulting is part of satire. Since that is invalid, the intended meaning is blaming one whose habit is memorizing soft poems and subtle satires until that distracts him from knowing what is obligatory upon him of his religious affairs and reforming his worldly life. It was said: He only meant the poets of the enemies of Allah and enemies of His Messenger who satirized and defamed the honors of his Companions, and elegized the killed polytheists at Badr and elsewhere, eulogizing them and mentioning their virtue. Since memorizing that is of the base impurities, he, peace be upon him, countered it with pus which the soul loathes and nature flees from, exaggerating in its filthiness. Ahmad bin Hanbal, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said: What is disliked of poetry is only satire and the soft (erotic) in which women are courted, so the hearts of youths are stirred by it. As for other than that, how beneficial it is. Al-Nadr said: How can our bellies be filled—meaning with poetry—while in them are the Quran, Fiqh, Hadith, and other things? This was only in Jahiliyya, but today, no. The blamer of poetry and poets held onto His Almighty's saying: (And the poets - [only] the deviators follow them. Do you not see that in every valley they roam? And that they say what they do not do?). The answer to that is that the one holding onto that argued with has no knowledge of the meanings of the Glorious Quran, for this verse is specific to the poets of Jahiliyya. It was narrated from Ikrimah that he said: The meaning of this verse is that two poets engaged in mutual satire in Jahiliyya, and with each one of them was a group of people following him, memorizing from him what he invented. It was narrated from Al-Hasan regarding His Almighty's saying: (Do you not see that in every valley they roam) that he said: We have seen their valleys in which they used to roam, sometimes in praise and sometimes in satire. It was narrated from Ibn Mujahid that he said: They roam in every art they master of the arts of poetry. It was said regarding His Almighty's saying: (And that they say what they do not do), meaning they claim against themselves that they killed while they did not kill, and fornicated while they did not do, and similar things... The sayings of the commentators on that are numerous and famous, and there is no dispute regarding the restriction of the verse to the poets of Jahiliyya such that we expand speech on that. Then from the ignorance of the one arguing against poets with this verse is his not knowing whom was excepted in it, reciting its beginning and forgetting its end, which is His Almighty's saying: (Except those who believe and do righteous deeds and remember Allah much and defend themselves after they were wronged). Those who believe are the Mukhadramun who were in Jahiliyya and Islam reached them, so their faith was good. Then He Almighty described them with doing righteous deeds when they answered the Caller of the Messenger and followed his straight Sunnah and stopped at his commands and prohibitions. He praised them for remembering Allah Almighty much, and mentioned their weighty dreams (forbearance) by His saying: (And defend themselves after they were wronged). For when Quraysh satirized them and provoked them, and started them with harm and angered them, they asked permission of the Messenger, peace be upon him, so he permitted them to take revenge on them. How did he leave mentioning these and what Allah Almighty described them with, and argue with the mention of the poets of Jahiliyya, were it not for deviation from the truth and bewilderment in those paths.

The blamer of poetry and poets held onto the saying of who said: Poetry is the vilest food eaten, the most obscene craft practiced, the filthiest arrow touched, and the cheapest garment worn, because the saying of its poet is falsehood, his praise is deception, his wording is immorality, and he is heavy, abandoned. If he is far, his harm is feared, and if he is near, his injury is not safe. The utmost a poet does when he runs in his field, unleashes the rein of his tongue, stretches in speech with his effort, armors himself in description with his seriousness, celebrates reaching his goal with whom he begs, and throws himself to the furthest of his desire with whom he frequents and seeks, is to differentiate in describing a camel, prolong in questioning a ruin, weep over an effaced trace, stand and ask to stand on stirred ashes, saddle the she-camels and he-camels, describe crossing deserts and traversing sands, mention arriving at brackish waters, and accompanying ghouls and demonesses in those road-mouths. What mind is less, and opinion more unjust and astray, than the mind of a man who sets himself up to hear that, and the opinion of a poet who tired himself and exhausted his sense in describing cows and asking stones? Then, if the poet composes a piece, and snatches a meaning, he belittles the first generation of poets, and despises Al-Khalil and Al-Mufaddal among scholars. He has nothing but gleams he took from the bellies of books and misread from the texts of pages. He did not graduate to knowing literature by long companionship nor old practice. If companionship is not long, the place [of knowledge] is not known. Knowledge has a secret; whoever falls short of its place is not counted among its brethren. How many a poet, he who bestowed favor upon him and treated him well was afflicted by him, so he countered benevolence with offense, favor with revenge, and good deed with ugly waste, until he made him taste after the sweetness of his praises the bitterness of his satire, and made him swallow the chokings of his defamation and the sting of his blame, breaking what he concluded, demolishing what he built, and belying himself in what he presented. No disdain turns him away from it, no shame deters him, no religion curbs him, and no piety restrains him. How many a noble of both sides, high of grandparents, pure of lineage, sound of ancestry, great of ranks, noble of mother and father, has he slandered with satire: base in his lineage, mean in claiming a father other than his father, low in his worth, contemptible in his affair. How many a free, noble, chaste, trustworthy, veiled, protected woman has satire torn her veil, and uncovered her cover, so shame encompassed her, and disgrace befell her; she cannot bear defense for that nor find prevention from it. What calamity is greater and tragedy more painful than a poet shooting the sanctity of a benefactor to him with his slander, and branding the side of a favor-giver to him with his defamation, so the shame of his satire sticks to him like the ring of the dove, until the Day of Judgment. The poet is only honored out of fear of his evil, and caution of his foul tongue, lack of religion, and absence of chivalry. He, peace be upon him, said: (The worst of people is he who is honored out of fear of his evil). Whenever a poet recites to you a satire with which he tore the honor of a Muslim, or presents to you an insult with which he slandered the sanctity of an innocent submissive one, he only intended by that to show you his venom, make you taste his poisons, teach you how he notches his arrows, frighten you with his brand, and warn you of his cautery. How many a generous one poetry made miserly, a pure-blooded one in his people it left an intruder, a brave one it made cowardly, and a trustworthy one it left treacherous. Do you not see Abu Nuwas and the kindness of Banu Barmak to him, his approach with praises to them, and their approach with gifts to him? Among his sayings about them:
'Peace be upon the world if there are not in it... Banu Barmak among goers and comers.'
People generally knew the fame of Banu Barmak for generosity and their specialization in giving what is available. Abu Nuwas was not ashamed of their kindness to him and people's belying him until he branded them with miserliness, and called them stingy, violating the consensus about them, and denying their favor to him, until he said among his satire of them:
'Banu Barmak, of meanness and miserliness you are... worthy, but it might be said: Impossible.'
He satirized Ja'far:
'If other than miserliness came from Ja'far... they would not have brought him down from it except for stupidity.
I see Ja'far increasing in meanness and pettiness... when the Merciful increases him in the ample provision.'
Likewise Abu Nuwas did with Al-Khasib. After his saying about him:

'If our mounts do not visit the land of Al-Khasib... then which youth after Al-Khasib will they visit?'
He says:
'Al-Khasib's bread is hung by the star... protected by every straightened and lined [spear/sword].'
This is Abu al-Tayyib [Al-Mutanabbi] who came to Kafur al-Ikhshidi seeking gifts, and arrived to him showering him with praise and eulogy. From his saying about him:
'Intenders of Kafur, leavers of other than him... and whoever intends the sea belittles the streams.'
