When Kafur continued his gifts to him and was excessive in giving his money and grants to him, he turned back on him with blame, blowing into the mouth of his honor the killers of his poison. He, peace be upon him, said: (It is forbidden for the malicious soul to leave the abode of the world until it does evil to one who did good to it). When Abu al-Tayyib was asked about the reason for his blaming Kafur, he claimed that he prevented him from seeking kings, and spilling the water of his face before the rich and the poor, and guaranteed him compensation for what ambitions imagined in that purpose. He could not argue with a shortcoming issued from Kafur. So is this a sin for which he deserved that he say after that praise in him:
'Who taught the castrated black man a noble deed... his white people or his noble fathers?'
If we counted those of the poets who did that, and those of them who countered kindness with blame and satire, we would write books on that, and cite from it curious wonders. This is the cream of one who churned his skin bag in blaming poetry and poets, and casting it and them away in estrangement in the open. We will mention the answer to that briefly, Allah Almighty willing.

**The Answer, and with Allah is success:**
Know, O blamer—may Allah Almighty reform you—that the truth is other than what you aimed for, and sincerity is other than what you fraternized. Whoever disputes in a matter and does not appeal to a judge other than himself, will not attain the proof of his arguments and the uncovering of his confusion. Whoever Satan beautified for him a matter in his seclusions so he was pleased with it, and his desire lured him for a purpose so ignorance led him to it, ceased not to be in a place of error from the truth and dark confusion in those paths. Self-admiration with opinion is the bane of the intellect, and hearts with desires are quick to turn; especially if they do not have a leader of insight from fairness, nor a helper of support from guidance. And they did not have for their crookedness a straightener or corrector, nor in their ignorance a guide or teacher. Whoever is pleased with something hates its opposite, argues for his falsehood with his effort, resents what opposes him, denies of it what he knew, is a builder for what was demolished of it, a binder for what strayed of its beauties, and deviating, turning away from what appeared of its evils. What you are upon is not of justice, nor is what you went to of fairness. Knowledge is other than what you imagined, and literature is not as you claimed. Indeed, knowledge is of impregnable sanctuary, difficult ascent, not attained by wishes, nor reached by ease. None will enjoy it except he who loved it for itself and its preciousness, sought it for its essence and pleasure, and loved it for its eye and merit. It was his companion in loneliness, his second in solitude; he multiplies with it in paucity, and finds glory with it in the state of humiliation. It will not give you part of it until you give it your all, and it will not accompany you until you throw yourself upon it. Perhaps with that, its aim is difficult for you, its attainment far from your hand. Do you not see it when he who is not of it entered it, and was satisfied with its name without its eye and body, how its splendor went, its luster sank, its freshness changed, its sunan were suspended, its path obliterated, its worth belittled, its matter disdained, its traces cast away, its quarters became desolate, its conditions broken, innovations introduced in it, and abominations appeared in it? Like the saying of the first:
'When people claimed knowledge equal... like cattle loaded with books.
Its cheerfulness sank and its bearer became angry... and the garden withered from it and was clothed in shame.'

You must, O blamer, know that poetry is speech, and in speech is the good and the bad, what earns reward and what brings punishment, what Paradises are bought with and what Fires are purchased with. So how can blame be launched on all, and the high be taken with the low, and dislike specific to some be attached to all poetry? He, peace be upon him, said: (Poetry is speech; its good is like good speech, and its ugly is like ugly speech). Know that poets are humans, and among humans are the righteous and the wicked, the wise and the ignorant, the praised and the blamed. It is not of reason and justice that we find in a man a blameworthy trait so we blame because of it everyone named by his name, and everyone attributed to his origin and root, and everyone entering his craft, and everyone counted in his group. Is it proper for the wise intelligent one to see a scribe making solecisms, bad in handwriting, mistaken in his vowels and dots, so he blames for his sake every scribe, and distances for hatred of him every record keeper and accountant? Is the doer of that counted among the legally responsible? No, by Allah, nor in the group of the achievers. Likewise, every craft, if one excels in it and does well, not all its people deserve praise; just as if one falls short in it and errs, blame is not attached to all its people. Rather, it is of justice and fairness, and the traits of the noble and honorable, that everything be given its share, and every possessor of a portion be fulfilled his right. So praise is attached to its owners and blame to its companions, as He, Glory be to Him and Exalted, said regarding who deserves praise: (Excellent is the servant, indeed he was repeatedly turning back [to Allah]). And He Almighty said regarding who deserves blame: (Cruel, after all that, base-born). A human should not be dragged with his desire to an end that throws him into his destruction. Know, O blamer, that poetry is a rare, noble craft whose mention is immortalized for the eternity of time, and its pride remains for the duration of eternity. Whoever did not run in the field of composition, and did not excel in the bet of skill and understanding, and the exercise of poetry did not train his nature, and the dissonance of rhymes did not rub his mind the rubbing of leather, and meanings refuse him the refusal of the difficult unruly [camel], and sweet fresh words are difficult for him the difficulty of the slow exhausted [camel], and returning the stray [meanings] of his intentions is hard for him, and exiting from the set pattern and limited bound to other varieties of descriptions and similes is impossible for him, did not know the realities of poetry and the subtleties of meanings, and did not know whether its sayer deserves praise or blame, unless he is an imitator not a critic. As for the Arabs' description of dwellings and traces, their standing at ruins and remains, and likening women to gazelles and wild cows, to other descriptions of road-mouths and ravines, dozing and night travel, they are excused in that, not blamed, because they ran in it on the sunan of the predecessors and the custom of those who advanced among them. They did not describe, characterize, liken, praise, and blame except what was in front of their eyes; they do not see other than it, nor suffer other than it. For every people there is a sunnah by which they guide themselves, and a way upon which they hover and to which they aim. Whoever lost that among them was outside his doctrine, opposing his nature, falling from behind his limit. Just as the Muwallad among poets, if he leaves the descriptions of straight statures, beautiful cheeks, moist glances, sweet words, and likening to roses, incense, dunes, moist branches and the like, and engages in descriptions of dwellings, traces, channels, wells, the water-camel, the large bucket, the rope, the strap and the ropes, and other things, would be outside his state, opposing his doctrine and his men, disapproved in what he brings of that, affected in what he fabricates of it. For every people there is a doctrine that befits them and is appreciated from them. The first who legislated that and established it for the Arabs so they followed him, and opened its door for them so they stormed and entered it, was Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr. The Bedouins appreciated his descriptions and similes, walked his path, and accepted his doctrine and saying.

So know that, O blamer, and beware of exposing yourself to blame a majestic virtue that has been praised on the tongue of the Master of Mankind, and the Noblest of Mudar, or to attain from a man of letters possessed of a peculiarity whose degree is not ascended and whose physiognomy is not feared. How many a high one was lowered, and a mighty one was humiliated and submitted, by his transgression against the literati and his diminishing the stations of the virtuous. And [how many] a building was demolished, a authority lost, a conjunction passed, a law abrogated, and a tight knot untied, while the landmarks of poetry are standing not bent, its flags spread not folded, its gardens lush not empty, its branches leafy not withered. It makes the fool forbearing, beautifies the noble, sheds blood and spares it, lowers honors and fortifies them, brings distant wishes near and distances them, and distances wide demands and brings them near. It benefits and harms, displeases and pleases, removes and appoints, impoverishes and enriches:
'Who has seen in mankind a quality... that brings a distant one near and distances a near one?
It kills and revives with its sayings... and impoverishes an opponent and enriches a beloved.'
As for our saying at the beginning of the chapter: Is engaging in it more reforming or rejecting it more abundant and weightier? The answer: How can leaving virtues be better than engaging in them, and avoiding merits be more reforming than continuing their highness? We have not known anyone of humans who was able to compose poetry and was proficient in it, and left that, and was not famous for it and attributed to it, unless he was deficient in it, a silent last one from the forerunners. So it is permissible that he leaves it for his inability in it, and the running out of his good [poetry] from it. As was transmitted about Al-Ma'mun when it was said to him: Why do you not compose poetry? He said: Its good refuses me and I refuse its bad. Despite this, he has many famous poems. If we enumerated who engaged in composing poetry among the Caliphs, Kings, Emirs, Viziers, Judges, Ascetics, Commanders, Scholars, and Nobles, we would single out for it a book whose number is great and whose volume is heavy. Even a group of the kings of Banu Buwayh bribed a group of poets so they composed poems for them, attributed them to themselves, and recorded them on their tongues; because of what lies in that of high status, beautiful trait, majestic merit, and noble virtue. Were it not for that, they would not have adorned themselves with its ornaments nor decorated themselves with its robes.

Many poems were narrated from a group of the Companions, to the extent that they compiled a Diwan for the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, and narrated good poems in it. As for the Prophet, peace be upon him, Allah Almighty said regarding him: (And We did not teach him poetry, nor is it befitting for him). This is to be more eloquent in proof against those who claimed he is a soothsayer, and once a sorcerer, and once (a poet for whom we await a misfortune of time), (And they said, "Legends of the former peoples which he has asked to be written down"), and they said (Muddled dreams; rather, he invented it; rather, he is a poet). So Allah Almighty prevented him from poetry as an honor to him since poetry was the habit of the people of his era in which he was sent. It was forbidden to him as an indication of his truthfulness and a testimony to the falsehood of the saying of the invalidators regarding him, and as a purification for him from their fabrication against him, and an increase in proof for him. He sent down upon him the Glorious Quran which (Falsehood cannot approach from before it or from behind it), which if humans and jinn gathered to bring the like of it, even if they assisted one another, they would not bring it. So he, peace be upon him, proceeded to challenge them group by group to bring the like of it, but they could not. If it were poetry and he demanded the like of it from them, it would have been easy for them, and present with them. His prevention, peace be upon him, from poetry was nothing but a virtue, a benefit, an honor, and a purification. There is no deficiency or shame on poetry by that. If everything Allah Almighty prevented him from so that the invalidators would not doubt was a deficiency for that art, writing would have been a deficiency when Allah made him unlettered, neither writing nor reading; to be stronger in cause, higher in status, and more famous in place. Therefore Allah Almighty said: (And you did not recite before it any scripture, nor did you inscribe one with your right hand. Otherwise the falsifiers would have had [cause for] doubt). If preventing him from poetry was a blame and deficiency for poetry and poets, preventing him from writing would be a blame and deficiency for writing and scribes. God forbid that a sane person says that, while Allah Almighty says: (Recite, and your Lord is the most Generous - Who taught by the pen). And He Almighty said: (Noble writers) meaning the angels. Allah Almighty made the people of the house of His Messenger, peace be upon him, his companions, and his brothers scribes and reckoners, just as He made of them poets and Rajaz reciters. Among his wives, peace be upon him, were those who wrote and read; they are Hafsa bint Umar, Aisha bint Abu Bakr, and Umm Salamah, may Allah Almighty have mercy on them all. They narrated from him, peace be upon him, that on the Day of the Confederates (Ahzab) he was moving earth and saying:
'O Allah, were it not for You we would not have been guided... nor given charity nor prayed.'
They narrated from him, upon him be peace, that on the Day of Hunayn he was on his white mule saying:
'I am the Prophet, no lie... I am the son of Abd al-Muttalib.'
They narrated that he, peace be upon him, was hit on his noble finger by a stone and it bled, so he said:
'Are you but a finger that bled... and in the way of Allah is what you met.'
I say: These reports, if authentic, mean that he, peace be upon him, was quoting them and not establishing their meter (Wazn), confirming and submitting to what Allah Almighty informed of, and He is the most truthful in speech. It is possible that he was saying: 'O Allah, we would not have been guided were it not for You, nor prayed nor given charity', and saying: 'I am the Prophet, no lie, I am the son of Abd al-Muttalib', and saying: 'Are you but a finger that bled, and in the way of Allah is what it met', or something close to this. Even if these reports are not agreed upon, the reasoning has fallen.

It was said: Abu Ali al-Manqari entered upon Al-Ma'mun while he was reclining on his bedding. Al-Ma'mun said to him: 'It reached me that you are unlettered, that you do not establish poetry (meter), and that you make solecisms.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, as for solecism, perhaps my tongue preceded with some of it. As for unletteredness and breaking poetry, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, did not write nor establish poetry.' Al-Ma'mun sat up straight, anger appearing on his face, and said: 'Woe to you. I asked you about three defects in you, and you increased me a fourth; which is your ignorance and stupidity, O ignorant one! That was a virtue in the Prophet, peace be upon him, and it is a deficiency and vice in you and your likes. The Prophet was only prevented from that to negate suspicion from him, not for a defect in poetry and writing, nor for a deficiency attached to them.' When Al-Manqari heard that, he said: 'You spoke the truth, O Commander of the Faithful; many a suspicion stumbled upon weakness.' It was said: Of the honor of the descendants of Fatimah, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, is that no one, even if his house is great and his origin noble, but wishes he were a Fatimid. Likewise, I say: There is no one, even if his worth is high and his mention elevated, but wishes he could say poetry well and compose it, to beautify himself with it and adorn himself with its lineage. Some people said: So what do you say regarding his saying, peace be upon him: (Imru' al-Qais is the bearer of the banner of poets, leading them to the Fire). Is this praise for poetry or blame? I said: If you contemplate the intent and verify the desire, you find the meaning leads to the praise of poetry. That is because he, peace be upon him, meant the bearer of the banner of the poets of Jahiliyya and the disbelievers, who satirized the Messenger of Allah and satirized the Muslims and deserved the Fire for their disbelief, not their poetry. There is no disagreement or dispute among scholars on that. If he intended generality, under that would fall his Companions who are guaranteed Paradise, his allies who believe in him, the Muhajirun, the Ansar, and the Tabi'un. God forbid that a Muslim goes to that or a sane person or scholar says it. His intent, peace be upon him, was only to aggrandize the state of Imru' al-Qais, maximize his affair, and prioritize his poetry over his peers and counterparts, and that he deserved precedence and preference over them by the quality of his poetry, the beauty of his meanings, and the impact of his similes. So he made him for that their dean, their master, the one preceding them, and their leader. He did not deserve for his disbelief anything but the Fire, and for the goodness of his poetry anything but precedence over poets. So this attribute was fitting for him, and its mark on him true. The praise of poetry has appeared to you in the folds of this blame. Similar to that is what Al-Asma'i narrated that a Bedouin came to a cousin of his and asked him for a dowry he owed, but he gave him nothing and turned him away disappointed. He came to a Magian man and complained to him of what happened from his cousin. The Magian gave him what he requested and released to him what his cousin had withheld from him. He began saying:
'The Magian sufficed me the dowry of Al-Rabab... a ransom for the Magian are a maternal uncle and a paternal uncle.
I was made to witness your good nature... and that you are the generous, the abundant giver.
And that you are the master of the people of Hell... when you fall among those who wronged.
You neighbor Pharaoh in its bottom... and Haman and the one nicknamed Al-Hakam.'
There is no doubt that the Bedouin did not intend to diminish and lower the Magian despite his kindness to him when his cousin deprived him, especially since he ransomed him with his two sides: his maternal and paternal uncles. But he intended to aggrandize the matter of the Magian, so he made him the master of the people of Hell and neighboring Pharaoh, Haman, and Abu Jahl bin Hisham, since the Magian did not deserve anything but the Fire. If he deserved Paradise, he would have placed him with its righteous and nobles. The meaning is apparent. It was said that when Hassan heard the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, regarding Imru' al-Qais, he said: 'I wish he said that about me while I am the one rolled in the Fire,' out of eagerness to reach the ultimate goal which necessitated the preference of Imru' al-Qais over all his counterparts and his precedence over all his peers. Some people asked about the saying of Al-Radi al-Musawi:
'Why do you accept to be called a poet?... Distance to it from the number of virtues.'
We said: Al-Radi was a seeker of a great position, talking to himself of grave matters:
'Wishes, if they are true, are the best wishes... otherwise, he has spent with them a comfortable time.'

So every noble virtue and majestic merit is belittled at his desire, and every high degree and impregnable domain is low and easy at his quest. His intent is to say: How do you accept for yourself that it be said of you: 'This is a poet', limiting yourself to this mark, satisfied with this status, stopping at this end, and leaving seriousness and diligence in attaining the rank you hope for and achieving the wish you seek. Then he said: 'Distance to it from the number of virtues', meaning distance to this deed from being counted among the virtues you were singled out with, urging himself and inciting it to seek a matter that is of higher place than poetry, more expensive ornament, more fulfilling honor, more abundant value, and dearer position. He did not intend that poetry is a despicable trait and blameworthy characteristic. How could he go to that or claim it or say it, when by poetry his name became famous, his star shone, his share of literature became abundant, his arrow hit the mark in pride, he spent his life in it, and passed his time accompanying it. If he claimed that poetry is a base trait and lowly position, his claim would not be heeded, nor would it be consistent for him to argue with that against his opponent's argument, nor is his saying in it accepted or conceded to him. Preceding is the saying of the Messenger, peace be upon him, in praising and describing it, and the sayings of his Companions, which refute every argument and clarify in victory every path. What indicates that Al-Radi was talking to himself of that with which majestic ranks and noble virtues are belittled is what Abu Ishaq al-Sabi' the Scribe wrote to him, either mocking him playfully or truthful in his praise to the extreme, which is:
'O Abu Hasan, I have a physiognomy in men... I am accustomed from it that it speaks and is truthful.
It has informed me about you that you are noble... you will ascend from the heights to the furthest ascent.
So I fulfilled for you the exaltation before its time... and I said: May Allah prolong the Master's survival.
And I concealed of it a word I did not reveal... until I see its manifestation for me released.'
Meaning: Peace be upon you, O Commander of the Faithful.
'So if I live or if I die, remember my good tiding... and obligate by it a right upon you, verifying.
And be a protector for me in children and family... when the side settles in the bed of the sand hill.'
I have no doubt that Abu Ishaq is playful in his saying, and that his interior in it is the opposite of his exterior. He only brought him what agrees with his purpose and what his soul talks to him about; to move with his jest the static of his water-wheel (manjanun - or madness?), as is said in the proverb: 'Move her young camel for her, she will yearn.' stranger than this is his acceptance of his saying, and his answering him with a poem, from which:
'If signs of a cloud flashed from me... to your eyes decreeing that it be generous and pour.
It is not watering a quarter before your quarter... nor ascending an ascent before your atmosphere.
And if nights confirm a cloud from it... then be the first given drink by the new water.
And if you see a lion crouching for prey... watching the inadvertently of fates, looking down.
That is only to save its food... for you when he reveals towards it and verifies.
If time feathers me, I will be a falcon for you... pleasing you confined and satisfying you released.
I will share with you the glory I gain... with the deal of a satisfied one whether you are rich or poor.
So you go with the half that is all richness... and I go with the half that is all misery.
Others, when they fly, leave their companions... a little below the heights, falling, while they soar.
Perhaps the nights will reach a wish... and knock for me a door of luck that is locked.
Wait and do not find my resolve slow, for you will never see... a hanging thing if it does not find something to hang on.
And if age holds me back from it, then... my glory will rise with me to it, verifying.'
So how can one who has the likes of this in his soul see satisfaction with the rank of poetry and not say: 'Distance to it from the number of virtues.'

In this answer is sufficiency, for the chapter has taken its due, and Allah Almighty is the Grantor of success to tread its paths, Allah Almighty willing.

**Chapter Five**
**On What the Poet Must Aim For, Avoid**
**Discard, and Seek**

The poet must avoid trivial speech, silly words, low reclaimed meanings, and strange affected language. He should not use false similes, unknown allusions, distant descriptions, or feeble expressions. He should not abbreviate in the place of expansion, nor expand in the place of abbreviation. When he wants to build a poem or compose a piece, he should picture the meaning in his heart, represent it in his soul as prose speech, then prepare words for it that match it, choose rhymes for it that agree with it, and place it on a meter upon which speech flows smoothly and meaning is led. When he composes a verse, he should contemplate it with the contemplation of one not pleased with himself, nor deceiving his understanding and sense, and criticize it with the criticism of one obstinate in it. If it agrees with correctness and runs on the path of approval, [good], otherwise he must drop it. If two verses occur to him on one rhyme, he chooses the more effective of them and voids the other. The poet must not reveal poetry of his except after his confidence in its quality and safety from the defects scholars pointed out and ordered to guard against. He should not follow the way of the Bedouins in what we forbade at the beginning of the book. As for committing necessities that are not prohibited, their use is permissible even if they are a defect according to investigators and their speaker is considered an offender by them, except that avoiding them while permissible is better. One should not emulate those who did badly among the ancient poets, but those who did well and excelled. He should not follow except the path of good poetry, chosen composition, good method, guiding Sunnah, elegant, sweet, subtle, easy wording that captivates hearts, takes over the powers of souls, reaches understandings without a veil, attacks minds without a knocker or doorkeeper, resembling spirits in wording and delicacy, and magic in sweetness and subtlety. The poet must avoid plagiarism of poems and avoid raiding meanings. If he attempts to look at something of that, he should make his mind like a low valley supplied by flowing torrents from different reefs, or like one who composed a perfume from variant mixtures of scents, so the fragrance of what he composed is not known from which scent it is. It is told in the likes of that that Khalid bin Abdullah al-Qasri said: My father made me memorize a thousand speeches, then said to me: Forget them. So I pretended to forget them, and they sank then overflowed. By Allah, I did not want anything of speech after that except its ruggedness became easy for me and its difficulty softened for my mind. The poet should, when he composes poetry, repeat it with a loud voice, for singing in it reveals its defects and shows the affectation of its words. Do you not see the saying of Hassan bin Thabit:
'Sing in every poetry you say... indeed singing is a track for this poetry.'
The poet should contemplate the hemistich of every verse so it resembles what is before it and matches what preceded it. Scholars have faulted a multitude of ancient poets for the like of that, like the saying of Al-A'sha:
'A blaze-faced, white one, by whom clouds are asked for rain... if he fought people for their honors, a knocking.'
The second hemistich does not resemble the first, even if each one of them stands by itself. This is a meaning that should be observed and stopped at. Similar is the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'As if I did not ride a steed for pleasure... nor lined the stomach of a buxom girl with anklets.
Nor did I buy the quenching wineskin, nor said... to my horses: Charge a charge at a startled flight.'
Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Tabataba al-Alawi said: These are two good verses. If the hemistich of each one were placed in the position of the other, it would be more resembling and more entering into the evenness of weaving. As if it were said:
'As if I did not ride a steed nor said... to my horses: Charge a charge after a startled flight.
Nor did I buy the quenching wineskin for pleasure... nor lined the stomach of a buxom girl with anklets.'
The poet should avoid padding (Hashw) by which the verse is spoiled, like the saying of Al-A'sha when he praised Qais:
'And I was informed about Qais and I did not come to him... and they claimed, he ruled the people of Yemen.'

Qais said to him: O woe to you, you say 'and they claimed'. This is a word only used when doubting the truthfulness of the sayer! So he made it a padding that spoiled the meaning of the verse. If he had said:
'And I was informed about Qais and I did not come to him... despite his distance, he ruled the people of Yemen.'
He would have been free of that. The poet should be chaste in his poetry and not be publicly obscene with indecencies, nor be sarcastic in satire. For scholars blamed whoever relied on that, and whoever was immoral and did not cover up, like Imru' al-Qais in his saying:
'And like you, a pregnant woman I visited at night and a nursing mother... so I distracted her from an amulet-wearing one-year-old.'
The poet should not use a word to establish the meter of the verse while it spoils it by its meaning. If the verse dictates that upon him, dropping it is better. Do you not see Dhu al-Rumma and his saying:
'She-camels that do not cease (ma tanfakku) except (illa) made to kneel... upon bitterness or she throws with them to a desolate land.'
How he introduced 'illa' (except) after 'ma tanfakku' to establish the meter of the verse, so he spoiled it. Because 'ma yazalu' (ceases not) and 'ma yanfakku' in their speech is denial, and 'illa' is affirmation, so how can they gather! Therefore if you said: 'Ma zala Zaydun illa qa'iman' (Zaid ceased not except standing), it would not be permissible. The poet should, if he sees poetry difficult for him and refusing its side to him, leave it in that state and not exhaust his genius in it, nor burden his mind to storm its abysses. Rarely does poetry come in that state as the poet prefers. Perhaps in leaving it is the occurrence of a meaning that was not in the mind before. The like of that happened to a group of poets frequently. It was said: When Dhu al-Rumma came to Bilal, he began frequenting him and trying to start a poem about him, but poetry was difficult for him and he could not reach it. An old woman, upon whom he used to go early and late, said to him—and he was Jamil—: Your frequenting has been long, O youth. Is it for a wife you were happy with, or a dispute you were miserable for? Dhu al-Rumma turned to his narrator and said: By Allah, what I want has come. Then he began saying:
'An old woman says, my going... to her door from my family and my coming early.
To a wife in the city or for a dispute... I see you staying for it in Basra this year?'
And he continued in the poem. It was as if the old woman struck the fire-stick of his mind with her speech. The eloquent in language is to say: 'Fulana zawju fulan' (So-and-so is the spouse/wife of So-and-so) and not 'zawjatu fulan'. Ibn Manadhir said: I said: 'Time strikes at the peaks of Radwa', and I stayed a year unable to complete it. Then I heard a sayer say: 'Habbud'. I said: What is Habbud? It was said a mountain. I said: 'And brings down rocks from Habbud'. Similar to this story is what Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Nasr the Scribe narrated, he said: Za'im al-Mulk told me, he said: Abu al-Hasan al-Jahrami told me: When I composed my piece in which I describe the rooster, and its beginning is:
'O many a parted-haired, red-brown... not fearful, timid.
Darkness clung to his tails... when he donned the lightnings.
So fire is the color of his dress... and other than him is in a fire from it.
He was shod with pure gold and increased in... beautification so he was crowned with carnelian.
You think him wading the afternoon... and wetting a top with sunrises.
He walks with two spurs, either... for escape or catching up.
The glances of his two lookers became drunk... with the cup of his parting, the nectar.'
I remained for days thinking about the spreading of his leg when he treads the ground and lifting it slowly to place it on the ground. I kept closing my hand and opening it seeking the meaning. A woman who saw me said to me: What is wrong with you, as if you are playing odds and evens (tuqari'u) with someone? I said to her: You relieved me and came out to me with my goal. Then I said:
'Similar of steps he moves them... with gentle slowness.
A leg that shows you the hand of the gambler (al-muqari')... in shaking hands with the road.'
The poet should approximate between words and not distance between them, for it is a defect. As it was said: Al-Kumayt recited to Nusayb his saying:
'And we saw in it houris, pampered... white, in whom coquetry and lustre of teeth were complete.'
Nusayb tied his little finger (counted one). Al-Kumayt said to him: What is this? He said: I am counting your mistake. Why did you not say as Dhu al-Rumma said:

'Dark-lipped, in her two lips is redness and darkness... and in the gums and in her canines is lustre.'
I say: What Nusayb denied is in the place of denial, and it is an ugly defect; because the speech did not run on a consistent order, nor did what resembles it fall beside the word. The first thing poetry needs is to be organized in a sequence and placed on the mark of resemblance. It was said: The uncle of Ubayd al-Ra'i al-Numayri said to Al-Ra'i: Which of us is more poetic, I or you? Al-Ra'i said: I am more poetic than you, O uncle. He got angry and said: By what and how? He said: Because I say the verse and its brother, and you say the verse and its brother's son. The poet should avoid words that confuse their hearers and readers, and not descend in address from highness to a low place; because it is more appropriate to ascend from lowness to highness. As for words that confuse, their example is what happened to Arta'ah bin Suhayya al-Murri, who had reached one hundred and thirty years. He entered upon Abdul Malik, who said to him: What remains of your poetry, O Ibn Suhayya? He said: By Allah, I do not drink, nor get delighted, nor get angry, and poetry only comes upon the like of one of these traits. And I say:
'I saw man being eaten by nights... like the earth eating the falling iron.
And death desires nothing when it comes... upon the soul of the son of Adam of increase.
And I know that it will return until... it fulfills its vow with Abu al-Walid.'
Arta'ah's kunya was Abu al-Walid, and Abdul Malik's kunya was Abu al-Walid. Abdul Malik was terrified and it was hard on him, and the color of his face changed thinking that he meant him. Arta'ah said to him: I did not mean you, but I meant myself. A group testified before him that his kunya is Abu al-Walid, so he refrained from him. Were it not for that, he would have punished him and destroyed him. The correct narration is that the verses reached Abdul Malik, so he denied them and considered them grave and said: What is this churl and mentioning me? He ordered him brought to punish him. They testified before him of his kunya and that he did not intend him by that. When he was brought while fearful and terrified, he secured him and released him. He returned, and a group of his enemies had spread rumors of punishment and evil consequences against him, so he composed saying:
'If we appear from the pass of Laflaf... then give glad tidings to men who hate my return.
And inform them that I returned with envy... sharpening my claws and grinding my canine.
And that I am Ibn Harb, the dogs of an enemy... do not cease barking at me, or my dogs bark.'
Close to this story is what Al-Musawwir al-Anazi narrated, and he was a narrator of the Arabs, he said: I entered upon Ziyad, and he said: Recite to us. I said: From whose poetry? He said: From the poetry of Al-A'sha. He said: I was blocked and nothing came to me except his saying:
'Sumayya departed early her camels... angry with you, so what do you say appeared to her?'
Ziyad frowned and got angry. I knew what I fell into, so I went out defeated. When he passed the people, I did not dare return to him, because Ziyad's mother's name was Sumayya. Dhu al-Rumma entered upon Abdul Malik, who said to him: Recite to me the best of your poetry. He recited to him:
'What is the matter with your eye, water pours from it... as if from a pierced kidney-skin it leaks.'
Abdul Malik's eyes used to flow with water. He said: So he got angry at him and ordered regarding him, so he was taken out humiliated, having known the place of his mistake. The next day he entered among the group of people and recited:
'What is the matter with my eye, water pours from it...'
Until he came to its end, so he rewarded him. Of wondrous coincidence is that Abdul Malik had given Amr bin Sa'id al-Ashdaq his safety, deceived him and lied to him until he got him and killed him. It happened that Ibrahim bin Mutammim bin Nuwayra came as a delegate to the sons of Amr bin Sa'id al-Ashdaq. They said to Abdul Malik: We have not seen a Bedouin resembling Ibrahim bin Mutammim in intellect and virtue. Abdul Malik said: Bring him in. When he entered upon him, he saw from him what the people saw. He said to him: Recite to us some of the elegies of your father Mutammim for your uncle Malik. He recited to him:
'Excellent knights on the day of Nushba left... under the dust your slain one, Ibn al-Azwar.'
When he reached his saying:
'Did you call him by Allah then kill him... if he had called you by the like of it, he would not have betrayed.'

Abdul Malik thought that the sons of Amr bin Sa'id had put him up to that. He got angry until his chest swelled with rage, and looked at his sons frowning. They knew what was with him, so they swore to him by divorce, confirmed oaths, vowed Hajj, and forbade wealth, slaves, and maids if they knew of his saying, or looked at it, or consulted him in it, or any word or deed occurred from them in this. He held back turning away and sent Ibn Mutammim out disappointed. When they left, they gathered something for him among themselves and returned him to his land fearing for him from Abdul Malik. The poet must guard against such suspicions and turn away from them. Among the words whose readers changed them is what my father, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, told me. He said: Haydar bin Muhammad bin Ubaydullah al-Alawi al-Husayni praised Yusuf bin Ayyub with a poem. Some of his enemies took it while it was in his handwriting. Among it was: 'Let not the transgressor (Al-Bāghī) be deceived by your patience (Anātuka).' He scraped the two dots of the Ta' (in Anātuka) a hidden scraping that hardly appears or is perceived, and dotted the Ta' with the dot of Ba' (making it B), and added another dot to the dot of Nun (making it T), so the word became 'Atābak'. He brought the poem to Izz al-Din Mas'ud Atabak and said to him: This Haydar, son of your Vizier, has praised your enemy and has satirized you and called you a transgressor (Bāghī). When he saw that, he did not doubt it, nor could an apologizer remove it from his heart. Haydar was taken and deposited in prison, and remained imprisoned until he was on the brink of death. This was by misspelling one word. So one should guard against the likes of this. As for descending in address from a noble rank to a silly position, it is like the saying of Abu al-Tayyib:
'The King, the Professor (Al-Ustādh), grew up mature... before maturity, disciplined before discipline.'
It was not good in the judgment of the craft of poetry to address him as 'Professor' after 'King', for that is a deficiency in literature and ugliness in knowledge. Do you not see that a lowly word is not fit to be coupled with a noble word, and likewise a noble word is not fit to be mentioned except with what is of its kind. Other than that flaws the craft according to the people of knowledge. I have informed you that a single word spoils the entire verse. Do you not see the saying of Abu al-Tayyib also:
'And there is no merit in it for courage and generosity (Nadā)... and the patience of the youth were it not for meeting death (Sha'ūb).'
The word 'Nadā' (generosity) spoiled the meaning; because his intent was to say: The world has no merit in it for courage and patience were it not for death. Because if the brave knew he was immortal, not touched by destruction, nor harmed if he threw himself into perils, there would be no merit for his courage. Merit is only for him in courage and patience with his knowledge that that leads to the destruction of the soul and loss of the bliss of the world. As for generosity (Nadā), it is contrary to that, because if a human knows he will die, giving his money becomes easy for him. Do you not see a person when reproached for extravagance in giving how he apologizes and says: I only give what I will not remain for, nor am I confident of enjoying it. Like the saying of the first:
'I give what I am not remaining for... nor by it can I attain survival.'
And the saying of the other:
'My soul which owns things is going... so I do not grieve over a thing when it goes.'
So it has become clear to you that the word 'Nadā' spoiled the meaning. Close to this meaning is that the poet describes himself with what raises him then follows that with a saying that lowers him and puts him down. This is a defect that drops the virtue of the poet and weakens his precedence. For this, scholars impugned Imru' al-Qais, faulted him, blamed him in their books, and reproached him where he says:
'If what I strive for was a minimum living... a little money would suffice me and I would not seek.
But I strive for a rooted glory... and the likes of me may attain rooted glory.'
This is the poetry of a king boasting of his kingship and describing what he attempts of his splendid might with the majesty of his affair and the greatness of his importance. So how was it good for him to descend from this majestic mount to a despised place, and wear a vulgar robe, saying:
'We have sheep we drive, abundant... as if the horns of their large ones are sticks.
They fill our house with Eqt (dried curd) and ghee... and sufficient for you of wealth is satiety and quenching.'
This is the poetry of a Bedouin wrapped in his cloak whose ambition does not exceed what his tent contains.

Al-Hutay'ah satirized Al-Zibraqan with less than this where he says:
'Leave noble deeds, do not rise to seek them... and sit, for you are the fed, the clothed.'
Al-Zibraqan complained to Umar bin al-Khattab against Al-Hutay'ah, so he imprisoned him until he repented and returned. The poet should guard completely against a word that his listener takes as a bad omen, especially if he begins with it and opens speech because of it. How many a poet has been deprived of benefit by its path, and the robes of happiness stripped from him. Of that is what they narrated about Al-Akhtal when he entered upon Abdul Malik and recited to him a poem beginning:
'The residents lightened (Khiffa), so they departed from you (Minka) or went early.'
Abdul Malik said: Rather from you, O son of the uncircumcised woman. Take him out. So he was taken out. The next day he entered upon him and recited:
'The residents lightened (Khiffa), so they departed today (Al-yawma) or went early.'
And he continued in the poem to its end. It was said: Ishaq bin Ibrahim entered upon Al-Mu'tasim while he was sitting in a palace he built in the square, the likes of which had not been seen. With him were his family and the notables of people for congratulation. He asked his permission to present a poem congratulating him on the place. He permitted him. He began and recited:
'O house of Hind, what effaced you... after the gathering, and what wore you out?
If your people bid you farewell and became... groups, and your dwelling became effaced.
Indeed we see you while we are in you with envy... if what we were upon lasted, we see you.'
Al-Mu'tasim took a bad omen from his saying and was repelled until his face turned ashen and gloom fell upon the people. He left that assembly and never returned to it, nor did any of those present. I said this is strange from Ishaq. Were it not for a heedlessness that overtook him from Allah Almighty covering his mind so he said what he said, either for admonition or discipline, he would have had of knowledge, understanding, experience in serving Caliphs, and criticizing poets, what would restrain him from uttering the like of this. Nay, but He covered their hearts. Ibrahim bin Shakla narrated a hadith proving that bad words may run on the tongue, without the judgment of the human, despite prohibition of them and warning against them. He said: I entered upon Al-Amin Muhammad while affairs were disordered against him. He said: O uncle, why don't you sit with us so we can be consoled by your words and you lighten our worry with them? He said: So I sat and we had lunch. He called for drink and summoned his slave girl Dibsiyya and ordered her to sing. She sang:
'Kulayb, by my life, was more in helpers... and easier in crime than you, yet was stained with blood.'
Al-Amin was enraged by her saying and said: What is this? She said: O my master, this is what you used to propose to me of old. He said: Sing another. She sang:
'They killed him so they could be in his place... as her Marzbans (satraps) once did to Khosrow.'
He took a bad omen from her singing, took the oud and hit her head with it, and said: Get up to the curse of Allah. Ibrahim said: So I said, O my master, she only intended your habit of songs, so if you see fit to return. I calmed his anger, so he ordered her return. An oud was brought and she sang:
'I see the tamarisk of Wadi al-Aqiq neighboring me... so why, when calamities assassinated Yazid?'
He ordered her dragged away, so she was dragged and taken out. He swore not to hear singing that day nor drink wine. Only three days passed until his head was cut off and stained with his blood. Abu Muqatil entered upon Al-Da'i on the day of Mihrajan and began congratulating him on it, saying:
'Do not say Bushra (Good tiding) but Bushrayan (Two good tidings)... the face of Al-Da'i and the day of Mihrajan.'
When he said 'Do not say Bushra', he rose from his seat taking a bad omen, cut the recitation, changing his seat, altering. Abu Nuwas entered upon Al-Fadl bin Yahya al-Barmaki and recited to him:
'O quarter of decay, indeed humility is apparent... upon you, and I did not betray you my affection.'
Al-Fadl was disturbed, taking a bad omen from that, and returned repeating 'Allah erases what He wills'. When he reached his saying:
'Peace be upon the world if you are lost... O Banu Barmak, of those present and bedouin.'
His bad omen became established. He rose and entered the house of the harem. No one remained in his assembly but found that ugly of Abu Nuwas's choice. Abu Ubada al-Buhturi entered upon Abu Sa'id al-Thaghri and recited to him:
'Woe to you (Laka al-waylu) from a night slow in its ends.'

Abu Sa'id said: Rather woe and war to you, may you have no mother. Wonder to Allah how that escaped Al-Buhturi, and he deemed it good to face a praised one and open his speech to him with his saying 'Woe to you'. What pleased him of this opening were it not for heedlessness that overtook him!? It was said: When Abu al-Tayyib recited to Adud al-Dawla his poem which begins:
'Owhi (Alas/Pain), a substitute for my saying Waha (Wow/Joy).'
Adud al-Dawla said to him: 'Owh and Kayyah (cautery/pain), woe to you, what is this speech?' Attention is only drawn to the misdeeds of the earlier poet so the later one avoids what was taken against him and wherein he erred. The purpose of that is not to diminish his nobility, nor to detract from his merit. The poet, if he places speech in its places, and puts meanings in their positions, his poetry is clothed in splendor, and his good approach earns him praise. If he excels in his composition, but does badly in his approach and lack of prudence, the offense covers the beneficence, and he deserves after honor the place of humiliation. Among the mistakes of poets is that Abu al-Najm al-Ijli entered upon Hisham bin Abdul Malik, who was cross-eyed. He recited to him his Lamiyya Rajaz which says in its beginning:
'Praise be to Allah, the Giver, the Abundant.'
Until he reached his saying:
'And the sun became like the eye of the cross-eyed.'
Hisham got angry and ordered regarding him, so he was beaten and imprisoned. Abdullah bin Umar al-Abli came as a delegate to Hisham also and praised him. He rewarded him with two hundred dinars. Then he went out from him and passed by Al-Walid bin Yazid, who was Hisham's Crown Prince. He said to him:
'O son of the Caliph, to the Caliph... and the Caliph is soon.'
His saying reached Hisham, so he got angry and sent after him. He was returned from the road. When he attended, he said to him: Woe to you! You praised me in your poem which begins:
'My night at Kanud in Al-Ghawr, return... with the purity of passion from Umm Usayd.'
And you said in it to me:
'And He protected you from deaths from an heir, a ruler... and the Lord of Hud kept you righteous.'
Then you passed by Al-Walid and announced my death to him! May Allah make you ugly. He ordered regarding him, so he was beaten two hundred lashes, a lash in place of every dinar. Then Abdullah al-Abli stayed until Hisham perished and Al-Walid was killed. Marwan bin Muhammad rose, so he praised him and praised his two Crown Princes Abdullah and Ubaydullah, saying:
'May they not be deprived of it, nor finish with it... until the beginning with you becomes decrepitude.'
Marwan laughed and said: O Abdullah, Abu al-Walid (Hisham) has disciplined you. Some of the moderns glanced at that and said:
'And your Crown Prince continues to be an Emir.'
Among the slips of the tongue that every poet, nay every human, must avoid is what Al-Akhtal relied upon with Al-Jahhaf bin Hakim al-Sulami. It was said that Al-Akhtal entered upon Abdul Malik bin Marwan, and Al-Jahhaf was with him. He had withdrawn from the war of Banu Taghlib. When Al-Akhtal saw him, he recited inciting Al-Jahhaf or mocking him:
'Verily ask Al-Jahhaf, is he taking revenge... for slain ones struck from Sulaym and Amir?'
Al-Jahhaf grabbed his beard and said:
'Yes, we will weep for them with every Indian sword... and announce the death of Umayr with the thrusting spears.'
He means Umayr bin al-Hubab al-Sulami. Then he said: I did not think, O son of the Christian woman, that you would dare against me even if you saw me captured. He threatened him and intimidated him, and went out dragging his cloak in anger. Abdul Malik said to Al-Akhtal: I see nothing but that you have dragged evil upon your people. Al-Akhtal did not leave his place until he developed a fever. Abdul Malik said to him: I am your protector from him. He said: If you protect me while I am awake, who protects me while I am asleep? Abdul Malik laughed at him. From this Al-Sulami took his saying:
'And upon your enemy, O cousin of Muhammad... are two watchers: the light of morning and darkness.
If he wakes up, you frighten him, and if he sleeps... dreams draw your swords against him.'

Al-Jahhaf went out to his people and said to them: Abdul Malik has appointed me over the lands of Banu Taghlib. He forged a letter, filled sacks with dust, and claimed it was money. He marched with them prepared. When he overlooked the lands of Banu Taghlib, he informed them of the reality of the matter, recited to them Al-Akhtal's verse, and said: I only got angry for you, so take revenge with your people. They attacked Banu Taghlib at Al-Bishr at night while they were heedless, unaware, secure. He killed a great slaughter of them. Al-Akhtal fled that night seeking help from Abdul Malik. When he entered upon him, he recited to him:
'Al-Jahhaf inflicted on Al-Bishr an infliction... to Allah from it is the complaint and reliance.
If Quraysh does not change it with its power... there will be from Quraysh a turning away and departure.'
Abdul Malik said to him: To where, O son of the uncircumcised woman? He said: To the Fire, O Commander of the Faithful. He said: By Allah, if you said other than it, I would have cut your tongue. Then Al-Jahhaf met Al-Akhtal after that and said:
'O Abu Malik, did you blame me when you incited me... to killing, or did a blamer blame me for you?'
This is what Al-Akhtal brought upon his people and committed against them with a word he could have done without and was able to leave. He who had the strength to incite with what he incited with, it was not fitting for him to have the weakness necessitating his saying: 'Al-Jahhaf inflicted...' the verse. When Jarir recited to Abdul Malik his saying:
'Do you sober up or is your heart not sobering?'
He said to him: Rather your heart, O son of the uncircumcised woman. When he reached his saying:
'Umm Harza complained then said... I saw the water-bringers possessors of milk-camels.'
He said to him: May Allah not quench her craving for milk. Then he sent him out disappointed. The cause was what he began with. The poet should not be ill-mannered in addressing the praised one, and should avoid what suspicion rushes to, like the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'I will complain to Al-Fadl bin Yahya bin Khalid... her love, perhaps Al-Fadl will combine (Yajma'u) between us.'
Al-Fadl said to him: Woe to you, did you find no one but me to combine between you two? He said: O my master, it is a combining of favor, not a combining of pimping/connection. By my life, it has a face to be explained by, and he was rich against the accusation in it. Abu al-Tayyib followed him in it, making intercession in place of combining. Combining might be by the gifts of the praised one, but intercession is not interpreted by that, so the meaning was spoiled for him by the word intercession. Jarir praised Bishr bin Marwan with a poem including:
'O Bishr, giving glad tidings (Tabshir) is right for your face... why did you not get angry for us while you are an Emir?
It was your right to say to Bariq... O family of Bariq, why was Jarir insulted?'
Bishr said to him: May Allah make you ugly, O son of the woman who rubs herself in dust, did you find a messenger other than me?! Bilal took Dhu al-Rumma to task for a word below this approach when he recited to him:
'I heard: People seek rain from a cloud... so I said to Saydah: Seek rain from Bilal.
Kneel at the best Yamani youth... when the adverse wind blows against the north wind.'
Saydah is the name of his she-camel. Bilal said: O boy, order fodder and date pits for her. He meant that Dhu al-Rumma does not know how to praise. I say: He was not fair to Dhu al-Rumma in that; because the speech bears the possibility that he intended: So I said to the owner of Saydah, meaning himself, as Al-Harithi said:
'I stood at the dwellings so they spoke to me... and the young she-camel did not control her tears.'
He intends the owner of the she-camel and meant himself. Allah Almighty said: (And ask the town), meaning the people of the town. If this interpretation is possible, there is no deficiency on Dhu al-Rumma by Bilal's denial. A sayer might say: Why did Dhu al-Rumma not apologize for himself when Bilal met him with his rejection? The answer to that is that the narrator did not say: That Dhu al-Rumma did not apologize for himself nor was prevented from that, but his intent was to narrate Bilal's saying. It is possible that Dhu al-Rumma apologized to Bilal with that or other than it and won with his argument. It is possible that he did not understand Bilal's intent by fodder and date pits to answer him, because he is a Bedouin who does not know the idiom of the speech of the city dwellers. The point is that he was not ignorant of the extent of what we mentioned, nor far from it. As for his saying: 'Sami'tu al-nasu' (I heard the people) with Raf' (nominative) of the Sin of Al-Nas, it was raised based on quotation (Hikaya), meaning I heard a sayer saying: 'Al-nasu yantaji'una' (The people seek rain), as the other said:

'We found in the book of Tamim... The most worthy of horses for running is the loaned (Al-mu'aru).'
Ahqqu is subject and Al-mu'aru is its predicate, with undotted Ayn. It means the horse breaks loose and goes right and left from its liveliness and energy. It is said: 'Ara al-farisu wa a'arahu sahibuhu' so he is 'mu'ar'. People think 'Al-mu'ar' is from 'Ariya' (loan), which is a mistake. Some people of literature narrated it in the handwriting of Abu Ali al-Farisi: 'Al-Mughar' with dotted Ghayn, from 'Aghartu al-habla' (I twisted the rope tight), so it is 'Mughar'. Meaning that the horse, if lean and compact in its fat and stoutness goes away from it, is worthy of being raced with. I did not see scholars of language relying on this meaning, and the correct is what they narrated first. Among what the poet should avoid of bad manners in his address, and turn upon it good research and investigation so he guides to the rain of its correctness, is what poets erred in and scholars faulted them for, like the saying of some of them praising Zubayda while she was listening, from verses:
'O Zubayda daughter of Ja'far... Blessed is your visitor, the rewarded.
You give from your two legs what... the palms give to the desires.'
The servants and retinue intended to beat him. She said: Leave him, for he only intended good, but he missed the correct way and strayed from the path, because he heard their saying in poetry: 'Your left hand is more generous than the right of another, and your back is better than the face of another.' He thought that what he went to was of that sort. Give him what he hoped for and alert him to what he neglected. People marveled at her clemency and the brightness of her sense and understanding. Not every praised one is forbearing, nor every listener knowledgeable. Close to this is what Abu al-Tayyib elegized the mother of Sayf al-Dawla with, saying:
'The canopy of glory is extended over you... and the kingdom of Ali your son is in perfection.'
Were it not for heedlessness that took away Abu al-Tayyib's mind and covered his sense and understanding, he would not have addressed a king regarding his mother with that, nor made anything extended over her. This is like his saying also:
'If I could, I would have ridden all people... to Sa'id bin Abdullah as camels.'
Did Abu al-Tayyib not know that Sa'id's wife and mother are among all people? So how did that escape him until he adopted it, and confronted the praised one with it and recited it?! To Allah is the goodness of Al-Mutawakkil al-Laythi where he says:
'Poetry is the core of a man, he displays it... and speech is like the locations of arrows.
Of them is one falling short of its target... and piercing ones (Nawaqir) that take the prize.'
He took that from their saying: Evil is like arrows in your quiver when you shoot at the target. Of it is rising, falling, side-hitting, and short. The rising is that which goes above the target, not deviating right or left, and it is liked. The falling is that which hits the target. The side-hitting is that which falls to the right or left of the target, and it is the worst. The short is that which falls short of the target and does not reach it. His saying: 'and piercing ones that take the prize', meaning hitting the mark. It is said: 'Naqara al-sahmu' so it is 'Naqir' if it hits. Al-Nawaqir: Calamities. The poet should avoid contradiction in his poetry, for it is of the fullest defects of poetry indicating his ignorance of meanings and placing speech in its places. A group of ancient poets were faulted for that. It is that the poet begins with something and establishes it, then follows it, either in the rest of the verse or in the one following it, contradicting what he built, and bringing what opposes its meaning. Of that is what Abdul Rahman al-Qass contradicted in by way of the relative, where he says:
'And indeed I, whenever death settles in her soul... it is removed from my soul before that, so I am buried.'
He combined before and after, and they are relative, because there is no before except for an after, and no after except for a before. For his saying: 'if death settles in her'—and in this speech is the meaning of condition and he placed it to have an answer he brings—and its answer is: 'it is removed from my soul before that', this is a contradiction. Its example is the sayer saying: 'If Zaid dies, Amr dies before him.' So he made what is before, after. This is a meaning many people err in and do not verify. Similar to it in contradiction by way of affirmation and negation is his saying also:
'I see her abandonment and killing as two likes, so shorten... your blame, for killing is more relieving and easier.'

He affirmed that abandonment and killing are two likes, then negated that from them by his saying: 'Indeed killing is more relieving and easier.' It is as if he said: Indeed killing is like abandonment and it is not like it. Of that is the saying of Ibn Nawfal:
'To eight unbelievers and a sheikh... old of age, possessing sight, blind (Darir).'
Darir: Fa'il form from Durr (harm/blindness), and it is not used mostly except for one who has no sight. So it is as if he says: He has sight and he has no sight; he is seeing blind. This is an apparent contradiction. Muslim bin al-Walid said:
'He disobeyed youth so he went (Raha) not dotard... and stayed (Aqama) between determination and endurance.'
Al-Hakami said to him: How can a human be going (Ra'ih) staying (Muqim), and Rawah is only by moving from place to place. Then you said 'and stayed between determination and endurance', so you made him moving staying. This is a contradiction, and I have an argument for it, this is not the place to mention it. Mahmud bin Marwan Ibn Abi al-Janub said:
'I have a trick regarding one who slanders... but in the liar there is no trick.
Whoever creates what he wants... then my trick in him is little.'
He contradicted because he said: 'But in the liar there is no trick', then said: 'then my trick in him is little'. This is apparent and clear. The poet should avoid Tathlim (Notching), which is coming with nouns incomplete to establish the meter, like the saying of Alqama bin Abada al-Fahl:
'As if their pitcher is a gazelle on a high place... covered with pieces (Saba) of linen, veiled.'
He intended 'Saba'ib' (pieces/strips) of linen, so he deleted. And like the saying of Labid:
'The dwellings (Al-Mana) at Mutali' were effaced so Aban.'
He intended 'Al-Manazil' so he deleted. Ishaq bin Khalaf al-Basri said:
'And the wearing of dust and the fluttering [banners]... show you deaths (Al-Mana) at the heads of spears.'
He intended 'Al-Manaya' so he deleted. The other said:
'And the weaving of Sulaym (Solomon) every destroying, trailing [coat of mail].'
He intended: And the weaving of Sulayman, so he deleted the Nun. Another said:
'From the weaving of David father of Sallam.'
He made Sulayman Sallam, which is an ugly change. The poet should avoid Tadhnib (Tailing), which is the opposite of Tathlim. That is coming with words falling short of establishing the meter, so he increases letters to them to complete the Arud of the verse, like the saying of the poet:
'Not like Abd al-Malik or like Yazid... or Sulayman after or like Hisham.'
He intended to say: 'Like Abdul Malik', meaning Ibn Marwan, so he made it 'Like Abd al-Malik' to establish the meter. Al-Malik and Al-Malik are two names of Allah Almighty. Just because a human is named by servitude to one of them does not necessitate that he be called by the other, just as one named Abdul Rahman must not be called Abdul Rahim. The poet should avoid Ikhlal (Deficiency), which is leaving out of the wording what completes the meaning, like the saying of Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Utbah bin Masud:
'O blamer, the urgent of what I desire... is more beloved than the much slow.'
He intended to say: The urgent of what I desire, despite littleness, is more beloved to me than the much slow. He left 'despite littleness', and by it the meaning is completed. Urwa bin al-Ward said:
'I wondered at them as they kill themselves... and their killing on the day of battle was more excusable.'
He intended: I wondered at them as they kill themselves in peace, and their killing on the day of battle is more excusable. He left 'in peace', and by it the meaning is completed. The poet should avoid Addition (Ziyada) as he must avoid Deficiency. It is bringing in speech what is not needed, spoiling the intended meaning by that addition, as the poet said:
'So no drop of water of a water-hole, fresh... prevented from the hands of climbers seeking it.
Is sweeter than her mouth, if you tasted it... when a night became quiet and its stars set.'
His saying: 'if you tasted it' is an addition by which he spoiled the meaning, because he implied that if you did not taste it, it would not be sweet. If he said: 'Is sweeter than her mouth, and indeed I am truthful', it would have been more emphatic in reporting and more correct in criticism. The poet should avoid Corruption of Explanation (Fasad al-Tafsir). It is to establish a meaning then attempt to explain what he established, but not bring what matches what he presented, so he spoils his explanation and contradicts his establishment, as the poet said:
'So O bewildered one in the darknesses of night... and who feared that oppression from enemies would meet him.

Come to him, you will meet from the light of his face... illumination, and from his palms a sea of generosity (Nada).'
When he countered the darknesses in the first verse with illumination in the second verse, he was correct and excellent. It was obligatory upon him to counter the fear of the enemies' oppression with victory over them and humiliating them. But he left that and explained it with other than what he established, saying: 'And from his palms a sea of generosity.' This should have been in answer to the complaint of poverty. If he said: 'And from his palms a supported victory' or something close to this, he would have been correct, so know it and measure it. The poet should avoid affectation of rhymes and summoning them while they refuse and abstain. For it occupies the meaning of the verse with a rhyme he brought forced and difficult. This is a defect scholars have stated. Do you not see the saying of Abu Tammam:
'Like the white doe, she summered so she grazed... the flower of fresh Arar and Jathjath.'
He built the entire verse to seek this rhyme, and occupied the meaning with it. There is no added beauty in describing the doe grazing Jathjath over her grazing Qaysum and Shih. Abu al-Tayyib followed Abu Tammam in that, saying:
'Great, like what is in me, let the torment be... Is the food of this nasal-voiced fawn Shih?'
This verse has several defects: Among them is deleting the Nun in 'Fal-yaku', and its mention has preceded. Among them is deleting the Nun with Idgham. Among them is the distance between its beginning sentence and ending sentence such that there is no suitability between them; because he began by mentioning his torments and sorrows, then left that and turned to asking about the fawn's food. What preceded of complaining about his torments does not befit asking about the fawn's food. If he said that the torments I complain of in loving a fawn, Shih is not among his pastures, it would be permissible, but it is as you see. Furthermore, I wish I knew! Does this nasal-voiced fawn, whom he intended in intention to resemble his beloved, if he grazed Qaysum, Barir, Kabath, and other pastures of gazelles, does the resemblance to his beloved cease from him due to the difference of his pastures which he feeds on? If the matter is so, then his beauty and resemblance are in Shih only. Were it not for the affectation of the rhyme, necessity would not have called him to arbitrariness that spoiled the meaning. We have exhausted the sections of what is in this verse in the 'Alawiyya Epistle'. Abdullah al-Abli said:
'And He protected you from deaths from an heir, a ruler... and the Lord of Hud kept you righteous.'
Were it not for the rhyme, it would have been possible to say: Lord of Noah or Lord of Lot, since attributing to Allah Almighty that He is the Lord of Hud is not better than attributing to Him Almighty that He is the Lord of Abraham and Ishmael. But the rhyme drove him to that, and from the chokings of necessity watered him. Rhymes may come which the charms of scorpions are sweeter than. Of that is the saying of Ahmad bin Jahdar al-Khurasani:
'And no desert land tore (Shabraqat)... in which is the sound (Waha) of Jinn, Zizayzam.'
Muhammad al-Taymi said:
'You missed the face of truth in confusion (Takhtukh)... You will surely be stretched (Latumtakhan) with a stretching rope (Mimtakh).'
Ibn Manadhir said:
'And whoever antagonized you met Marmaris (disaster/smooth rock).'
Abu Tammam said:
'And they threw him with the calamity (Saylam), the Khanfaqiq (calamity/desert).'
If Khanfaqiq were in a sea, it would muddy it. Rhymes may come falling in a place that if the poet strove for another to fill its place, it would exhaust him and weary him, and undoing what he founded in it and built would be impossible for him. For the likes of this the poet must search. Of that is the saying of Urwa bin Udhayna al-Laythi:
'She withheld her greeting, so I said to my companion... What made it most abundant to us and least?'
'So he approached and said: Perhaps she is excused... in some of what she withheld. I said: Perhaps (La'allaha).'
His saying in the rhyme 'La'allaha' (Perhaps), nothing like it falls in its place. Abu Nuwas said:
'You remain and annihilation is for us... so if You annihilate us, then be (Fakun).'
His saying 'Fakun' (then be), no rhyme in the letter Nun falls in its place. Ulayya daughter of Al-Mahdi said:
'And an estranged one in Al-Marj weeping for his grief... and the helpers in love have parted from him.
Whenever the riders come to him from the direction of his land... he breathes seeking healing in the scent of proximity (Al-Qurb).'

For 'Al-Rakb' (the riders) there was a good place here, but she saw 'Al-Qurb' (proximity) more entitled to it; because the riders, were it not for proximity, their scent would not be sought for healing. If using the original is possible, no place remains for the branch substituting it, even if it fills the place well. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said describing doves:
'Until they knew the tower by signs... looming to the looker from far away (Hayhat).'
Hayhat in this place is a rhyme no other falls in its place; it is high over whoever seeks it, expensive over whoever bargains for it. For Ibn al-Mu'tazz describing two horses competing in speed, he says:
'How often I went early on a swimmer (horse)... generous to the spur, a jumper.
A short-haired, locust-like mare competes with him... when he almost won, we almost [won] with her (Kidna biha).'
Al-Mu'tamid Muhammad bin Abbad al-Maghribi said, writing it to his father:
'My master, I complain to you of a disease... by which my heart has become wounded.
Your anger has increased me in illness... so send satisfaction to me as a Messiah (healer).' 
His saying 'Masiha' is of the rhymes which no other fills its place. Of that is the saying of Mihyar:
'And they said: Can separation be while a man ties... his guts with the virtue of prudence? I said: It can be (Yakunu).'
Al-Sanawbari said:
'His death came at sixty, O sorrow... since his age was not sixty years (Sitina).'
Another said:
'My covenant with your shade while youth was a guest in it... days your quarter was to the beautiful women Ukaz.'
The rhyme is Za'iya; nothing fills its place but Ukaz, which is the name of a market for Arabs in the region of Mecca where they used to gather every year. Examples of that in ancient and modern poetry are many. The poet should not oppose the preceding poets in their habits when they liken, and their intents when they awaken and alert, for that is among what is faulted and counted among his sins. Do you not see the scholars how they faulted Al-Marrar for his saying:
'And a mole on your cheeks appears as if it is... the light of the full moon in a black night whose darkness is apparent.'
It is known that the mole is black, and the cheek white. Al-Marrar reversed it and made the mole like the light of the full moon in brightness, and the cheek like the night in blackness. This is other than what the custom of poets ran upon in describing the mole. The known is like the saying of Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf:
'The beauty of a mole on her cheek cuts my heart... when she unveils it, it sings with magic.
Indeed a mole on that cheek is better to look at... than the black spot in the brightness of the full moon.'
And like the saying of Abdul Malik al-Harithi describing it:
'As if it is a dot of musk... looming in the whiteness of ivory.'
And like the saying of Al-Sanawbari:
'And the mole on the cheek when I liken it... is a flower of musk on a moist earth of gold.'
And like the saying of the other:
'As if it is of jet-black obsidian... set in moist pearl.'
The like of this meaning in poetry is abundant. When Al-Marrar brought what breached consensus in it and opposed sight and hearing, the people of literature counted it a defect against him and a mistake from him. Among those who opposed the habits of poets in their intents is Al-Hakam al-Khudri by his saying:
'Banu Ghalib were to their nation... like the rain pouring (yakifu) at every hour.'
It is not familiar for rain to pour at every hour, nor did poets describe rain with pouring at every hour or every month. They only likened the praised one to rain for the generality of his favoring, and that he is not stingy with his gift, just as rain generalizes with its downpour, and is not dissolved by its flowing saliva. Their meanings in this are many. Among those who opposed the habits of poets in their similes is Ahmad bin Abi Fanan where he says:
'Do not lean, for I... fear that he breaks (yataqassafu).'
The beloved is only likened to the flexible rod and the moist branch, and is not described as breaking. Ibn Abi Fanan followed in his saying Qais bin al-Khatim. It has been said before that the poet should emulate who did well among poets and excelled, not who did badly and opposed the customary law. Ibn al-Khatim said:
'As if she is a fragile (qasifu) willow branch.'
Ibn al-Rumi said in blaming Ibn Abi Fanan for his saying 'yataqassafu':
'O sayer: Indeed I... fear that he breaks.
This description is nothing but... the description of a dried crucified one.'
Abu Nuwas said in the like of his saying:

'A boy above what I describe... as if his stature is an Alif.
Whenever he leans he terrifies me... I fear for him he might break.'
When Abu al-Tayyib said:
'Without embracing, two wasting ones like two forms of... Nasb (accusative vowels?), the thinner of them, and the Shakil joined [or the flank joined].'
That was faulted against him because he opposed the doctrine of poets in it and made himself and his beloved equal in wasting away. The custom is that the lover is described with wasting away, not the beloved, like the saying of Dik al-Jinn:
'Both of us are a fresh branch... so this is worn out and this is moist.
Whenever the wind blows... and the silk robe and chemise sway.
They show of him what is pleasant... and of me what love has wasted.'
As for likening himself and his beloved to two forms of Nasb, there must be a gap and separation between them. The custom of poets in the intensity of adhering and the tightness of embrace is other than that, as Ibn al-Jahm, Ibn al-Mu'tazz, and others said. We have exhausted speech and recitation on it in the 'Alawiyya Epistle', and reached the limit in it. He put 'Nahilayn' in accusative as a Hal (circumstantial), as if he said: How many a stand we stood without embracing, wasting away. The poet should improve metaphor and avoid in it the approaches denied on others; the happy is he who is admonished by another. Of that is the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'When the fox of rejection appeared to us... I sent the dog of union in his pursuit.'
Abu al-Uzafir al-Ammi said:
'Passion laid eggs in my heart... and remembrance hatched.'
Another said:
'The kindling of love nested in my heart... and the bird of distance incubated over it.
I made Nabidh for passion in the jar of my heart... so worries behaved drunkenly upon my heart.'
These are metaphors like one wearing mourning clothes at a wedding. Abu Tammam said:
'Do not give me the water of blame to drink, for I... am a lover who found the water of my weeping sweet.'
Water of blame is of ugly metaphors. He also said:
'You were not given drink after passion, water upon thirst... like the water of a sufficient woman (Kafiya) which an understanding one gives you.'
He also said:
'So you struck Time in its two neck veins (Akhda'ayh)... a strike that left it an old ridden camel.'
Abu al-Tayyib has in this chapter poems counted among wondrous wonders, including his saying:
'A joy in the hearts of perfume is her parting... and a heartbreak in the hearts of swords and shields.'
He made for perfume, swords, and shields hearts that rejoice and feel heartbreak. And his saying:
'I tasted the sweets of sons over boyhood... so do not think I said what I said out of ignorance.'
And his saying:
'So as if he thought the spearheads sweet... or thought them Barni dates and Azadh dates.'
And his saying:
'The palm engulfs his temples and his shoulder... so it gets clothed from him with the smell of the sweaty sock.'
And his saying:
'Saffron-colored in her saffron clothes... blackness from the fox grapes.'
He has many poems of this kind. Close to these poems is a story told to me by Abdul Rahman al-Daqqaq by my reading to him in the year six hundred thirteen. He said: Ibn Khayrun told me from Al-Jawhari from Al-Marzubani, he said: Al-Suli told me, he said: Yamut bin al-Muzarri' told me, he said: Muhammad bin al-Hasan al-Hisni had a son. He said to him one day: I have said poetry. Al-Hisni said: Recite it to me, O my son, lest the devil of poetry plays with you. He said: If I do well, will you gift me a slave girl or a boy? He said: Rather I will combine them for you. So he recited to him:
'Indeed the dwellings at Mayyafa... stirred a sadness that has been effaced.
They made me weep for my misery... and made my head like the nape.'
Al-Hisni said: By Allah, O my son, you do not deserve with this a slave girl nor a boy, but your mother is divorced from me three times if she gave birth to the likes of you. The poet should avoid raiding (Ighara). We have presented its mention in the sections of blameworthy plagiarism, which is: claiming the wording and meaning without the poet thinking to tire himself. No poet was blamed in thefts with uglier than it. Example of that: Waliba bin al-Hubab said:
'O brother of the soul from Asad... you slept from my night and I did not almost (sleep).'
Abu Nuwas took it and said:

'O brother of the soul from Hakam... you slept from my night and I did not sleep.'
Waliba's saying is more eloquent because he said: 'I did not almost', and he who does not sleep might almost sleep. Most of Abu al-Tayyib's poetry is from this section. From that is his saying:
'Praise guaranteed for him the return of his life... when it folded, so it is as if it is spread (Manshur - resurrected/spread).'
He took it from Abu al-Qawafi al-Asadi where he says:
'His deeds returned his life to him... when it folded, so it is as if he is spread (Manshur).'
Al-Mutanabbi said:
'And indeed a draught enriches me from water... and I have patience from it like the ostriches have patience.'
He took it from Marwan bin Abi Hafsa where he says:
