'And indeed a draught enriches me from water... and I have patience from it like the patience of camels.
And I raise myself above small ambitions... when the desirables of the great become scarce.'
Al-Mutanabbi said:
'And of the misery of the world upon the free is that he sees... an enemy for whom he has no escape from friendship.'
He took it from Ishaq al-Mawsili where he says:
'And of the misery of the world upon the free is that he sees... an enemy and loves that he be called a friend.'
Al-Mutanabbi said:
'As if the daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major) in its darkness... are virgins unveiled in mourning clothes.'
He took it from Abu al-Abbas al-Nashi' where he says:
'As if the white-footed dark horses in it... are virgins unveiled in mourning clothes.'
Al-Mutanabbi said:
'Like the sun in the middle of the sky, and its light... covers the lands, easts and wests.'
He took it from Ibn al-Rumi where he says:
'Like the sun, its place is in the middle of the sky... and its rays are in the rest of the horizons.'
If we exhausted the sections of his thefts in this section specifically, we would dedicate a book to them. It is the poet's right, if he takes a meaning he was preceded to, to change its words and make it better than the craft of the predecessor to it, or increase in it upon him so he deserves it. But if he comes with his wording and meaning, that is an ugly defect among deficient poets, let alone proficient ones. The poet should reconcile between the simile and the object likened to and observe that, so that speech does not come discordant and meanings distant. For if he looks closely at the composition of his poetry and the arrangement of his verses, and understands the goodness of its neighborhood or its ugliness, so he harmonizes between them, organizes their meanings, and connects speech in them, he will be proficient, counted among the proficient poets. Do you not see Ibn Harma and his saying:
'And my leaving the dew of the generous ones... and my striking with my palm fire-sticks, stingy.
Is like one leaving her eggs in the open... and clothing the eggs of another with a wing.'
And Al-Farazdaq and his saying:
'And indeed you, when you satirize Tamim and accept bribes... the shirts of Qais or the worn-out turbans.
Are like one spilling water in the desert, and deceived him... a mirage spread by the Samum winds.'
Ibn Tabataba al-Alawi said: If the second of Ibn Harma's two verses were a substitute for the second of Al-Farazdaq's two verses, and the second of Al-Farazdaq's two verses were a substitute for the second of Ibn Harma's two verses, the simile for them would be correct and the meanings of their poetry would be consistent. Otherwise, the simile in the two poems is not falling in its place. This is criticism from Ibn Tabataba in the highest degrees of goodness and perception. The poet should not describe his praised one in an art of the arts of his generosity, knowledge, skill, courage, nobility of origin, firmness of house, and all what he includes in his poetry of his praise, except he seeks the utmost in it and is not satisfied in it with less than the end. For if the poet comes with a meaning in which he fell short, his critic does not excuse him nor say: His work is according to the measure of his praised one. When Kuthayyir recited to Abdul Malik his praise in which he says:
'Upon Ibn Abi al-As is a smooth, fortified [coat of mail]... the weaver did well in its weaving and lengthened it.
Bearing its nails burdens the weak of the people... and the high-nosed chief is strong enough to bear it.'
Abdul Malik said to him: Why did you not say as Al-A'sha said to Qais bin Ma'dikarib:
'And when a gathered battalion comes... dumb, the defenders fear its drinking [of blood].
You were the advanced one, not wearing armor... striking with the sword, marking its heroes.'

Kuthayyir said: Al-A'sha only described his companion with recklessness, clumsiness, and exposing to danger, and I described you with prudence, soundness of opinion, and working on protection. So Abdul Malik was pleased with his saying. Yet Al-A'sha's saying in the craft of poetry and the rule of courage and valor is more eloquent and better. Kuthayyir fell short of that description, but it was an excuse with which he repelled his opponent and completed his deficiency. This is like his excuse to Muhammad bin Ali al-Baqir, may Allah have mercy on them both, when he said to him: O Kuthayyir, do you claim that you are of our Shia and our lovers, yet you praise the family of Marwan? He said: O my master, I only mock them and ridicule them, and make them snakes, scorpions, and lions—and lions are dogs—and I take their money and clothes. Like my saying to Abdul Aziz bin Marwan when I reproached him and he shied away some shying:
'And I had reproached a reproach, so persisted... with me the excess away from the way of reproach.
And your spells ceased not to extract my grudge... and bring out my mists from their place.
And the charmers charm for you until... a snake under the veil answered you.'
So I made him a charmer of snakes. And I said to Abdul Malik:
'You see Ibn Abi al-As while lined up before him... eighty thousand, their completeness has arrived.
He turns the eyes of a snake in a shell... to which the night clouds added their flow.
He turns away and overlooks while he is a lion of a thicket... if a jump is possible for him, he does not cancel it.'
When he, may Allah have mercy on him, heard that from him, he said: O Kuthayyir, whoever wants the Hereafter does not desire the wreckage of the world. This is evidence that he did not accept Kuthayyir's excuse. It is like the excuse of Ibn al-Ruqayyat in his saying:
'And some speech goes in the winds.'
And the story is known. The poet should bring his approach close and not make his request far, nor intend strangeness. For if he becomes subtle, he becomes obscure, and if he uses savage language, the ears of narrators flee from him. He should present the meaning with the wording customary in its like. His metaphors and similes should be fitting to what they are borrowed for and likened to, not repelling from their meanings. For poetry, its freshness does not please, its joy does not shine, its margins do not soften, its branches do not leaf, and its chamomiles do not wonder, unless it is with this description. If a subtle meaning, strange wisdom, or good literature coincides with that, it is an increase in the splendor of poetry. If it does not coincide, poetry has stood by itself and dispensed with other than it. If the poet follows a path other than this golden path, and his tongue and wording fall short of realizing this demand, such that he relies on precise meanings with arbitrary words and disturbed weaving, even if something of sound structure and straight organization happens within that, we say to him: You have brought wisdom. If you wish, we call you a wise man, but we do not call you a poet nor eloquent; because you went other than the way of eloquent poets. This is a method not followed by those whom scholars of this craft thanked. The poet should not antagonize the people of knowledge nor take them as adversaries, for they are capable of making his goodness bad, his rhetoric stuttering, and his eloquence restriction, and twisting his meaning, and demolishing what he built. How many a man of letters have the people of knowledge dropped the judgment of his literature, and made obscure of his mention what he excelled in. If we counted them, we would single out a book for them. To Allah is Ammar al-Kalbi where he says:
'What have I met from the Arabizers and from... the analogy of their grammar, this which they invented?
If I say a virgin rhyme in which is... a verse contrary to what they measured or scanned.
They said: You made a solecism, and this is not accusative... and that is genitive, and this does not rise (nominative).
And they incited between Abdullah out of stupidity... and between Zaid, so the beating and pain prolonged.
How much is between a people who schemed for their logic... and between a people who were imprinted on their syntax.
Not all my saying is explained to you, so take... what you know and what you do not know, leave.
Because my land is a land where is not lit... the fire of the Magians, nor are churches built in it.'

Perhaps the people of knowledge come to impossible meanings and disturbed words, so they straighten their crookedness with their reasons and fix their corrupt parts with their knowledge. Whoever is in this way, it is not good that he be angered or defamed; for many a calamity fell on one who is more calamitous than him. In the hadith of Yazid al-Raqashi to Abu al-Abbas al-Saffah, may Allah be pleased with him, is a wonder, if what he related is true, not fabricated. He said: A man from the Arabs stopped at a woman from Banu Amir. She honored his stay and improved his hospitality. When he wanted to depart, he recited:
'By your life, the shirts of Amir do not wear out... from meanness as long as their skins are on them.'
The woman said to her maid: Say to him: Did we not treat you well and do such and such? Did you see any shortcoming from us? He said: No, by Allah. She said: Then what carried you to recite the verse? He said: It ran on my tongue so it showed it. A maid came out to him from one of the tents and talked to him until he became familiar and reassured. Then she said: From whom are you, O cousin? He said: From Banu Tamim. She said: Do you know the one who says:
'Tamim in the paths of meanness is more guided than the sandgrouse... and if they walked the paths of noble deeds, they would go astray.
I see the night cleared by the day, but I do not see... through disgraces, from Tamim, that they cleared.
Tamim is like the colt of the blacks suckling his mother... and following her with a hustle if she stumbled.
And if a flea had its skin skinned... Tamim would drink from it and drink again.
And if a flea on the back of an ant... charged at the two rows of Tamim, they would turn away.
And if the elite of Tamim gathered their crowds... against a shackled ant, they would find it heavy.
And if the mother of the spider built for them... her shade on the day of dew (generosity/wind), they would shade themselves.
We slaughtered and named (said Bismillah), so our slaughtered was lawful... and Tamim never slaughtered one day and named.'
He said: I am not from Tamim. She said: How ugly is lying for its people! So from whom are you? He said: From Banu Dabba. She recited to him satire about them. He said: No, by Allah, I am not from Banu Dabba. He ceased not moving from one tribe to another while she recited satire about them, until he left no tribe but attributed himself to it and heard its satire, until he resigned, having been settled in the abode of humiliation, and said: I am a man from Banu So-and-so. The story is known. Close to it is what was narrated about Al-Mufaddal al-Dabbi. It was said: A Bedouin came to him on a camel with worn gear. He greeted and uncovered a face like the polished dinar. Al-Mufaddal said to him: From whom is the youth? He said: Ta'i. Al-Mufaddal said, and he was forbearing, rarely hasty: 'Tayya ya kalimatan fastamarrati' (Tayya, oh word, so it continued). The Bedouin said to him with a tongue sharp of tip:
'Indeed it is upon our questioner that we ask him... and the burden is not known until you carry it.'
You attributed us, so attribute yourself to us. Al-Mufaddal said: One of Banu Dabba. The Bedouin said: And indeed I am addressing a Dabbi since today! By Allah, I consider it a sin whose punishment was hastened for me. Do you know the one who says:
'If you meet a man from Dabba... then cry for him deliberately on the middle of the anus (Sabba).'
O brother of Banu Dabba, how is your knowledge of your people? Al-Mufaddal said: Indeed I am knowledgeable of them. He said: Which of the women of your people is the one who says:
'In the privacy of a night and whiteness of a day... from the son of the Wa'ili is the cure of my heart.
In a bend, I pillow him on my left... and gather with the right the tails of my garment.
And I stick my guts to his guts... and every difficult thing of my leading becomes easy.
And I let his palm touch a body that rose... on knees like the body of the back of a cup.
So he gathers my shoulders to him until... he reaches my braids with the dust of earth.
I say to him: May my father and mother correspond to you... your life from all people is enough for me.'
Then he said: Which of your aunts is this, O brother of Banu Dabba? And he began saying:
'The stumbles of the tongue are not cancelled... and by the hands of men, men are disgraced.
So make the mind a shackle for the tongue... for the straying of the tongue is an incurable disease.
And benefit from the excesses of ignorance and look... how the ignorant perish by tongues.'

'Indeed, bridling speech is preserving for honor... and by speech, speech is stirred.'
When Al-Mufaddal heard that, his color changed and his forehead dripped with sweat. Then the Bedouin left. Al-Mufaddal said: By Allah, he mentioned something I did not think anyone on the face of the earth knew. So praise be to Allah that I did not ask him for more. Al-Mufaddal's saying: 'Tayya ya kalimatan fastamarrati', is from a verse which is:
'And Tayyi' is nothing but Nabateans who gathered... and said Tayya, O word, so it continued.'
Close to this story is what my tutor Sheikh Abu Muhammad bin Abi al-Barakat bin al-Baqqal, the reciter, the tutor, narrated to me by reading to him in the year six hundred and two. He said: Abu Muhammad Salman bin Masud bin al-Husayn al-Qassab told us in the Mosque of Al-Mansur, he said: Abu al-Ghana'im Muhammad bin Ali al-Narsi al-Kufi told us, he said: The Sharif Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Ali bin al-Hasan al-Alawi al-Hasani told us, he said: Abu al-Hasan Muhammad bin Zaid bin Muslim told us, he said: Ali bin Abdullah told us, he said: Harami told us, he said: Abdullah told us, he said: Ismail bin Mahran told us, he said: Ahmad bin Abi Nasr told me from Aban bin Uthman from Aban bin Taghlib from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas, he said: Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, told me, he said: When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was ordered to present himself to the Arab tribes, he went out and I was with him and Abu Bakr, and he was a genealogist. He greeted, and they returned the greeting. He said: From whom are the people? They said: From Rabi'a. He said: From its peak (Hama) or from its jaws (Lahazim)? They said: Rather from its greatest peak. He said: Which of its greatest peak? They said: Dhuhl the Elder. He said: Is Auf among you, about whom it used to be said: No free man in the valley of Auf? They said: No. He said: Is Bistam among you, possessor of the banner and the end of the neighborhoods? They said: No. He said: Is Al-Hawfazan among you, killer of kings and stripping them of their selves? They said: No. He said: Is Al-Muzdalif among you, possessor of the single turban? They said: No. He said: Are you the maternal uncles of the kings from Kinda? They said: No. He said: Are you the in-laws of the kings from Lakhm? They said: No. He said: Then you are not Dhuhl the Elder, you are Dhuhl the Younger. A boy from Banu Shayban called Daghfal, who had just grown a mustache, stood up to him and said:
'Indeed it is upon our questioner that we ask him... and the burden is not known until you carry it.'
O you, indeed you asked us and we did not hide anything from you, so from whom is the man? He said: From Quraysh. He said: Bakh Bakh (Bravo), the people of honor and leadership. From which Quraysh are you? He said: From Banu Taym bin Murra. He said: By Allah, you enabled the shooter from the middle of the gap. Is Qusai bin Kilab among you, by whom Allah gathered the tribes from Fihr so he was called the Gatherer? He said: No. He said: Is Hashim among you... who crumbled the Tharid for his people... while the men of Mecca were drought-stricken, lean? He said: No. He said: So is Shayba al-Hamd among you, feeder of the birds of the sky, whose face is like the moon of the sky illuminating the night of dark darkness? He said: No. He said: Are you of the dispensers (Mufidin) of the people? He said: No. He said: Are you of the people of Nadwa (Council)? He said: No. He said: Are you of the people of Hijaba (Guardianship of Kaaba)? He said: No. He said: Are you of the people of Siqaya (Watering)? He said: No. He said: Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, pulled the rein of his she-camel and returned to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Daghfal said:
'The rush of the torrent encountered a rush pushing it... crushing it with its push or cracking it.'
Nay, by Allah, if you had stood firm, I would have informed you that you are from the Zama'at (small/lowly ones?) of Quraysh, or else I am not Daghfal. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, smiled. Ali said: So I said: O Abu Bakr, you encountered a calamity from the Bedouin. He said: Yes! Indeed above every calamity is a calamity, and tribulation is entrusted with speech. The rest of the story is known. The matter is as Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Indeed above every calamity is a calamity. Of the like of that, Al-Kumayt complained in his saying:
'Is half a man from half a tribe insulting me?... By my life, I have met a grave matter from the matter.
Hail to Kalb that a dog (Kalb) insults me... and I did not return an answer to a dog.
Kalb has attained a favor by insulting me... that sufficed it ancient scandals and stigma.'

Meaning that the people of baseness and lowness are not exchanged poetry with (Yuqaradun) despite ability and capacity. Clemency is the most worthy thing used by those of prudence. And pardon is not from the scholar except in the pure essence.
'Characters with which the Vizier Muhammad was singled out... and he rose by them in value over the Viziers.
He exceeded the chiefs in beauty and eloquence... and generosity that outweighed the generous ones.
And he occupied the high place as a growing child... until he rose in it over Gemini.'
Generosity is of his ways, honor of his morals, and clemency of his natures. We, the assembly of literati, are of his makings; his hands are apparent to us, and his morning clouds are coming and going upon us. The mill of our hopes does not turn except on his pole. In every case, we take from his wealth and his literature. How much literature I borrowed from the lights of his sciences, and sought a wish from the blossom of the gardens of his dreams (forbearance). I acquired fragrance from the scent of his mention, and gained knowledge (Urf - or mane/high place) from the depths of his sea. When I sought refuge in his extended shading shade, and held fast to the mountain of his might from the difficult grave accident, and was counted in the group of his visitors, and was happy to belong to the total of his entourage, he turned away from me the eye of accidents, and withheld from me the palm of disasters, and filled my heart with security, so I did not knock a tooth (in regret) after his looking at me. So thanks for his favors is obligatory upon me, and his ample armors are a screen for me from calamities:
'How many a favor and deed... I have from our master the Vizier.
My thanks for it is the thanks of the... dark green gardens for the raining cloud.'
May his state remain immortal, his blessing eternal, his elevation paved, his word guided, his authority obeyed, and his time benefit and benefitting. He has revived the dead literature with his etiquettes, and made benevolence his habit and custom:
'So all that I have is from him... knowledge, favor, and prestige.
Time refused me, so it compelled him... to care for me and forced him.'
Since speech has brought us to this end, and we have brought in what we stipulated sufficiency and more than sufficiency, it has become obligatory to conclude the book, and shorten prolixity. And Allah is the Grantor of success to correctness, Allah Almighty willing.
